revisionDesc.change: edited markup and assigned CTS URN

body.head: Plato's Protagoras
body.p: *prwtago/ras h)\ sofistai/: e)ndeiktiko/s. This is how the title appears in B, except that e)ndeiktiko/s (which is absent in T) is apparently from a later hand.B denotes the Bodleian MS. = Bekker's U: T a manuscript in the library of St Mark's at Venice (append. class. 4 cod. 1) = Bekker's t. The former is the best representative of the MSS. of the first class: the latter is supposed by Schanz to be the source of all the MSS. of the second class. Plato probably called the dialogue *prwtago/ras (compare the titles Crito, Euthyphro, etc.— the majority of the dialogues are named after an interlocutor): the words h)\ sofistai/ and e)ndeiktiko/s were added by Thrasylus, whose date is about the Christian era. The Protagoras is the sole example of an ‘endeictic’ dialogue: it is so called because it was thought to be an arraignment (e)/ndeicis) of the Sophists. That this is the meaning of e)ndeiktiko/s, and not ‘probative’, can be inferred from the fact that Albinus used e)legktiko/s in its place (ei)sagwgh\ ei)s tou\s *pla/twnos dialo/gous, ch. v. Cobet takes the right view: see his edition of Diog. Laert. III. 51). The arrangement of the Platonic dialogues into tetralogies is also probably due to Thrasylus. The Protagoras is the second dialogue of the sixth tetralogy, the others being (1) Euthydemus, (3) Gorgias, (4) Meno. See Grote's Plato, 1, 158 ff.

div.p: Socrates meets a friend, who asks him to describe his interview with Protagoras.

1. po/qen—w(/ran. The opening words of Cicero's translation of the Protagoras are preserved by Priscian (VI. 63): quid tu? unde tandem appares, o Socrate? an id quidem dubium non est, quin ab Alcibiade? h)\ = Latin an? introduces a second question intended to forestall Socrates' answer to the first: cf. Apol. 26B pw=s me fh\|s diafqei/rein, w)= *me/lhte, tou\s newte/rous; h)\ dh=lon dh\ o(/ti ktl.;

2. kunhgesi/ou—w(/ran. For the metaphor in kunhgesi/ou Sauppe quotes Soph. 222D th=| tw=n e)rw/ntwn qh/ra| to
 nou=n, w(s e)/oikas, ou)/pw prose/sxes and Xen. Mem. 1. 2. 24 *)alkibia/dhs—dia\ me
 ka/llos—qhrw/menos ktl. tou= peri\ th
 *)alkibia/dou w(/ran (= to
 w(rai=on *)alkibia/dhn, cf. bi/h *(hraklei/h for bi/aios *(hraklh=s) is a slight para\ prosdoki/an as in the English: ‘From hunting, no doubt—after the young and blooming Alcibiades.’ It was part of Socrates' habitual irony to pretend to be in love with young men of ability (cf. the words of Alcibiades in Symp. 216D *swkra/ths e)rwtikw=s dia/keitai tw=n kalw=n kai\ a)ei\ peri\ tou/tous e)sti\ kai\ e)kpe/plhktai and 216E: see also below, note on 310A l. 36).

kai\ mh/n moi kai/. kai\ mh/n is merely ‘well’ as in Phaedo, 84D kai\ mh\n—ta)lhqh= soi e)rw=. The second kai/ goes with prw/|hn: ‘well, it was only the other day that I saw him, etc.’ In the next line kalo\s a)nh/r is in the predicate: the readings of Bekker (a(nh/r) and Athenaeus (o( a)nh/r) are less good. a)nh\r me/ntoi is ‘but yet a man’)(pai=s. At the age of 18 an Athenian ei)s a)/ndras e)negra/feto.

4. w(/s g' e)n au)toi=s h(mi=n—u(popimpla/menos. au)toi=s = mo/nois is emphatic as in the usual au)toi\ ga/r e)smen and therefore precedes h(mi=n. w(/s g' e)n au)toi=s h(mi=n ei)rh=sqai apologises for a)nh\r me/ntoi: for this use of w(/s ge cf. Euthyd. 307A w(/s ge pro\s se\ ta)lhqh= ei)rh=sqai and below 339E kai\ in kai\ pw/gwnos is ‘and’ not ‘even’. u(po- in u(popimpla/menos is diminutive, like sub- in Latin. So in 312Ah)/dh ga\r u(pe/faine/n ti h(me/ras.

6. ou) su\ me/ntoi. ‘In interrogationibus haec particula’ (me/ntoi) ‘ita cum ou) negatione coniungitur, ut gravissima sententiae vox intercedat, quo modo aliquis eis quae ex altero quaerit summam veritatis ingerit speciem’ (Hoefer, de particulis Platonicis, p. 34). The idiom is very frequent in Plato, e.g. Rep. I. 339B, Crat. 439A, Theaet. 163E. Translate ‘You don't mean to say that you disapprove of Homer’.

7. o(\s e)/fh xariesta/thn h(/bhn ktl. Homer, Il. XXIV. 348 and Od. X. 279 prw=ton u(phnh/th| tou=per xariesta/th h(/bh. To insert th/n (with Hirschig) before h(/bhn would make the reference to Homer less precise. The line in Homer refers to Hermes, and Sauppe quotes Clement to show that sculptors modelled their busts of Hermes after Alcibiades.

11. eu)= e)/moige e)/docen, sc. diakei=sqai. Socrates replies to his friend's second question (kai\ pw=s pro\s se\ o( neani/as dia/keitai;)
first, and to his first question (h)= par' e)kei/nou fai/nei;) second, in the words kai\ ou)=n kai\ a)/rti a)p' e)kei/nou e)/rxomai, where ou)=n marks the regression to the earlier inquiry. Both B and T read a)/rxomai by mistake for e)/rxomai: e)/rxomai is found in a Vienna codex (suppl. phil. gr. 7) which Kral and Wohlrab place along with B in the first class of MSS.

14. ou)/te prosei=xon—e)pelanqano/mhnte. te following ou)/te throws emphasis on the second clause: e.g. Apol. 26C panta/pasi/ me fh\|s ou)/te au)to\n nomi/zein qeou\s tou/s te a)/llous tau=ta dida/skein. The idiom is very common in Plato (e.g. below 347E 360D 361E and corresponds to neque—que or (more frequently) neque—et in Latin. For the interchange of pronouns e)kei/nou— au)tou= see on 310D
19. kai\ polu/ ge, i.e. kalli/oni e)ne/tuxon.

23. *)abdhri/th|. Abdera, on the coast of Thrace, was the birthplace of Democritus and of Protagoras. The reputation of the city for heaviness and stupidity seems not to be earlier than the age of Demosthenes: see pseudo-Dem. peri\ tw=n pro\s *)ale/candron, 23 w(/sper e)n *)abdhri/tais h)\ *marwnei/tais a)ll' ou)k e)n *)aqhnai/ois politeuo/menoi and Cic. ad Atticum, VII. 7. 4.
25. ui(e/os. Schanz writes u(e/os in conformity with the general usage of inscriptions about Plato's time, but MSS. upon the whole favour ui(e/os: see the Editor's note on Crito, 45C.

26. to\ sofw/taton. So the MSS.: Schanz and others read sofw/teron, apparently the reading of Ficinus, who translates the word by sapientius. Socrates, however, is thinking of Protagoras, who is not sofo/s, but sofw/tatos (l. 31): the effect of the neuter to\ sofw/taton is to generalise the statement into a kind of adage. sofw/teron would introduce a somewhat frigid comparison between Alcibiades and Protagoras in respect of wisdom; and it should also be noted that the MSS. reading sofw/taton was more likely to be changed to sofw/teron by mistake than vice versa. There may be an allusion to some proverbial form of speech resembling that in Theognis, 255 ka/lliston to\ dikaio/taton: lw=|ston d' u(giai/nein ktl.: cf. also the scolion referred to in Gorg. 451E. The sentiment is an interesting anticipation of the Stoic paradoxes as to the beauty of the wise man.

28. a)ll' h)= expresses surprise and interest: ‘What! have you just left etc.’ So in Gorg. 447A a)ll' h)= to\ lego/menon kato/pin
e(orth=s h(/komen; Presently me\n ou)=n is as usual corrective: see on Apol. 26B.
31. sofw/tatos ei)=nai *prwtago/ras. The interest is sustained by reserving the name of Protagoras to the end.
35. pa/nu ge polla\ kai\ ei)pw\n ktl. Sauppe places a comma after pa/nu ge, but it suits the rapid movement of the dialogue better to take pa/nu with polla/.

36. ti/ ou)=n ou) dihgh/sw. Literally ‘why didn't you relate’, i.e. ‘tell us at once’. So in 317Dti/ ou)=n—ou) kai\ *pro/dikon kai\ *(ippi/an e)kale/samen; This construction of ti/ ou) and ti/ ou)=n ou) is common in animated conversational style, especially with the second person: e.g. Gorg. 503B ti/ ou)xi\ kai\ e)moi\ au)to\n e)/frasas ti/s e)stin; = fra/son o(/ti ta/xista—ou)k a)\n fqa/nois fra/zwn as Thompson remarks.

th\n cunousi/an recalls suggegonw/s in l. 34. The continual use of the words sunei=nai, suggi/gnesqai, plhsia/zein, i)e/nai e)pi/, e)ra=n and the like to denote the relation between learner and teacher in Plato's dialogues depends upon the conception of the philosophical impulse as e)/rws: see Symp. 210.
37. e)canasth/sas to\n pai=da toutoni/. The slave was doubtless in attendance on the Friend.
40. a)kou/hte. From this, as well as from h(mei=s and a)kou/ete, it appears that the Friend was not the only listener.

42. diplh= a)\n ei)/h h( xa/ris. The expression is almost proverbial: cf. (with Schneidewin on Soph. Phil. 1370) Eur. Rhesus, 162-3 panti\ ga\r proskei/menon ke/rdos pro\s e)/rgw? th\n xa/rin ti/ktei diplh=n, and Eur. Suppl. 333-4 tw=|de/ t' ei)/rhkas kalw=s ka)moi/: diplou=n de\ xa/rma gi/gnetai to/de.

div.head: CHAPTER II
div.p: Socrates begins his story. Hippocrates called on him at an early hour and entreated him to apply to Protagoras on his behalf.

1. e)/ti baqe/os o)/rqrou. o)/rqros baqu/s is the period just before daybreak: o)/rqros is the morning twilight, and baqu/s implies that it was more dark than light: Crito, 43A. A similar use of baqu/s is seen in the expressions baqei=a nu/c and baqei=a e(spe/ra.

2. *(ippokra/ths—*fa/swnos de\ a)delfo/s. Hippocrates is known only from this dialogue. de/ without preceding me/n is regular in such twofold descriptions of a person: Sauppe refers to Aesch. Pers. 151 mh/thr basile/ws, basi/leia d' e)mh/ and Hdt. VII. 10 patri\ tw=| sw=|, a)delfew=| de\ e)mw=| *darei/w|, h)go/reuon. The use of de/ in ma=llon de/=‘vel potius’ is the same.

4. h)/|ei e)peigo/menos. So BT: neither in the 3rd singular of such forms nor elsewhere do Plato's MSS. always avoid hiatus. Schanz (vol. XII, p. XV) would insert the n e)felkustiko/n in such forms before a vowel, unless a pause follows.

7. *(ippokra/ths, e)/fhn, ou(=tos. We have followed Heindorf in printing a full stop after ou(=tos. Heindorf (following Ficinus) correctly takes the words as an aside; Socrates recognises Hippocrates by his voice. The neuter comparative of ne/os regularly implies that the new is worse than the old: see on Euthyphr. 2A.

8. ei) mh\ a)gaqa/ ge. Compare Ar. Knights, 186 mw=n e)k kalw=n ei)= ka)gaqw=n; ma\ tou\s qeou/s, ei) mh\ 'k ponhrw=n ge and Blaydes in loc. The idiom originally meant ‘unless by new/tera you mean a)gaqa/’, which would be a contradiction in terms, since new/teron is kako/n. Preceded by ou)de/n it has come to mean little more than ‘except good’.
11. prw/|hn: see 309Dtri/thn ge h)/dh h(me/ran.
12. e(spe/ras ge: xqe/s is unnecessary, as the Athenians counted the interval between two sunsets as one day (Kroschel, referring to Varro, ap. Gell. Noct. Att. III. 2. 4).

e)piyhlafh/sas tou= ski/mpodos. The ski/mpous was a low stool or bed. According to a scholiast on Ar. Clouds, 254, the word means properly a ‘lame stool’ (xwlo\n krabba/tion) and is connected with skimpa/zein = xwlai/nein. e)piyhlafw= is followed by the accusative where it does not (as here) contain the idea of search for, e.g. in Rep. II. 360A (e)piyhlafw=nta to\n daktu/lion).

14. *oi)no/hs. Oenoe (probably = the Wine-country) was a dh=mos in the fulh\ *(ippoqownti/s, near Eleutherae, on the road to Thebes. The slave had endeavoured to escape across the frontier into Boeotia. There was another dh=mos of the same name near Marathon, belonging to the fulh\ *ai)anti/s.

17. e)peidh\ de\ h)=lqon. For this sense of e)/rxomai (‘come back’) Heindorf quotes Lysias u(pe\r *mantiqe/ou § 4 a)ll' h)/lqomen pri\n tou\s a)po\ *fulh=s ei)s to\n *peiraia= katelqei=n pro/teron pe/nq' h(me/rais.

18. a)delfo/s. So (not a(delfo/s) the MSS. The article is not rarely omitted with names denoting relation, as we usually omit it with ‘father’ and ‘mother’. See Kühner's Griechische Grammatik, 11, 522. The force of e)/ti is ‘late though it was’. de/ is commonly omitted after e)/peita and ei)=ta: so below, 350Dprw=ton me
 ga/r—e)/peita; Symp. 211A prw=ton me
 a)ei\ o)/n—e)/peita ou) th=| me
 kalo/n, th=| d' ai)sxro/n.

20. po/rrw tw=n nuktw=n. The plural is idiomatic: cf. Symp. 217D dielego/mhn a)ei\ po/rrw tw=n nuktw=n; Ar. Clouds, 2 w)= *zeu= basileu= to\ xrh=ma tw=n nuktw=n o(/son. So me/sai nu/ktes for ‘midnight’. In quibus loquendi formulis remarks Heindorf ‘nu/ktes horas nocturnas denotant’.

21. o( u(/pnos a)nh=ken is modelled on Homer (e.g. Il. II. 71 e)me\ de\ gluku\s u(/pnos a)nh=ken), but Plato gives a different turn to a)nh=ken by adding e)k tou= ko/pou, where e)k is ‘from’, not ‘after’ (as Stallbaum thinks). Note presently that ou(/tw to introduce the apodosis after participles is especially common in Plato: cf. below, 314C 326D

23. a)ndrei/an. a)ndrei=os occurs in much the same sense in Meno, 81D ou)de\n kwlu/ei—ta)/lla pa/nta au)to\n a)neurei=n, e)a/n tis a)ndrei=os h(=| kai\ mh\ a)poka/mnh| zhtw=n. soi/ is emphatic and should therefore be accented, like se/ in l. 28.
24. a)dikei=. a)dikei=n is often used of a past injury because the injury is regarded as continuing till atonement is made: see on Crito, 50C.

27. a)
 au)tw=| didw=|s a)rgu/rion kai\ pei/qh|s e)kei=non. For the variation of pronouns cf. Euthyphr. 14D a)lla/ moi le/con ti/s au(/th h( u(rhpesi/a e)sti/ toi=s qeoi=s; ai)tei=n te fh\|s au)tou\s kai\ dido/nai e)kei/nois; above, 309B and below, 318C The change is most frequent where the second pronoun is different in case from the first: cf. Classen on Thuc. I. 132. 5. Cobet ejects the words kai\ pei/qh|s e)kei=non, but they are supported by the parallel expression of 311Da)
 me
 e)ciknh=tai ta\ h(me/tera xrh/mata kai\ tou/tois pei/qwmen au)to/n.
28. w)= *zeu= kai\ qeoi/: i.e. kai\ oi( a)/lloi qeoi/. The exclamation is common: see Blaydes on Ar. Plutus, I.
29. e)n tou/tw| ei)/h. Cf. 354Eand 356Dei) ou)=n e)n tou/tw| h(mi=n h)=n to\ eu)= pra/ttein.

30. ou)/te tw=n fi/lwn. The English idiom would lead us to expect ou)/te tw=n tw=n fi/lwn: but in Greek the double article is avoided by substituting ‘my friends’ for ‘my friends' property’. Analogous is the usage known as comparatio compendiaria, e.g. ko/mai *xari/tessin o(moi=ai (Il. XVII. 51), where ‘the Graces’ is put for ‘the Graces' hair’.
a)ll' au)ta\ tau=ta. See on Apol. 23B. tau=ta = dia\ tau=ta is frequent in Plato and Aristophanes.

34. o(/te to\ pro/teron e)pedh/mhsen. Probably about 445 B.C., if the date of action of the dialogue is 433-432. (See Introduction p. xxxiii.) Protagoras went to Thurii in 443 B.C., being charged by Pericles to draw up a code of laws for the new colony.

38. *kalli/a| tw=| *(ipponi/kou. Callias, son of Hipponicus, belonged to one of the richest families in Athens (below, 337Dau)th=s th=s po/lews—to\n me/giston kai\ o)lbiw/taton oi)=kon to/nde). His devotion to the ‘Sophists’ in general is remarked upon in Apol. 20A a)ndri\ o(\s tete/leke xrh/mata sofistai=s plei/w h)\ cu/mpantes oi( a)/lloi, *kalli/a| tw=| *(ipponi/kou (cf. Crat. 391B): but he seems to have been particularly attached to the doctrines of Protagoras: see Theaet. 164E ou) ga\r e)gw/, w)= *sw/krates, a)lla\ ma=llon *kalli/as o( *(ipponi/kou tw=n e)kei/nou (i.e. *prwtago/rou lo/gwn) e)pi/tropos. One of his two sons (Apol. 20A), Protarchus, appears as an interlocutor in the Philebus. In 393-392 Callias was associated with Iphicrates in the command of the Athenian forces at Corinth, and as late as 371 we find him acting as ambassador to Sparta (Xen. Hell. VI. 4). It appears that he spent all his money and died in actual want (Athenaeus, XII. 52).

39. mh/pw, w)gaqe/. The MSS. have mh/pw a)gaqe/: probably the archetype had mh/pwgaqe/, by a natural mistake. Cobet rejects e)kei=se i)/wmen, reading mh/pw ge, on the ground that with mh/pw ge the Greek idiom does not repeat the verb: but there is no proof that the verb could not be expressed with mh/pw (without ge).

40. deu=ro e)canastw=men ei)s th
 au)lh/n. Herwerden needlessly suggests that e)canasta/ntes should be read, or ei)s th

au)lh/n rejected: ei)s th
 au)lh/n goes with e)canastw=men: cf. e)me\ de\ dei= poi e)canasth=nai in Theages, 129B. deu=ro we should translate by ‘here’: ‘let us rise and go out into the court here’. Classic Greek does not admit of th=|de in such a case: see Cobet's Novae Lectiones, p. 91.

div.head: CHAPTER III
div.p: Socrates cross-examines Hippocrates as to his purpose in putting himself under Protagoras, and elicits from him that his object is liberal education.

1. a)nasta/ntes ei)s th
 au)lh/n. For a)nasta/ntes after e)canastw=men cf. below, 314Cwhere e)pista/ntes is followed by sta/ntes, 328Ee)pekdida/cei—e)cedi/dacen, 361Cdiecelqo/ntas—e)celqei=n; Phaedo, 104D e)pi\ to\ toiou=ton dh/, fame/n, h( e)nanti/a i)de/a e)kei/nh| th=| mopfh=|, h(\ a)
 tou=to a)repga/zhtai, ou)de/rot' a)
 e)/lqoi—ei)pga/zeto de/ ge h( peritth/; Euthyd. 281C ou)k e)la/ttw pra/ttwn e)la/ttw a)
 e)camarta/noi, e)la/ttw de\ a(marta/nwn h)=tton a)
 kakw=s pra/ttoi and Rep. I. 336E; Phaedo, 59B; Crito, 44D; Crat. 399A-B.

2. a)popeirw/menos—diesko/poun. r(w/mh of strength of will and resolution (cf. a)ndrei/a above 310D as in Polit. 259C pro\s th\n th=s yuxh=s su/nesin kai\ r(w/mhn. gnw/mhs, the suggestion of Hoenebeek, would be much less forcible and exact.

6. w(/sper a)
 ei) ktl. a)/n goes with a)pekri/nw in l. II. The application of the similes follows in D, and each illustration contains two subordinate protases, viz. (in B) (1) ei) e)peno/eis— e)kei/nw|, (2) ei)/ ti/s se h)/reto, and (in C) (1) ei) de\—e)kei/nois, (2) ei)/ ti/s se h)/reto. With this multiplication of protases Heindorf compares Meno, 74B manqa/neis ga/r pou o(/ti ou(twsi\ e)/xei peri\ panto/s: ei)/ ti/s se a)ne/poito tou=to o(\ nu=n dh\ e)gw\ e)/legon, ti/ e)sti sxh=ma, w)= *me/nwn; ei) au)tw=| ei)=res o(/ti stpoggulo/ths, ei)/ soi ei)=ren a(/rep e)gw/, ro/tepon sxh=ma h( stpoggulo/ths e)sti
 h)\ sxh=ma/ ti; ei)=res dh/ rou a)
 o(/ti sxh=ma/ ti. The reasoning from analogy is quite in Socrates' style: see for example Gorg. 448B ff.

7. ‘*ippokra/th—to\n tw=n’ *asklhpiadw=n. It is unnecessary (with Naber) to bracket *(ippokra/th. Hippocrates, the founder of medical science, born about 460 B.C. in Cos, was at the height of his renown about the year 400. He is referred to also in Phaedrus, 270C (ei) me\n ou)=n *(ippokra/tei ge tw=| tw=n *)asklhpiadw=n dei= ti pei/qesqai) as holding the view that the human body could not be
Compare Ar. Peace, 383 ei)pe/ moi ti/ pa/sxet' w)=ndres; Pl. Euthyd. 283B ei)pe/ moi, e)/fh, w)= *sw/krate/s te kai\ u(mei=s oi( a)/lloi. The exhortation or command is in general primarily addressed to one man: contrast, however, below, 330Band Lach. 186E su\ d', w)= *la/xhs kai\ *niki/a, ei)/peton h(mi=n e(ka/teros.

28. a)/llo ge, i.e. other than the name ‘Protagoras’. It is more in accordance with Plato's usage to make the first question end with the first a)kou/omen, and regard the w(/sper clause as introducing the second question ti/ toiou=ton peri\ *prwtago/rou a)kou/omen; This second question is rejected by Cobet as spurious, but the punctuation which we have adopted seems to remove the difficulty. The w(/sper clause defines in advance the meaning of toiou=ton: for this and for the asyndeton compare Sophist. 258B-C po/teron ou)=n—dei= qarrou=nta h)/dh le/gein o(/ti to\ mh\ o)
 bebai/ws e)sti\ th
 au(tou= fu/sin e)/xon; w(/srep to\ me/ga h)=n me/ga kai\ to\ kalo
 h)=n kalo
 kai\ to\ mh\ me/ga mh\ me/ga kai\ to\ mh\ kalo
 mh\ kalo/n, ou(/tw de\ kai\ to\ mh\ o)
 kata\ tau)to
 h)=n te kai\ e)/sti mh\ o)/n, e)na/piqmon tw=n pollw=n o)/ntwn ei)=dos e(/n; Crat. 394AB; Theaet. 172D with Heindorf's note. See also 330Aw(/sper ta\ tou= prosw/pou, where the same punctuation should be adopted. In l. 31 the MSS. read h)kou/omen by mistake for a)kou/omen.

31. sofisth/n—ei)=nai. On sofisth/s see below, note on 312C ge implies that Protagoras may be a sophist only in name. ei)=nai is frequently used with verbs of naming: cf. Lach. 192A o(\ e)n pa=sin o)noma/zeis taxuth=ta ei)=nai. Cobet's suggestion to read ei)=en, e)/fhn, w(s for ei)=nai, e)/fh. w(s is ingenious but needless.
34. au)to\s de\ dh\—para\ to\n *prwtago/ran, sc. ti/ a)\n a)pokri/naio;
36. u(pe/faine/n ti h(me/ras. u(pofai/nei h(me/ra is used, as Heindorf says, de die illucescente. Here ti h(me/ras = ‘something of day’, ‘some daylight’.

37. ei) me/n ti—e)/oiken. Heindorf remarks that Stephanus' conjecture tou=to e)/oiken is needless, the vague indefinite subject being frequently omitted. Cf. Crat. 387D ei)/per ti toi=s e)/mprosqen me/llei o(mologou/menon ei)=nai; Phaedo, 99E i)/sws me\n ou)=n w(=? ei)ka/zw tro/pon tina\ ou)k e)/oiken.

39. ei)s tou(s *(/ellhnas sauto/n. ei)s tou\s *(/ellhnas goes with
pare/xwn: cf. Symp. 179B i(kanh\n marturi/an pare/xetai—ei)s tou\s *(/ellhnas. Young men of fashion were fond of looking to Greek, as opposed to Athenian, public opinion. The MSS. have au(to/n, but the use of the third personal reflexive pronoun for the first and second in the singular number does not seem to be certain in Plato; and it is simplest to suppose that s fell out after *(/ellhnas: Schanz, VII, xii.

41. a)ll' a)/ra—mh\ ou) toiau/thn. ou) goes closely with toiau/thn, and mh/ is virtually ‘perhaps’ (originally ‘lest’ as in o(/ra mh/ Theaet. 145B): ‘but perhaps after all (a)/ra) this is not the kind of learning which etc.’ Cf. Euthyd. 290E a)ll' a)/ra—mh\ o( *kth/sippos h)=n o( tau=t' ei)pw/n and Apol. 25A a)ll' a)/ra—mh\ oi( e)n th=| e)kklhsi/a?, oi( e)kklhsiastai/, diafqei/rousi tou\s newte/rous; Meno, 89C mh\ tou=to ou) kalw=s w(mologh/samen. In all of these passages it is better to take mh/ in this way than as equivalent to Latin num. From this use of mh/ grew up the use of mh/pote = ‘perhaps’, frequent in Aristotle and later, e.g. Eth. Nic. X. 2. 1173a. 22 mh/ pot' ou) le/gousin to ai)/tion.

43. oi(/aper h( para) is the reading of T: B has oi(/a peri\. The grammatistai/ of Athens were schoolmasters, who besides teaching reading and writing (cf. below, 326D translated (e(rmhneu/ein) Homer and interpreted his glw=ttai. They were distinct from the grammatikoi/ or kritikoi/ who pursued more scientific literary and grammatical studies. The kiqaristh/s and grammatisth/s between them taught mousikh/, and the paidotri/bhs gumnastikh/; and mousikh/ and gumnastikh/ were the two parts of paidei/a or liberal education: Rep. II. 376E.

45. e)pi\ te/xnh|—a)ll' e)pi\ paidei/a|: cf. 315Ae)pi\ te/xnh| manqa/nei, w(s sofisth\s e)so/menos. The distinction between professional and liberal (w(s to\n i)diw/thn kai\ to\n e)leu/qeron pre/pei) education is frequently emphasised by Plato (see especially Laws, I. 643D): his word for the latter is always paidei/a, cf. Gorg. 485A, Rep. VI. 492C. The ‘arts’ are throughout the Republic looked on as ba/nausoi, and unfit for men whose souls are free.

div.head: CHAPTER IV
div.p: Socrates continues his cross-examination, and reduces Hippocrates to a)pori/a.

3. parasxei=n qerapeu=sai a)ndri( sofisth=|. The word pare/xw is often used of putting oneself in the hands of a doctor: cf. Gorg. 456B fa/rmakon piei=n h)\ temei=n h)\ kau=sai parasxei=n tw=? i)atrw=|. a)nh/r is regularly used (mostly in a complimentary sense, real or feigned) with words which denote one's profession, standing or the like, e.g. a)nh\r ma/ntis, a)nh\r nomeu/s, a)/ndres dikastai/; cf. Euthyphr. 15D. For parasxei=n Cobet reads pare/xein, but if MSS. can be trusted, Plato used the aorist infinitive with me/llw tolerably often: see Schanz, Preface to Symposium, p. vii.

6. ou)/t' ei) a)gaqw=| ou)/t' ei) kakw=| pra/gmati. So in Gorgias 520B ou)k e)gxwrei=n me/mfesqai tou/tw| tw=| pra/gmati (their pupils) o(\ au)toi\ paideu/ousin. Here Socrates uses the most general form of expression because ex hypothesi nothing is yet known as to the sophist: cf. below, 330Ch( dikaiosu/nh pra=gma/ ti/ e)stin h)\ ou)de\n pra=gma; Cases like Crito, 53D ou)k oi)/ei a)/sxhmon a)\n fanei=sqai to\ tou= *swkra/tous pra=gma; are somewhat different and contain a slight admixture of contempt: see the Editor's note in loc.

7. oi)=mai/ g' ei)de/nai. Hippocrates oi)/etai ei)de/nai mh\ ei)dw/s: he is thus, according to Socrates, in the worst of all states: cf. Apol. ch. VI ff. Socrates now proceeds to convict him of ignorance.

8. w(/sper tou)/noma le/gei—tw=n sofw=n e)pisth/mona. Hippocrates derives sofisth/s from sofo/s and (e)p)i/st(amai) ‘quasi sit o( tw=n sofw=n i)/sths’ (Heindorf, comparing the derivation of *(/hfaistos in Crat. 407C from *fa/eos i(/stwr). The correct derivation is perhaps given by Suidas s.v.: sofisth\s kai\ o( dida/skalos w(s sofi/zwn (cf. swfroni/zw=make sw/frwn), but -i/zw is very elastic in meaning, and sofi/zw may very well mean ‘play the sofo/s’.

12. tw=n ti/ sofw=n. tw=n pro\s ti/ sofw=n would be more precise, but the accusative of reference is preferred for brevity. For the construction Kroschel compares Theages, 125C tw=n ti/ sofw=n sunousi/a| fh\|s sofou\s ei)=nai tou\s tura/nnous, where, however, sofw=n
is masculine. The neuter of sofo/s is not here used ironically as in Theaet. 157C parati/qhmi e(ka/stwn tw=n sofw=n a)pogeu/sasqai.

15. o( de\ sofisth\s tw=n ti/ sofw=n e)stin. Heusde suggested e)pisth/mwn after e)stin, but the sense can be supplied out of the -isth/s of sofisth/s, according to the derivation of the word just given: the full sense is as it were o( de\ sofisth\s tw=n ti/ sofw=n e)stin (sof)isth/s.

16. ti/ a)\n a)pokrinoi/meqa au)tw=|. There is no need to change the verb to a)pokrinai/meqa, as was done by Bekker to suit e)/roito: cf. below, 354Aei) e)roi/meqa—fai=en a)/n and Phaedr. 259A ei) ou)=n i)/doien—dikai/ws a)\n katagelw=|en.

17. poi/as e)rgasi/as e)pista/ths. These words are not of course part of the imaginary questioner's interrogation, but are spoken by Socrates to help out Hippocrates' answer. Socrates suggests that Hippocrates should say that the sophist is e)pista/ths of some sort of e)rgasi/a, but in order that the answer should come from Hippocrates himself, he substitutes for the desired answer: ‘(The sophist is) e)pista/ths—of what kind of e)rgasi/a?’ Hippocrates then replies by explaining the e)rgasi/a, viz. to\ poih=sai deino
 le/gein. The full grammatical construction would be poi/as e)rgasi/as e)pista/ths (o(/ti e)sti
 a)pokrinai/meqa a)
 au)tw=|); If we take this view, it is not necessary to insert e)sti/n after e)pista/ths (with Hirschig).

Note that e)pista/ths is substituted here for e)pisth/mwn: it is clear from Crito, 47B, that Plato connected the two words— probably because both contain the syllable -ist- as in i(/stwr: he frequently plays on the similarity of form between e)pi/stamai e)pisth/mh and e)pistatei=n: see the Editor's note on e)pista/th| kai\ e)pai+/onti in the Crito, loc. cit.

17. ti/ a)
 ei)/poimen—w)= *sw/krates; Hippocrates is on the verge of a)pori/a, and merely throws out his suggestion e)pista/thn tou= poih=sai deino
 le/gein for what it is worth. The words e)pista/thn tou= poih=sai deino
 le/gein are strictly speaking a reply to the question of Socrates poi/as e)rgasi/as e)pista/ths; for tou= poih=sai deino
 le/gein answers poi/as e)rgasi/as, and but for the intervening clause (ti/ a)
 ei)/poimen au)to
 ei)=nai;) the word e)pista/thn would have been in the nominative.

Thus explained, the MSS. reading need not be changed.
The next best view is to read (with Schanz) ti/ a)
 <ei)> ei)/poimen
au)to
 ei)=nai, w)= *sw/krates, e)pista/thn tou= poih=sai deino
 le/gein;

22. w(/sper o( kiqaristh\s ktl. Cf. Gorg. 449E and 451A ff.,
where much the same reasoning is employed to discover ti/ e)sti tou=to tw=n o)/ntwn, peri\ ou(= ou(=toi oi( lo/goi ei)si/n, oi(=s h( r(htorikh\ xrh=tai (Gorg. 451D). Rhetoric and Sophistic were regarded by Plato as sisters: cf. Gorg. 464B ff. The clause w(/sper o( kiqaristh\s ktl. is logically the protasis to ei)=en: o( de\ dh\ sofisth\s ktl.: see on 311Eabove.
24. ei)=en: o( de\ dh\ sofisth/s. For ei)=en and de\ dh/ see on 311Cabove.

25. dh=lon o(/ti peri\ ou(=per kai\ e)pi/stasqai. Stahl's emendation (e)pi/stasqai for e)pi/statai), which had occurred to us independently, seems to be certain. Most editions read h)\ dh=lon o(/ti peri\ ou(=per kai\ e)pi/statai; inserting h)/ before dh=lon (with Heindorf) and giving the words to Socrates, but it is surely more natural to regard them as giving Hippocrates' reply to Socrates' question, in which case dh=lon o(/ti is right. The MS. reading e)pi/statai gives a non sequitur; for the harpist makes one deino\s le/gein peri\ ou)=per kai\ e)pisth/mona i.e. peri\ ou)=per kai\ e)pi/stasqai, not peri\ ou(=per kai\ e)pisth/mwn-e)sti
 i.q. e)pi/statai. The next sentence ti/ dh/ e)sti tou=to, peri\ ou(= au)to/s te e)pisth/mwn e)sti
 o( sofisth\s kai\ to
 maqhth
 poiei= (sc. e)pi/stasqai); in no way invalidates the reading e)pi/stasqai: it is everywhere assumed in the Platonic writings that he who makes others know has knowledge himself: see for example Alcib. I, 111B ou)k oi)=sq' o(/ti xrh\ tou\s me/llontas dida/skein o(tiou=n au)tou\s prw=ton ei)de/nai; h)\ ou)/; pw=s ga ou)/; and ibid. 113C, 118C.
27. ou)ke/ti. See below on ou)ke/ti in 321D

div.head: CHAPTER V
div.p: Socrates points out that Hippocrates is running a grave risk in submitting himself to one of the ‘Sophists’ without knowing what ‘Sophist’ means.

2. h)\ ei) me
 to\ sw=ma ktl. For h)/ cf. Crito, 50E h)\ pro\s me
 a)/pa soi to
 rate/pa—rpo\s de\ th
 ratpi/da a)/pa kai\ tou\s no/mous e)/stai soi; and for the general form of the sentence Apol. 28E ei) o(/te me/n—to/te me/n—tou= de\ qeou= ta/ttontos—e)ntau=qa de/, Meno, 94C-D, Gorg. 512A: see the Editor's note on Apol. loc. cit.

4. polla\ a)
 perieske/yw: but e)/dei in l. 3 and pareka/leis in
6. The effect is to represent the process of reflection by oneself as prior to consultation with friends. Heindorf on Gorg. 514D quotes a parallel from the Theaetetus (144E): a)ta ei), nw=|n e)xo/ntoin e(kate/pou lu/pan, e)/fh au)ta\s h(pmo/sqai o(moi/ws, ro/tepon eu)qu\s a)
 e)pisteu/omen h)\ e)peskeya/meqa a)
 (i.e. should have inquired first) ei) mousiko\s w)
 le/goi;

8. th
 yuxh/n. Cf. (with Heindorf) Rep. IX. 583E o(\ metacu\ a)/pa nu=n dh\ a)mfote/pwn e)/famen ei)=nai, th
 h(suxi/an, tou=to/ rote a)mfo/tera e)/stai. e)n w(=| presently is like e)n tou/tw| in 310D where see note: Heindorf cites Eur. Iph. T. 1057 kai\ ta)/m' e)n u(mi=n e)stin h)\ kalw=s e)/xein h)\ mhde
 ei)=nai. For kai\ e)n w(=| we should at first sight expect kai\ e)n au)tw=|: for the Greek idiom is relative+anaphoric pronoun, not relative+relative, when the two pronouns have the same antecedent and are connected by a conjunction: e.g. Gorg. 452D ti/ e)sti tou=to o(\ fh\|s su\ me/giston a)gaqo
 ei)=nai—kai\ se\ dhmiourgo
 ei)=nai au)tou=: see the Editor's note on Apol. 40A. Here, however, the fact that the relative precedes its antecedent (o(\ de\ peri\ plei/onos—peri\ de\ tou/tou) makes the rule inoperative; and there are other exceptions, e.g. Rep. II. 374B kai\ tw=n a)/llwn e(ni\ e(ka/stw| w(sau/tws e(
 a)redi/domen, rpo\s o(\ refu/kei e(/kastos kai\ e)f' w(=| e)/melle tw=n a)/llwn sxolh
 a)/gwn dia\ bi/ou au)to\ e)pgazo/menos—kalw=s a)perga/zesqai, and Theaet. 192B kai\ o(\ oi)=den kai\ o(\ ai)sqa/netai (where, however, Bonitz rejects the second o(/, perhaps rightly).

12. tw=| a)fikome/nw| tou/tw| ce/nw|. Heindorf's suggestion tw=| a)fikome/nw| tou/tw| tw=| ce/nw| would convey a somewhat different meaning, viz. ‘this arrival, the foreigner’. The presence of a)fikome/nw| renders the article after tou/tw| unnecessary: cf. below, 337Eto\ a)kribe\s tou=to ei)=dos. There is some contempt in tou/tw|= isti (see note on Apol. 45A), and much scorn in th\n sh\n yuxh/n, repeated slowly at the end of the clause.
13. o)/rqrios: the MSS. have o)/rqrion by mistake. The adjectival construction of this word is found in Laws, XII. 961B dei=n de\ o)/rqrion ei)=nai to\n su/llogon.

18. gignw/skeis. The present is regularly used of being acquainted with a person, e.g. Phaedo, 60A *canqi/pphn, gignw/skeis ga/r; Theaet. 144C a)lla\ sko/pei ei) gignw/skeis au)to/n. gignw/skw. In Plato the perfect is generally used of knowing things: e.g. Apol. 23B o(/stis—e)/gnwken o(/ti ktl., Euthyphr. 2C tosou=ton pra=gma e)gnwke/nai.
ou)/te diei/lecai ou)depw/pote, sc. au)tw=|: cf. on 313A l. 8 above.

20. w(=| me/lleis sauto
 e)pitre/pein is wrongly rejected by Cobet. The words are to be taken closely with to
 de\ sofisth
 o(/ ti/ pot' e)/stin fai/nei a)gnow=n: that Hippocrates should entrust himself to that of which he knows nothing is the climax of Socrates' rebuke.

21. e)/oiken: sc. ei)=nai, i.e. be true (not e)me\ a)gnoei=n, which is doubtful Greek for e)/oika a)gnoei=n). The subject is simply ‘it’, as in Rep. I. 333C, where e)/oiken is similarly for e)/oiken ei)=nai.

23. tugxa/nei w)\n—yuxh\ tre/fetai. tugxa/nei w)/n is virtually equivalent to ‘really is’: cf. Gorg. 468D oi)o/menos a)/meinon ei)=nai au)tw=|, tugxa/nei de\ o)\n ka/kion, and note on Euthyphr. 4E. The e)/mporos is a travelling merchant who trades on a larger scale than the retail dealer or ka/phlos: see Rep. II. 371D h)\ ou) kaph/lous kalou=men tou\s rpo\s w)nh/n te kai\ rpa=sin diakonou=ntas i(dpume/nous e)n a)gora=|, tou\s de\ planh/tas e)pi\ ta\s po/leis e)mpo/rous; The same account of the Sophist as e)/mporo/s tis peri\ ta\ th=s yuxh=s maqh/mata (Soph. 231E) is given in Soph. 223C-224E.

24. fai/netai ga\r e)/moige toiou=to/s tis. We follow Schleiermacher in giving these words to Socrates. Turner judiciously points out that ge in e)/moige is only appropriate if Socrates speaks the words, and that Hippocrates could hardly assent till he knew what trofh\ yuxh=s meant.

26. o(/pws ge mh\—e)painw=n a(\ pwlei= e)capath/sei. pwlei=n is ‘to have on sale’: ‘to sell’ is a)podi/dosqai. Cobet, Novae Lectiones, p. 159. For e)capath/sei the MSS. have e)capath/sh|, but the 1st aor. conj. is very doubtful in Plato after o(/pws mh/ (see on the whole question Kühner's Griechische Grammatik, II, 899), and final -h| and -ei are frequently confused in the MSS.

28. o( e)/mporo/s te kai\ ka/phlos. e)/mporo/s te kai\ ka/phlos together make a plural, and according to strict logic would require a plural article; but o( is written by attraction instead of the grammatically impossible oi(. Cf. Symp. 186C o( diagignw/skwn —to\n kalo/n te kai\ ai)sxro\n e)/rwta; below, 355Eta/ o)no/mata—to\ h(du/ te kai\ a)niaro/n.

40. tugxa/neis e)pisth/mwn. tugxa/neis has sunk to a mere copula. It is not necessary to insert w)/n after e)pisth/mwn, although it is only in a few cases that tugxa/nw (in this sense) occurs in Plato's MSS. without the participle expressed, viz. Phaedr. 263C me/giston tw=n a)gaqw=n tugxa/nei; Gorg. 502B ei) de/ ti tugxa/nei a)hde\s kai\ w)fe/limon; Rep. II. 369B tugxa/nei h(mw=n e(/kastos ou)k au)ta/rkhs a)lla\ pollw=n e)ndeh/s; Alc. I, 129A r(a/|dion tugxa/nei to\ gnw=nai e(auto/n; ibid. 133A e)kei=no w(=| tou=to tugxa/nei o(/moion. In these cases (as here in the Protagoras) it is easy to suppose that the participle has fallen out from ‘lipography’: but in Hipp. Maior (perhaps pseudo-Platonic), 300Aand in Laws, XI. 918C, and Timaeus, 61C, the participle cannot be so easily supplied: and that the construction without the participle was used in everyday speech appears from Ar. Eccl. 1141 kai\ tw=n qeatw=n ei)/ tis eu)/nous tugxa/nei. See Rutherford's New Phrynichus, p. 342.
43. peri\ toi=s filta/tois. ta\ fi/ltata is used here of the soul's health as in Gorg. 513A su\n toi=s filta/tois h( ai(/resis h(mi=n e)/stai tau/ths th=s duna/mews th=s e)n th=| po/lei.

44. kubeu/h|s te kai\ kinduneu/h|s. Cobet rejects te kai\ kinduneu/h|s, but Plato often puts metaphor and interpretation side by side. Cf. below 314Be)n au)th=| th=| yuxh=| labo/nta kai\ maqo/nta (where Deuschle wrongly rejected kai\ maqo/nta); 334Dsu/ntemne/ moi ta\s a)pokri/seis kai\ braxute/ras poi/ei; Euthyd. 297C polu\ ga/r pou/ ei)mi faulo/teros tou= *(hrakle/ous, o(\s ou)x oi)=o/s te h)=n th=| te u(/dpa| diama/xesqai, sofistpi/a| ou)/sh| kai\ dia\ th
 sofi/an a)niei/sh|, ei) mi/an kefalh
 a)rotmhqei/h tou= lo/gou, rolla\s a)nti\ th=s mia=s, kai\ kapki/nw| tini\ e(te/pw| sofisth=| . . . o(\s e)reidh\ au)to
 e)lu/rei ou(/tws e)k tou= e)p' a)ristera\ le/gwn kai\ da/knwn ktl.; Lach. 194C xeimazome/nois e
 lo/gw| kai\ a)porou=sin; Theaet. 174C ei)s fre/ata/ te kai\ pa=san a)pori/an e)mpi/ptwn. See also note on tou\s tw=n ne/wn ta\s bla/stas diafqei/rontas in Euthyphr. 3A.

47. para\ tou= kaph/lou kai\ e)mpo/rou: so B. The ka/phlos is put in the foreground as the most usual seller of siti/a and pota/: the article is expressed only once, because the ka/phlos and e)/mporos both belong to the same genus ‘merchants’: cf. Hdt. IV. 71 to\n oi)noxo/on kai\ ma/geiron kai\ i(ppoko/mon kai\ dih/konon kai\ a)ggelihfo/ron ktl. There is no sufficient ground for bracketing
the words para\ tou= kaph/lou kai\ e)mpo/rou as is done by Schanz, nor for reading para/ tou (with T) and omitting kaph/lou kai\ e)mpo/rou, as Hermann did.

e)n a)/llois a)ggei/ois: i.e. other than our own bodies. Cf. 311Eti/ o)/noma a)/llo ge lego/menon peri\ *prwtago/rou a)kou/omen; It need not be implied that the body is itself an a)ggei=on (viz. of soul), though the notion is not unplatonic, and kindred expressions are found in later philosophy, e.g. Marcus Aurel. X. 38 to\ perikei/menon a)ggeiw=des kai\ ta\ o)rga/nia tau=ta ta\ peripeplasme/na (said of the body).

54. e)n au)th=| th=| yuxh=| labo/nta kai\ maqo/nta. lamba/nein e)n (not ei)s) as in Rep. VII. 517A ei)/ pws e)n tai=s xersi\ du/nainto labei=n; Soph. 243C tau)to\n tou=to pa/qos ei)lhfo/tes e)n th=| yuxh=|. For kai\ maqo/nta, which is explanatory of e)n au)th=| th=| yuxh=| labo/nta, see note on kubeu/h|s te kai\ kinduneu/h|s.

57. ne/oi w(/ste tosou=ton. Heindorf quotes Eur. Andr. 80 ge/rwn e)kei=nos w(/ste s' w)felei=n parw/n, and points out that whereas new/teroi h)\ w(/ste would deny altogether h( tou= diele/sqai du/namis, the words ne/oi w(/ste are less strong; nobis nonnisi iuvenilis quaedam facultas suppetit ad tantam rem diiudicandam. The best MSS. of Plato read tau)to/n, toiou=ton, tosou=ton, etc., in the great majority of cases rather than tau)to/, etc. Schanz (Preface to Laws, p. vi) thinks it probable that Plato always used the forms in -n. In inscriptions of Plato's time to\ au)to/ and to\ au)to/n occur side by side, but apparently only toiou=ton, tosou=ton. See Meisterhans, Grammatik der Griechischen Inschriften2, p. 122.

61. *(ippi/as. Hippias of Elis was one of the most accomplished and—if we may trust the Platonic writings—ostentatious of the Sophists. According to the Hippias Maior (285B ff.) he claimed to be at home in all the learning of the day—in Astronomy, Geometry, Arithmetic, Philology, Music, Mythology, History and Archaeology. See Zeller's Philosophie der Griechen, I4, 956 ff.

62. oi)=mai de\ kai\ *pro/dikon to\n *kei=on. Contrast Crat. 402B oi)=mai de\ kai\ *(hsi/odos. Either construction is admissible. Prodicus of Ceos is repeatedly mentioned in the Platonic writings. A fellow-citizen of the poet Simonides (below, 339E, he professed like Gorgias and Hippias to educate young men (Apol. 19E,
Theages, 127E, Rep. X. 600C) and received very large sums in return for his instruction together with the gratitude of his pupils. On one occasion, when in charge of a political mission from Ceos, he is said to have won great reputation in the boulh/ at Athens for his conduct of public business, and to have given at the same time private lectures, which were popular and well paid (Hipp. Maior, 282C). He laid great stress on the importance of using words in their correct sense (o)rqo/ths o)noma/twn): see below, 337A 358A and Euthyd. 277E, Charm. 163D, Lach. 197D; cf. also Phaedr. 267B; but this was only taught (we are told) in his 50-drachma lecture; the impecunious Socrates had only paid one drachma and was not quite master of this subject (Crat. 384B). Socrates is fond of professing himself a pupil of Prodicus, e.g. below, 341A Meno, 96D, Charm. 163D. Prodicus wrote eulogies of Heracles and others (Symp. 177B): the substance, if not the actual words, of his Apologue of Heracles at the cross-roads is given by Xenophon, Mem. II. 1. 21. A scholiast on Rep. X. 600C says the Athenians put him to death by hemlock for corrupting the youth, but there is no other authority for this unlikely story. Cf. Zeller, I4, 952 ff.

div.head: CHAPTER VI
div.p: Socrates and Hippocrates proceed together to Callias' house.

1. do/can h(mi=n tau=ta. This idiom seems not to occur elsewhere in Plato. We can hardly supply poiei=n: rather do/can tau=ta is like do/canta tau=ta, an accusative absolute, the singular verb being kept as in e)/doce tau=ta. See Goodwin's Moods and Tenses (1889), p. 339, § 854.

2. proqu/rw|. The rooms of a Greek house opened on the cloisters surrounding the au)lh/ or court: from the au)lh/ a passage (qurwrei=on, so called because the porter's lodge was situated in it) led into the pro/quron or space in front of the main door (au)/leios qu/ra or au)lei/a without qu/ra). Blümner, Griechische Privatalterthümer, pp. 147 ff.
e)pista/ntes dielego/meqa. The situation recalls Symp. 175A ff., where Socrates, on his way to Agathon's house, is discovered standing wrapt in thought in front of a neighbouring house.
4. ou(/tws e)si/oimen. ou(/tws with the apodosis after participles is extremely common in Plato: see above on 310D

5. sta/ntes. For the dropping of the preposition after e)pista/ntes
see on 311A The Bodleian has e)sta/ntes, but T sta/ntes: Schanz reads e)pista/ntes, Cobet e(stw=tes. Tr. ‘we came to a stand and conversed’.

6. dokei= ou)=n moi. Cf. Phaedo, 108D o( bi/os moi dokei= o( e)mo\s— tw=| mh/kei tou= lo/gou ou)k e)carkei=: the construction is fairly common in Plato: see on Crito, 43D. To have a eunuch for porter was rare, and a mark of wealth: they were supposed to be more trustworthy than others and fetched a higher price in the East (Hdt. VIII. 105).

7. kinduneu/ei—a)/xqesqai. Present, because the dialogue is narrated just after it took place (see 309B, and as Protagoras is still with Callias, the stream of visitors probably continues. It is not quite clear why the number of the sophists should have made the porter annoyed with the visitors, unless the visitors themselves were sophists. Probably therefore toi=s foitw=sin means toi=s foitw=sin sofistai=s: in the porter's judgement the house was already too full of sophists. foita=n implies frequent visitation: cf. Lach. 181C xrh=n me\n ou)=n kai\ pro/tero/n se foita=n au)to\n par' h(ma=s kai\ oi)kei/ous h(gei=sqai.
9. e)krou/samen th\n qu/ran. There was a metal knocker (r(o/ptron, ko/rac, e)pi/spastron) on the au)/leios qu/ra. Blümner, Gr. Privatalt. p. 149.
10. ou) sxolh\ au)tw=|. For au)tw=| ‘the master’ cf. below, 315B Rep. I. 327B h)ro/mhn o(/pou au)to\s ei)/h, and the Pythagorean au)to\s e)/fa ipse dixit.
11. a)mfoi=n toi=n xeroi=n. So B: T has tai=n for toi=n. Cobet has shown that the dual feminine of the article is the same as the dual masculine: Variae Lectiones, p. 70.
13. e)krou/omen, but e)krou/samen in l. 9. Socrates pretends to be somewhat staggered by the rebuff.
e)gkeklh|me/nhs. So Bekker for e)gkekleime/nhs of B: the Attic form is klh/|w not klei/w: Cobet, Var. Lect. p. 159.

18. a(/nqrwpos. According to Ast, the Greeks sometimes used a)nh/r and a)/nqrwpos without the article of a definite person sed ita ut vel contemptionem vel reprehensionem aliquam simul indicarent. But in the cases quoted in support of this usage where the word is in an oblique case, the meaning is quite
general like the English ‘a man’, e.g. Rep. X. 596C deino/n tina le/geis kai\ qaumasto
 a)/ndra; Phaedo, 98B o(rw= a)/ndra tw=| me
 nw=| ou)de
 xrw/menon; Soph. Phil. 1228 a)pa/taisin ai)sxrai=s a)/ndra kai\ do/lois e(lw/n; Theaet. 155D e)a/n soi a)ndro/s, ma=llon de\ a)ndrw=n o)nomastw=nth=s dianoi/as th
 a)lh/qeian—sunecereunh/swmai: it is therefore safer to suppose (with Schanz and most Platonic scholars) that where a)nh/r and a)/nqrwpos of the MSS. can only be translated by ‘the man’, the rough breathing should be restored: e.g. below, 315E and Phaedr. 267A, 268C; Rep. I. 331E.
20. prostw/|w|. The au)lh/ was surrounded by cloisters. This prostw=|on is doubtless that on which the passage from the pro/quron opened.

23. *pa/ralos—*)anti/moiros. The mother of Xanthippus and Paralus had once been the wife of Hipponicus, to whom she bare Callias: Plut. Pericl. XXIV. 9. In 320Aas well as in Meno, 94B Plato remarks that Pericles was unable to teach the art of statesmanship to either of his two sons: cf. Alc. I, 118E tw\— *perikle/ous ui(e/e h)liqi/w e)gene/sqhn. They both died of the plague. One of the most interesting fragments of Protagoras describes the fortitude of Pericles when his sons died: see Appendix 11, p. 221, Frag. 3. Charmides, son of the elder Glaucon, was Plato's maternal uncle: the dialogue Charmides is named after him. He was filo/sofo/s te kai\ pa/nu poihtiko/s (Charm. 155A), and as remarkable for swfrosu/nh as for personal beauty (ibid. 157D). He was afterwards one of the Ten, and fell along with Critias at the battle of Munychia in 404 B.C. (Xen. Hell. II. 4. 19). Of Philippides and his father Philomelus and Antimoerus of Mende (on the west coast of the peninsula Pallene) nothing further is known.

28. tou/twn—e)fai/nonto. B and T omit oi(/, which was inserted by Stephanus: Heindorf prefers to insert w(=n after legome/nwn. The MSS. reading could only be defended if e)fai/nonto could be regarded as parenthetical = w(s e)fai/nonto, like dokei= moi = w(s dokei= moi (see on 314Cabove), but there seems to be no authority for such a use of fai/nomai. It is hardly to be supposed that in e)pakou/ontes and e)ph/kooi (in B below) there is an allusion to an outer circle of Protagorean students, deemed unworthy of the subtlest teaching of the master, in spite of Theaet. 152C, where Socrates is hardly serious.
30. e)c e(ka/stwn tw=n po/lewn. The plural is used as in Theaet. 157C parati/qhmi e(ka/stwn tw=n sofw=n a)pogeu/sasqai and Rep. X. 601A xrw/mat' a)/tta e(ka/stwn tw=n texnw=n.

33. xorw=|. The tragic chorus consisted of 15 xoreutai/, arranged in 3 rows (stoi=xoi) of 5 each, the leader (korufai=os) being in the middle of the first. So here Protagoras occupies the middle of a row of 7. With the metaphor cf. Theaet. 173B tou\s— tou= h(mete/rou xorou= and ibid. C le/gwmen dh\—peri\ tw=n korufai/wn; Phaedr. 246E ff.

34. hu)labou=nto. The MSS. have eu)labou=nto, but in the classic period eu)- (and ei)-) were always augmented in the past tenses, while after 300 B.C. hu)- does not appear on inscriptions. See Meisterhans, Gr. der Att. Inschr.2, p. 136.

div.head: CHAPTER VII
div.p: The scene in the house of Callias is further described.

1. to
 de\ met' ei)seno/hsa, e)/fh *(/omhros. Homer, Od. XI. 601 to
 de\ met' ei)seno/hsa bi/hn *(hraklhei/hn. The reference is not to be pressed beyond the words quoted: for there is no special likeness between Homer's Heracles (deino
 paptai/nwn, ai)ei\ bale/onti e)oikw/s 608) and Plato's Hippias, whose situation as here described is more like that of Minos in Homer, ibid. 569 ff. xru/seon skh=ptron e)/xonta qemisteu/onta ne/kussin, h(/menon: oi( de/ min a)mfi\ di/kas ei)/ponto a)/nakta h(/menoi e(stao/tes te kat' eu)purule\s *)/aidos dw=. With e)/fh *(/omhros (‘as Homer said’) cf. Meno, 76D su/nes o(/ toi le/gw, e)/fh *pi/ndaros.
3. e)n qro/nw|—e)pi\ ba/qrwn. Hippias is depicted as a schoolmaster among his pupils.

*)eruci/maxo/s te—*)/andrwn o( *)androti/wnos. Eryximachus and his father Acumenus were doctors. The former delivers one of the speeches in the Symposium, defining his art as e)pisth/mh tw=n tou= sw/matos e)rwtikw=n pro\s plhsmonh\n kai\ ke/nwsin (Symp. 186C). Phaedrus, son of Pythocles, of the deme of *murrinou=s in the tribe *pandioni/s, also appears in the Symposium, and gives his name to the dialogue Phaedrus. Andron, son of Androtion (so T here, and both B and T in Gorg. 487C—the
*)aristi/wnos of B is therefore a mistake), is in the Gorgias described as one of those who shared the view of Callicles, that too much filosofi/a ruined men. His son is believed to have been the orator Androtion.

6. peri\ fu/sews. The primary substance which early Greek philosophy sought to discover was called by them fu/sis: see Aristotle, Met. IV. 4, p. 1014b. 32 ff. tou=ton ga\r to\n tro/pon kai\ tw=n fu/sei o)/ntwn ta\ stoixei=a/ fasin ei)=nai fu/sin, oi( me\n ru=p, oi( de\ gh=n, oi( d' a)e/pa, oi( d' u(/dwp, oi( d' a)/llo ti toiou=ton le/gontes, oi( d' e)/nia tou/twn, oi( de\ pa/nta tau=ta. Thus (among others) Heraclitus, Anaxagoras, and Empedocles called their books peri\ fu/sews, i.e. on the substance which gives birth (fu/ei) to all else. By Plato's time the word had acquired a wider meaning equivalent to ‘de rerum natura’, our ‘Nature’, and it is in this sense that the word is here used.

7. a)stronomika\ a)/tta. Schanz brackets a)stronomika/, but the word is meant to be taken rather with metew/rwn than with fu/sews. On Hippias' skill in astronomy cf. Hipp. Minor, 367Eh)=s (sc. a)stronomikh=s) au)= su\ te/xnhs e)/ti ma=llon e)pisth/mwn oi)/ei ei)=nai h)\ tw=n e)/mprosqen.

10. *ta/ntalo/n ge. Od. XI. 582 kai\ mh\n *ta/ntalon ei)sei=don krate/r' a)/lge' e)/xonta. Prodicus is compared to Tantalus because of his physical wretchedness: see Crat. 395E kai\ a)texnw=s e)/oiken w(/srep a)\n ei)/ tis boulo/menos tala/ntaton o)noma/sai, a)rokpurto/menos o)noma/seie kai\ ei)/roi a)nt' e)kei/nou *ta/ntalon: toiou=to/n ti kai\ tou/tw| to\ o)/noma e)/oiken e)kpori/sai h( tu/xh th=s fh/mhs.

e)pidhmei= ga\r a)/ra. Heindorf's correction e)pidhmei= for e)pedh/mei seems to be necessary, as Prodicus is still in Athens. Just so the presential tenses are used in 314Dkinduneu/ei de\— a)/xqesqai and below, l. 14 kata/lusin pepoi/hken. If the clause is taken as a parenthetical clause of explanation, there is nothing harsh in the construction: h)=n de\ e)n oi)kh/mati/ tini naturally enough follows on ei)sei=don. For ga\r a)/ra (a somewhat rare combination) Heindorf quotes Rep. IV. 438A pa/ntes ga\r a)/ra tw=n a)gaqw=n e)piqumou=sin, Symp. 205B a)felo/ntes ga\r a)/ra (so T: B has only ga/r) tou= e)/rwto/s ti ei)=dos o)noma/zomen, Laws, III. 698D suna/yantes ga\r a)/ra ta\s xei=ras saghneu/saien pa=san th\n *)eretrikh/n. ga\r a)/ra always introduces something supposed to be known to the person addressed: see 314Boi)=mai de\ kai\ *pro/dikon to\n *kei=on.

17. *pausanias is known from the Symposium 180C ff. The deme *keramh=s was in the tribe Acamantis. w(s me
 e)gw)=|mai is to be taken closely with kalo/n te ka)gaqo
 th
 fu/sin.

20. th\n d' ou)=n i)de/an pa/nu kalo/s. Cf. Symp. 174A tau=ta dh\ e)kallwpisa/mhn i(/na kalo\s para\ kalo\n (i.e. *)aga/qwna) i)/w. There is no ground for reading kalo/n for kalo/s with Stephanus: cf. Lach. 180E ta\ ga\r meira/kia ta/de—dialeno/menoi.

21. *)aga/qwna. It is at the poet Agathon's house that the scene of the Symposium is laid. From his speech in that dialogue 194D ff. we should infer that he had studied under Prodicus to some purpose. Born about 447 B.C., Agathon was first successful on the tragic stage at an early age: cf. Symp. 175E h( de\ sh\ (sc. *)aga/qwnos sofi/a) lampra/ te kai\ pollh\n e)pi/dosin e)/xousa, h(/ ge para\ sou= ne/ou o)/ntos ou(/tw sfo/dpa e)ce/lamye kai\ e)kfanh\s e)ge/neto rpw/hn e)n ma/rtusi tw=n *(ellh/nwn ple/on h)\ trismuri/ois. He visited the court of Archelaus about 407 B.C. and died probably about 400. That he was held in esteem by the Athenians appears from Ar. Frogs, 83 ff. *)aga/qwn de\ pou= 'sq'; o(/pou 'st'; a)polipw/n m' oi)/xetai a)gaqo\s poihth\s kai\ poqeino\s toi=s fi/lois. For paidika\ *pausani/ou cf. Symp. 193B.

22. tou=t' h)=n to\ meira/kion. So BT: the idiom is like our ‘There was this young man’. The nearest parallels seem to be Phaedo, 59B h)=n de\ kai\ *kth/sippos o( *paianieu/s and Rep. X. 615D h)=san de\ kai\ i)diw=tai/ tines. tou=to/ te dh/ (Ast), tou=to/ t' ou)=n (Heindorf), tou=t' e)/ndon h)=n (Schirlitz), have been suggested, while Kroschel rejects the words, but the text is probably sound.

23. tw\ *)adeima/ntw. Adimantus son of Cepis is not elsewhere named. The son of Leucolophidas was afterwards strathgo/s under Alcibiades, whose policy he supported (Xen. Hell. I. 4. 21): he was taken prisoner at the battle of Aegospotami, but spared by the Spartans. He was afterwards put on his trial by Conon on the charge, not improbably a true one, of having betrayed the Athenian fleet at this battle: see Kock on Ar. Frogs, 1512.

26. pa/ssofos—a(nh/r—kai\ qei=os. For a(nh/r BT read a)nh/r, but see on 314Eabove. pa/ssofos is often ironical: e.g. Euthyd. 271C o(\ de\ su\ e)rwta=|s th\n sofi/an au)toi=n, qaumasi/a, w)= *kri/twn: pa/ssofoi a)texnw=s tw/ ge, ou)d' h)/|dh pro\ tou= o(/ ti ei)=en oi( pagkratiastai/. For the meaning of qei=os cf. Meno, 99C ou)kou=n—a)/cion
tou/tous qei/ous kalei=n tou\s a)/ndras, oi(/tines nou=n mh\ e)/xontes polla\ kai\ mega/la katorqou=sin w(=n pra/ttousin kai\ le/gousi; qei=os (in the form sei=os) was the favourite Spartan word of praise and was much affected by the Socratic circle in Athens.

div.head: CHAPTER VIII
div.p: After Hippocrates has been introduced to Protagoras, the latter enlarges upon the antiquity of his profession. At the suggestion of Socrates a circle is formed to hear the Sophists discourse.

3. *kriti/as the foremost of the Thirty so-called tyrants was related to Plato on the mother's side, Perictione Plato's mother being granddaughter of the elder Critias, who was father of Callaeschrus. He is one of the dramatis personae in the Charmides and Timaeus, and the dialogue Critias is named after him. A scholiast on the Timaeus, 20A (quoted by Stallbaum) describes him as gennai/as kai\ a(dra=s fu/sews, h(/pteto de\ kai\ filoso/fwn sunousiw=n, kai\ e)kalei=to i)diw/ths me\n e)n filoso/fois, filo/sofos de\ e)n i)diw/tais. For the fragments of his poems see Bergk's Poetae Lyrici Graeci4, II, 279 ff.

4. e)/ti smi/kr' a)/tta—diaqeasa/menoi. smi/kr' a)/tta is the plural of smikro/n ti, and as e)/ti smikro/n ti diatri/yantes would mean ‘after a little further delay’, so e)/ti smi/kr' a)/tta diatri/yantes means ‘after some little further delays’. The reference in e)/ti is to 314C tau=ta in kai\ tau=ta refers to the causes of the delays, which were, as usual, some topics of discourse: its antecedent is involved in diatri/yantes.

6. pro\s se/ toi h)/lqomen. Here, as in 314E both B and T have ti for toi: but ti is impossible here, and this use of toi is very frequent in address: Heindorf refers (inter alia) to Ar. Plut. 1100 se/ toi se/ toi le/gw, *kari/wn, a)na/meinon.

15. oi)/etai/ oi( ma/list' a)
 gene/sqai. B and T read ma/lista without a)/n: see on Crito, 51E. It is more likely that a)/n should have dropped out after ma/lista here than that Plato's usage should have varied with oi)/omai and the aorist infinitive referring
to the future: cf. below, 353Bh(=| oi)=mai a)
 e)/gwge ka/llista fanero
 gene/sqai, where a)/n is in all the MSS.

17. mo/nos oi)/ei dei=n—pro\s mo/nous. oi)/ei dei=n is virtually like one verb, a)cioi=s or the like: it therefore takes the nom. (not the acc.) with inf.; cf. Demosth. Fals. Leg. 235 eu)qu\s h(gou/mhn e)n tou/tois—au)to\s periei=nai dei=n au)tw=n kai\ megaloyuxo/teros fai/nesqai, quoted by Stallbaum on Crito, 50E. Note that Protagoras here uses the more precise mo/nos pro\s mo/nous, but above only mo/nw| (316 B)—unless (with Cobet and Schanz) we there insert mo/noi before mo/nw|.

19. ce/non ga a)/ndra kai\ i)o/nta ktl. For kai\ i)o/nta T reads in the margin katio/nta: Liebhold suggests katalu/onta. i)o/nta, however, is parallel to ce/non and to pei/qonta, ‘a man who is a stranger and goes—and tries to persuade etc.’ The whole passage recalls Apol. 19E-20A tou/twn (viz. Gorgias, Prodicus, Hippias) ga e(/kastos—oi(=o/s t' e)sti
 i)w
 ei)s e(ka/sthn tw=n po/lewn tou\s ne/ous oi(=s e)/cesti tw=n e(autw=n rolitw=n rpoi=ka cunei=nai w(=| a)
 bou/lwntai—tou/tous rei/qousi ta\s e)kei/nwn cunousi/as a)roliro/ntas sfi/sin cunei=nai xrh/mata dido/ntas kai\ xa/rin proseide/nai. Notice throughout the longwinded character of Protagoras' speeches: cf. Philostrat. Vit. Soph. I. 494 (quoted by Kroschel on 320C, gnou\s de\ to
 *prwtago/ran o( *pla/twn semnw=s me
 e(rmhneu/onta, u(ptia/zonta de\ th=| semno/thti kai/ pou kai\ makrologw/teron tou= summe/trou, th
 i)de/an au)tou= mu/qw| makrw=| e)xarakth/risen.

29. to\ e)paxqe\s au)th=s. e)paxqe/s like fortiko/n means what hearers will resent (think a burden or a)/xqos) as in bad taste because presumptuous: cf. Demosth. de Pace, 4 to\ le/gein peri\ w(=n au)to\s ei)=re/ tis kai\ repi\ au(tou=—ou(/tws h(gou=mai foptiko\n kai\ e)paxqe\s w(/ste ktl.

30. tou\s me\n poi/hsin. sofo/s and its derivatives are often used especially in early writers in connection with poetry, e.g Theognis, 19-20 *ku/rne sofizome/nw| me\n e)moi\ sfrhgi\s e)pikei/sqw toi=sd' e)/pesin, Pindar, Isthm. 4. 29-30 mele/tan de\ sofistai=s *dio\s e(/kati pro/sbalon sebizo/menoi.

32. tou\s a)mfi/ te *)orfe/a kai\ *mousai=on = ‘Orpheus and Musaeus and their schools’. The Editors quote Ar. Frogs, 1032 ff. *)orfeu\s me
 ga teleta/s q' h(mi=n kate/deice fo/nwn t' a)re/xesqai, *mousai=os d' e)cake/seis te no/swn kai\ xphsmou/s, *(hsi/odos de\ gh=s e)rgasi/as, karpw=n w(/ras, a)ro/tous: o( de\ qei=os *(/omhros a)po\ tou=
timh
 kai\ kle/os e)/sxen plh
 tou=d' o(/ti xrh/st' e)di/dace, ta/ceis, a)reta/s, o(pli/seis a)ndrw=n; For the misplacement of te cf. Crito, 43B e
 tosau/th| te a)grupni/a| kai\ lu/ph| ei)=nai.

34. *)/ikkos—*(hro/dikos. Iccus is mentioned in Laws, VIII. 839E ff. as a model of temperance. According to Pausanias, he won in the pentathlon at the Olympic Games and afterwards set up as a trainer (gumnasth/s). Herodicus of Selymbria in Thrace combined the professions of the gumnasth/s and i)atro/s (mi/cas gumnastikh\n i)atrikh=|). He is described in Rep. III. 406A as the inventor of the paidagwgikh\ tw=n noshma/twn i)atrikh/—by means of which he tortured first himself (by prolonging his own dying) and afterwards others: dusqanatw=n—u(po\ sofi/as ei)s gh=ras a)fi/keto (ibid. B).
o( nu=n e)/ti w)/n—sofisth/s. Heindorf reads h(=tton in place of h(/ttwn, but nu=n e)/ti w)/n is ‘still living’ and ou)deno\s h(/ttwn sofisth/s is a descriptive qualification.

37. *)agaqoklh=s—*puqoklei/dhs. Agathocles is mentioned in Lach. 180D as teacher of Damon: according to the Alc. I, 118C Pythoclides also taught Pericles. A scholiast on the Alc. I (loc. cit.) remarks: *puqoklei/dhs mousiko\s h)=n th=s semnh=s mousikh=s dida/skalos, kai\ *puqago/reios, ou(= maqhth\s *)agaqoklh=s, ou(= *lamproklh=s (*la/mpros, van Prinsterer), ou(= *da/mwn. With the sentiment compare the imitation in Plut. Pericl. 4. 2 o( de\ *da/mwn e)/oiken a)/kpos w)
 sofisth\s katadu/esqai me
 ei)s to\ th=s mousikh=s o)/noma rpo\s tou\s pollou\s e)pikrupto/menos th
 deino/thta.
40. tai=s te/xnais tau/tais parapeta/smasin e)xrh/santo. Cf. Plut. Pericl. loc. cit. ou) mh\n e)/laqen o( *da/mwn th=| lu/ra| parakalu/mmati xrw/menos.

41. kata\ tou=to ei)=nai. ei)=nai is redundant as in Isaeus, peri\ tou= *menekle/ous klh/rou, 32 h(mei=s w)mo/samen eu)= poiei=n a)llh/lous— kata\ du/namin ei)=nai, kai\ lo/gw| kai\ e)/rgw|, and in the common e(kw\n ei)=nai: but no other instance of the precise phrase kata\ tou=to ei)=nai is quoted.

45. oi(/ ge polloi\—ou)de\n ai)sqa/nontai. Cf. Gorg. 474A tou\s de\ pollou\s e)w= xai/rein, kai\ e(/na e)piyhfi/zein e)pi/stamai, toi=s de\ polloi=s ou)de\ diale/gomai. For w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n (to be taken with ou)de\n) see on Apol. 17A. The phrase is used to qualify the comprehension of a word or phrase, generally ou)dei/s or pa/ntes.

47. to\ ou)=n—e)pixeirh/matos. B and T read to
 for to/, by a natural error. Heindorf compares Theaet. 144A to\ ga eu)maqh= o)/nta—rpa=|on au)= ei)=nai diafepo/ntws—e)gw\ me
 ou)/t' a)
 w)|o/mhn gene/sqai ktl. and Rep. I. 331B to\ ga mhde\ a)/konta/ tina e)capath=sai—me/ga me/ros ei)s tou=to h( tw=n xrhma/twn kth=sis sumba/lletai. Here kai\ tou= e)pixeirh/matos is a virtual repetition of a)podidra/skonta: cf. to
 tau=ta pra/ttonta above in 316C The sentence reminds one of the practice observed in Spartan education—to punish the youths not for stealing but for failing to escape with their booty: Xen. Rep. Laced. 2. 8 ei)/poi d' a)
 ou)=n tis: ti/ dh=ta, ei)/rep to\ kle/rtein a)gaqo
 e)no/mize, rolla\s rlhga\s e)re/bale tw=| a(liskome/nw|; o(/ti, fhmi\ e)gw/, kai\ ta)/lla, o(/sa a)/nqpwroi dida/skousi, kola/zousi to
 mh\ kalw=s u(phretou=nta: cf. Rep. I. 361A to
 a(lisko/menon de\ fau=lon h(ghte/on.

52. tou/twn th
 e)nanti/an a(/pasan o(do/n. ‘h. e. th
 o(do
 h(\ a(/pasa/ e)stin e)nanti/a tou/twn. pro tou/twn eadem comparatione quae vocatur compendiaria dici potuit tou/tois. Andocid. or. I. 4 e)gw\ polu\ th
 e)nanti/an tou/tois gnw/mhn e)/xw’ (Kroschel). For a(/pasan with an adjective compare (with Kroschel) Xen. Anab. I. 5. I h(=n h( gh= pedi/on a(/pan o(male\s w(/sper qa/latta and the common phrase pa=n tou)nanti/on.

54. sofisth\s ei)=nai kai\ paideu/ein a)nqrw/pous. The sofisth\s sofi/zei, i.e. paideu/ei: see note on 312Cabove. Theaet. 167C (where Socrates is speaking for Protagoras) o( sofisth\s tou\s raideuome/nous ou(/tw duna/menos raidagwgei=n sofo/s te kai\ a)/cios pollw=n xrhma/twn toi=s paideuqei=sin.

57. su
 qew=| ei)pei=n. ‘Crebra modestiae formula, bene explicat Steph., quod ita dico, ut in eo opem divinam agnoscam’. Heindorf on Theaet. 151B kai\ su
 qew=| ei)pei=n, pa/nu i(kanw=s topa/zw oi)=s a)
 suggeno/menoi o)/nainto.

59. polla/ ge e)/th h)/dh ei)mi\ e)n th=| te/xnh|. Meno, 91E oi)=mai ga\r au)to\n (i.e. *prwtago/ran) a)poqanei=n e)ggu\s kai\ e(bdomh/konta e)/th gegono/ta, tettara/konta de\ e)n th=| te/xnh| o)/nta. The phrases ei)=nai e)n th=| te/xnh|, e)n filosofi/a| and the like are common.

60. ou)deno\s o(/tou ou). For the asyndeton Heindorf compares Hom. Od. XIV. 96 h(= ga/r oi( zwh/ g' h)=n a)/spetos: ou)/ tini to/ssh a)ndrw=n h(rw/wn. The nearest parallel to pa/ntwn (which Cobet
rejects) after ou)deno\s o(/tou ou) seems to be in Dem. adv. Lept. § 3 ou) ga\r e)/stin e)f' o(/tou tou=to ou) pepo/nqate tw=n pa/ntwn (quoted by Heindorf).

62. a(pa/ntwn goes with tw=n e)/ndon o)/ntwn. It seems better to take peri\ tou/twn with bou/lesqe than with to\n lo/gon poiei=sqai: otherwise it is hardly possible to separate tou/twn from a(pa/ntwn.

65. e)ndei/casqai kai\ kallwpi/sasqai—o(/ti e)rastai/. o(/ti depends rather on e)ndei/casqai than on kallwpi/sasqai: cf. below, 327Ae)di/daske kai\ e)pe/plhtte to\n mh\ kalw=s au)lou=nta, and ibid. B tw=n dikai/wn kai\ tw=n nomi/mwn ou)dei\s fqonei= ou)d' a)pokru/ptetai w(/sper tw=n a(/llwn texnhma/twn, Phaedo, 94D ta\ me\n a)peilou=sa, ta\ de\ nouqetou=sa tai=s e)piqumi/ais. See also notes on 327Aand 335Ebelow.
66. ei)=men. BT read ei)/hmen, but in Plato's time the short form of the optative plural is regular: see on Apol. 22E.
ti/ ou)=n—ou)—e)kale/samen. See above on 310A and for e)pakou/swsin note on 315A
70. kaqezo/menoi. So T: B has kaqizo/menoi, but presently in 317Eboth MSS. read sunekaqezo/meqa.

72. kai\ au)toi\ a)ntilabo/menoi. This passage is difficult and different views are possible as to the construction and meaning. The MSS. read kai\ au)toi/ te. If the MSS. reading is retained, te must be regarded as answering to de/ in e)n de\ tou/tw| (cf. Euthyphr. 3E), and kai\ au)toi/ = etiam ipsi, i.e. even without waiting for servants—a harsh explanation both for kai/ and au)toi/. If te is left out (with most of the editors, following Heindorf), kai\ au)toi/ means ‘ourselves also’ as opposed to Callias and Alcibiades in e)n de\ tou/tw| *kalli/as te kai\ *)alkibia/dhs. There is still a slight difficulty in contrasting au)toi/ with these two, because they also would seem to be included in au)toi/ (pa/ntes h(mei=s—kai\ au)toi/), but such slight inaccuracies of expression are common in actual dialogue, which Plato's style is intended to imitate.
75. *kalli/as. Hermann read *kriti/as in order to escape the slight difficulty remarked on in the preceding note: ‘sed hospitis erat Prodicum ut accederet invitare’ (Kroschel).

76. a)nasth/santes: but a)/gonte just before. Euthyd. 273B offers an exact parallel (if we follow the reading of the Bodleian
MS.): i)do/ntes de\ au)to\n o(/ te *dionuso/dwros kai\ o( *eu)qu/dhmos prw=ton me\n e)rista/nte dielege/sqhn a)llh/loin, a)/llhn kai\ a)/llhn a)roble/rontes ei)s h(ma=s: cf. ibid. 273A ei)selqo/ntes—periepatei/thn and D e)gelasa/thn gou=n a)/mfw ble/yantes ei)s a)llh/lous. The dual in Plato as in Greek generally is apt to sink into the plural.

div.head: CHAPTER IX
div.p: Protagoras explains his profession. It is to teach civil virtue and make men good citizens.
6. ga/r used like Latin enim to introduce a speech (introductory ga/r): see on Apol. 20E.

7. o(/ ti—a)pobh/setai—puqe/sqai. For the situation cf. Gorg. 455C-D, where Socrates says i)/sws ga\r kai\ tugxa/nei tis tw=n e)/ndon o)/ntwn maqhth/s sou boulo/menos gene/sqai, w(s e)gw/ tinas sxedo\n kai\ suxnou\s ai)sqa/nomai, oi(\ i)/sws ai)sxu/noint' a)/n se a)nepe/sqai: u(r' e)mou= ou)=n a)nepwtw/menos no/mison kai\ u(r' e)kei/nwn a)nepwta=sqai: ti/ h(mi=n, w)= *gopgi/a, e)/stai, e)a/n soi sunw=men; repi\ ti/nwn th=| ro/lei sumbouleu/ein oi)=oi/ te e)so/meqa;

12. e)n th=| u(sterai/a| tau)ta\ tau=ta: sc. e)/stai soi. e)n (bracketed by Schanz after Hirschig) before th=| u(sterai/a| means ‘during’: cf. (with Kroschel) Thuc. I. 44. 1 th=| me\n prote/ra| ou)x h(=sson—a)pede/canto tou\s lo/gous, e)n de\ th=| u(sterai/a| mete/gnwsan ktl. and add below 321Ch( ei(marme/nh h(me/ra parh=n, e)n h(=| e)/dei kai\ a)/nqrwpon e)cie/nai e)k gh=s.

17. o(\ mh\ tugxa/neis e)pista/menos. tugxa/nois (suggested by Bekker) would be the usual periodic structure: but the indicative is looser and more direct: Kroschel compares Gorg. 464D ei) de/oi—diagwni/zesqai—po/teros e)pai/ei. Notice the usual Socratic implication that virtue is knowledge.

18. a)lla\ mh\ ou(/tws. Cf. Meno, 74D a)lla\ mh/ moi ou(/tws and below 331C So mh\ ga/r, mh\ su/ ge, mh/ toi/ ge and the like are often used without a verb expressed. w(/sper a)/n belongs to ei)/poi a)/n in ll. 26 and 30: it is answered by ou(/tw dh/ in l. 31. au)ti/ka here does not mean ‘for example’ but goes with ma/la (which intensifies it): ‘as if Hippocrates were to change his desire on the spot and conceive a desire (e)piqumh/seien) for etc.’ au)ti/ka ma/la is idiomatic,
cf. Gorg. 469D au)ti/ka ma/la dei=n teqna/nai, Crat. 384B au)ti/ka ma/la ei)de/nai.

20. nu=n newsti/: nunc nuper as in Meno, 90A. The more general word is followed by the more specific exactly as in Theaet. 161C batra/xou guri/nou, where guri=nos according to a scholiast is to\ e)k tou= batra/xou paidi/on.

21. *zeuci/ppou. An obscure sculptor (not painter) of this name is mentioned in Corp Inscr. Gr. No. 1229 (quoted by Overbeck, Die Antiken Schriftquellen zur Geschichte der bildenden Künste bei den Griechen, p. 300). The Zeuxippus here mentioned is supposed to be the same as the famous painter Zeuxis of Heraclea (the Greek colony in Italy, most probably) who is mentioned by Plato in Gorg. 453C, and several times by Xenophon (Mem. I. 4. 3, Oecon. 10. 1, Symp. 4. 63 to\n *(hraklew/thn ce/non): see Overbeck, pp. 311 ff. Zeuxis began to rise into fame probably about 424 B.C.: he would therefore be still a young man about the date when this dialogue is supposed to take place: see Introduction, p. xxxiii. Brunn would read *zeu/cidos for *zeuci/ppou here, but according to Fick (quoted by Sauppe) *zeu=cis is nothing but a familiar diminutive of *zeu/cippos: for other similar examples see Fick, Die Griechischen Personennamen, pp. xxviii ff. -ippos in proper names was aristocratic (Ar. Clouds, 62 ff.) and could upon occasion be omitted or added without prejudice to personal identity: cf. Clouds, 929 ou)xi\ dida/ceis tou=ton *kro/nos w)/n with ibid. 1071 su\ d' ei)= kro/nippos, where -ippos adds mock dignity to kro/nos.
27. *)orqago/ra| tw=| *qhbai/w|. Orthagoras is said by Athenaeus (IV. 184E) on the authority of Aristoxenus to have taught Epaminondas how to play the flute.

29. au)to/n but e)kei/nou in 28 and e)kei/nw? in 30: see on 310D ei)s o(/ ti belti/wn is here used rather than o(/ ti or ti/ belti/wn (as in l. 25) to prepare for ei)s au)/lhsin, where the preposition could hardly be dispensed with.
31. ou(/tw dh/. Heindorf would write ou(/tw de/, which is frequent after w(/sper, e.g. 328A see his note on Phaedo, 72C.
32. *prwtago/ra| suggeno/menos: ‘gravius hoc quam soi\ suggeno/menos’ (Kroschel). See also note on 335A

41. lwbw=ntai is here rather kakw=s poiei=n than kako
 poiei=n, although (like kakourgei=n, lumai/nomai and the like) it unites both meanings: cf. Rep. I. 335 B ff., and see on Euthyphr. 3A kakourgei=n th
 po/lin. With the words of Protagoras compare those of Anytus in Meno, 91C *(hra/kleis, eu)fh/mei, w)= *sw/krates, mhde/na tw=n suggenw=n, mh/te oi)kei/wn mh/te fi/lwn, mh/te a)sto
 mh/te ce/non, toiau/th mani/a la/boi, w(/ste rapa\ tou/tous e)lqo/nta lwbhqh=nai, e)rei\ ou(=toi/ ge fanera/ e)sti lw/bh te kai\ diefqora\ tw=n suggignome/nwn.

ta\s ga\r te/xnas—e)mba/llousin ei)s te/xnas. te/xnai is used of Arithmetic, Geometry, Solid Geometry and Harmonics in Rep. VII. 532C: elsewhere in Plato ai( te/xnai generally means the mechanical arts, e.g. Rep. VI. 495D and VII. 522B. Here te/xnai can only mean the subjects taught in schools (grammatikh/, logistikh/, kiqaristikh/), as Sauppe remarks, but there seems to be no precise parallel to such a use of the word.
44. ei)s to\n *(ippi/an a)pe/bleyen: see on 314B

47. eu)bouli/a peri\ tw=n oi)kei/wn. The editors quote Meno, 91A ou(=tos ga\r—pa/lai le/gei pro/s me o(/ti e)piqumei= tau/ths th=s sofi/as kai\ a)peth=s h(=| oi( a)/nqpwroi ta/s te oi)ki/as kai\ ta\s ro/leis kalw=s dioikou=si, kai\ tou\s gone/as tou\s au(tw=n qepareu/ousi, kai\ roli/tas kai\ ce/nous u(pode/casqai/ te kai\ a)pope/myai e)pi/stantai a)ci/ws a)ndro\s a)gaqou=; Euthyd. 273D a)reth\n—w)= *sw/krates, oi)o/meqa oi(/w t' ei/)nai paradou=nai ka/llist' a)nqrw/pwn kai\ ta/xista.
52. a)/ndras a)gaqou\s poli/tas forms a single expression: ‘good citizens’ are the e)/rgon of politikh\ te/xnh. So Ar. Knights, 1304 a(/ndra moxqhro\n poli/thn.
53. e)pa/ggelma o(\ e)pagge/llomai. e)pagge/llomai and its derivatives are often used of sophistic ‘professions’.

div.head: CHAPTER X
div.p: Socrates professes to disbelieve that a)reth/ can be communicated by teaching. His arguments are twofold: (1) while in matters connected with the arts of building, ship-carpentry, and the like, the Athenians will listen only to the professional man, in politics they give ear to any and every one: (2) Athenian statesmen have not been able to communicate their political virtue to their sons.

2. ei)/per ke/kthsai. Cobet's rule (Mnemos. XI, 168) ‘ubi praecedit vocalis, semper (Plato) ke/kthmai ponit, ubi consonans, promiscue kekth=sqai et e)kth=sqai’ represents the usage of the best MSS., but Schanz now writes e)kth=sqai universally after consonants. See also Mnem. VIII, 336. e)kth=sqai is in reality an old Ionic form: it is used by Aeschylus, Prom. 795 koino\n o)/mm' e)kthme/nai.

4. ou)k e)/xw o(/pws a)pistw=. The MSS. reading o(/pws a)/n a)pistw= was corrected by Heindorf, o(/pws a)/n with the subjunctive being only used in final clauses. The subjunctive is deliberative: cf. Euthyphr. 11B ou)k e)/xw e)/gwge o(/pws soi ei)/pw o(\ now=.

5. ou) didakto\n—mhde\, ou) negatives didakto/n only, mhde/ the whole of its clause: a similar case is Eur. Andr. 586 dra=n eu)=, kakw=s d' ou)/, mhd' a)poktei/nein bi/a|. mh/ after verbs of thinking and saying is tolerably common in Plato. See on Euthyphr. 6B o(mologou=men peri\ au)tw=n mhde\n ei)de/nai.

7. w(/sper kai\ oi( a)/lloi *(/ellhnes, sc. fasi/. Cf. 337D where Hippias calls Athens th=s *(ella/dos au)to\ to\ prutanei=on th=s sofi/as: a somewhat less favourable judgement is given in Laws, I. 641E th
 po/lin a(/pantes h(mw=n *(/ellhnes u(polamba/nousin w(s filo/logo/s te/ e)sti kai\ rolu/logos, *lakedai/mona de\ kai\ *kph/thn, th
 me
 bpaxu/logon, th
 de\ polu/noian ma=llon h)\ polulogi/an a)skou=san.

10. metapempome/nous is probably middle: Plato does not seem to use metape/mpeiv in the sense of ‘send for’ (like Thucydides, e.g. I. 112. 3 *)amurtai/ou metape/mpontos tou= e)n toi=s e(/lesi basile/ws: VI. 52. 1 et al.). The subject is tou\s poli/tas to be supplied from th\n po/lin. Cf. Gorg. 455B ff. o(/tan peri\ i)atrw=n ai(pe/sews h)=| th=| ro/lei su/llogos h)\ repi\ naurhgw=n h)\ repi\ a)/llou tino\s dhmioupgikou= e)/qnous, a)/llo ti h)\ to/te o( p(htopiko\s ou) sumbouleu/sei; dh=lon ga\r o(/ti e)n e(ka/sth| ai(re/sei to\n texnikw/taton dei= ai(rei=sqai and Alc. I, 107A-C. Kroschel well remarks that the words peri\ tw=n oi)kodomhma/twn (which Hirschig wrongly rejects) are added to show that it is only about the actual buildings that the builders are consulted, ‘non de necessitate, utilitate, magnitudine’, as to which the orators advise: cf. Gorg. 455D.

15. ka)
 pa/nu kalo\s h)=| ktl. Imitated in Alc. I, 107B and C: e)a/n te/ ge smikro\s h)\ me/gas h)=|, e)a/n te kalo\s h)\ ai)sxro/s, e)/ti te gennai=os
h)\ a)gennh/s, pw=s ga ou)/;—a)ll' a)/n te pe/nhs a)/n te plou/sios h)=| o( parainw=n, ou)de
 dioi/sei *)aqhnai/ois, o(/tan repi\ tw=n e)n th=| ro/lei bouleu/wntai, rw=s a)
 u(giai/noien, a)lla\ zhtou=sin i)atro
 ei)=nai to
 su/mboulon.

19. oi( toco/tai. The toco/tai (bowmen) or *sku/qai (so called from their nationality) or *peusi/nioi (from one *peusi/s who according to the schol. on Ar. Ach. 54 had the chief hand in establishing them) were the police. e(/lkw was regularly used of removing an offending orator: e.g. Ar. Knights, 665 ka)=|q' ei(=lkon au)to\n oi( pruta/neis xoi) toco/tai.

19. e)cai/rwntai. So T (B has e)ce/rwntai): the present is perhaps due to tense-assimilation to keleuo/ntwn. The active ai)/rein is used in the same connection by Ar. Eccl. 261 h(mei=s de/ g' h)\n ai)/rws' (sc. oi( toco/tai), e)a=n keleu/somen, but no exact parallel for the use of the middle has yet been found—the nearest seems to be Eur. I. T. 1201 ou) ga/r pot' a)/n nin h)ra/mhn ba/qrwn a)/po: cf. Ar. Ach. 1140 th\n a)spi/d' ai)/rou kai\ ba/diz' w)= pai= labw/n; ibid. 953.

21. peri\ tw=n th=s po/lews dioikh/sews. So B and T, but in both the copyist had doubts as to the text. It is usual to drop either tw=n or dioikh/sews: Kroschel transposes tw=n and peri/. Sauppe retains the MSS. reading, making peri\ govern dioikh/sews—but this is very harsh. ta\ th=s po/lews dioikh/sews is a periphrasis for h( po/lews dioi/khsis (for the omission of the article with po/lews cf. Polit. 296E tou=ton dei= kai\ peri\ tau=ta to
 o)/ron ei)=nai to/n ge a)lhqinw/taton o)pqh=s ro/lews dioikh/sews, o(
 o( sofo\s kai\ a)gaqo\s a)nh dioikh/sei to\ tw=n a)rxome/nwn), ‘the city's administration’ being contrasted with tw=n e)n te/xnh| dioi/khsis. The whole phrase peri\ tw=n th=s po/lews dioikh/sews corresponds to 318Ekai\ repi\ tw=n th=s ro/lews, o(/rws ta\ th=s ro/lews dunatw/tatos a)
 ei)/h kai\ pra/ttein kai\ le/gein.
23. a)nista/menos. The audience sat in the assembly: cf. Rep. VI. 492B o(/tan, ei)=pon, cugkaqezo/menoi a(qro/oi polloi\ ei)s e)kklhsi/as— ye/gwsi ktl.

27. maqw/n. Heindorf quotes many cases of the transition from plural to singular in Plato (e.g. below, 324B: the change is justified here because in each case the reproach would be addressed to a single person.
29. mh\ toi/nun o(/ti—a)lla\ i)di/a|. See on Apol. 40D oi)=mai a)\n mh\ o(/ti i)diw/thn tina/, a)lla\ to\n me/gan basile/a ktl.

31. ou)x oioi/ te a)/llois paradido/nai. Plato comments on the inability of statesmen to teach their sons political sagacity in Meno, 93B ff., citing Themistocles, Aristides, Pericles and Thucydides as cases in point. Cf. Alc. I, 118E ff.
33. a(\ me\n didaska/lwn ei)/xeto. The phrase is used by Plato in the other passages where he deals with this topic: cf, below, 324D Meno, 93D and 94A.

36. ne/montai w(/sper a)/fetoi. ne/mesqai is properly ‘to graze’, and a)/fetos is said de grege numini alicui consecrato (Heindorf): cf. Critias, 119D a)fe/twn o)/ntwn tau/rwn e)n tw=| tou= *poseidw=nos i(erw=|. The same expression occurs in Rep. VI. 498C o(/tan de\ lh/gh? me
 h( p(w/mh, rolitikw=n de\ kai\ stpateiw=n e)kto\s gi/gnhtai, to/te h)/dh a)fe/tous ne/mesqai kai\ mhde
 a)/llo pra/ttein. Here the object of ne/mesqai is virtually the clause e)a/n pou—th=| a)reth=| ‘going to and fro by themselves they graze like creatures set apart upon whatever excellence etc.’: cf. (for the use of e)a/n) Rep. VII. 528A fqonoi=s mh
 ou)d' a)
 a)/llw| ei)/ ti/s ti du/naito a)p' au)tw=n o)/nasqai.

e)a/n pou au)to/matoi peritu/xwsin th=| a)reth=|. au)toma/tw? (used as in Theaet. 180C, Polit. 271D o(\ d' h)/rou peri\ tou= pa/nta au)to/mata gi/gnesqai toi=s a)nqrw/pois) agreeing with a)reth=| would make the expression more pointed, and avoid the slight contradiction involved in the expression au)to/matoi peritu/xwsin (since one cannot spontaneously fall in with a thing), but au)to/matoi is not to be pressed, and should be understood as equivalent to a)po\ tou= au)toma/tou (cf. 323C.
37. *kleini/an. The author of the First Alcibiades makes Alcibiades himself speak of his younger brother as maino/menos a)/nqrwpos (118E).
39. mh\ diafqarh=| dh/. dh/ adds a touch of irony to spare the feelings of Alcibiades.
41. kataqe/menos e)n *)ari/fronos. According to Plutarch (Alcib. ch. 1) Ariphron shared with Pericles the guardianship of Alcibiades. Ariphron was Pericles' brother.

42. a)pe/dwke tou/tw|, i.e. Pericles to Alcibiades. Pericles is humorously represented as restoring his ward in despair to the
very man who was suspected of corrupting him: and Alcibiades is again appeased.
45. ou)/te tw=n a)llotri/wn. See Gorg. 515C ff., where it is argued that Pericles, Cimon and Miltiades made none of their fellow-citizens better.
48. ka/mptomai. Stallbaum quotes Thuc. III. 58. I kai/toi a)ciou=me/n ge—kamfqh=nai u(ma=s kai\ metagnw=nai.

49. pollw=n me\n—ta\ de\ au)to\n e)churhke/nai. It is implied that Protagoras' originality is not equal to his industry. The MSS. have e)ceurhke/nai, but in the perfect as in past tenses generally initial eu became hu: see on 315Babove.
52. a)ll' e)pi/deicon. See below on e)pideica/menos in 328D
53. w(s presbu/teros newte/rois. Gorg. 527A ta/xa d' ou)=n tau=ta mu=qo/s soi dokei= le/gesqai w(/sper grao/s.

54. h)\ lo/gw| diecelqw/n. So BT: Cobet requires h)\ lo/gw| diece/lqw, but lo/gw| diecelqw/n contrasts with mu=qon le/gwn, not with e)pidei/cw, which belongs to both participial clauses. For the aorist participle (where we should expect the present) cf., with Sauppe, Theaet. 167D a)mfisbh/tei lo/gw| a)ntidiecelqw/n.

div.head: CHAPTER XI
div.p: Protagoras' reply falls into three sections, viz. (1) 320C323C (2) 323C324D (3) 324E328D cf. Introduction, pp. x-xi. In the first he is concerned to justify the Athenians for allowing everyone to address them on political questions: this he does in the first instance by relating a myth of prehistoric man.

It is probable that this myth comes from Protagoras' treatise peri\ th=s e)n a)rxh=| katasta/sews, mentioned in Diog. Laert. IX. 55. It does not resemble the other myths of Plato in point of style, and if not actually written by Protagoras, it is at least carefully modelled on his way of writing: cf. the similar imitations of the style of Agathon in Symp. 194D ff. and of Prodicus below, 337 A ff. See Introduction, p. xix. That the ‘Sophists’ taught by means of parables we can see from Prodicus' Apologue of Heracles in Xen. Mem. II. 1. 21 ff. The other passages in Plato treating of the primitive constitution of man are Polit. 269C ff., Tim. 42E ff. and Symp. 189C ff. In Rep. III. 414C ff. there are also some points of resemblance to the present story.

1. h)=n ga/r pote xro/nos. ga/r introduces the story: see on Apol. 20E *xairefw=nta ga\r i)/ste pou. h)=n xro/nos was usual in beginning a tale: the editors quote Theocr. 8. 1 h)=n xro/nos a(ni/k' e)gw/n ktl.

qnhta\ de\ ge/nh ou)k h)=n. In the Timaeus, 42E ff., the creation of men takes place after that of gods.
