The lower animals in the Timaeus arise from the degeneration of the souls of men in later births, every soul being first born as man: cf. Tim. 41E with 90E ff. Here the lower animals are created simultaneously with man, for qnhta\ ge/nh is of course not limited to the human race.
2. *xro/nos h)=lqen ei(marme/nos gene/sews. The omission of the article, as well as the whole turn of expression (h)=lqen au)toi=s xro/nos), is somewhat poetic.

3. qeoi\ gh=s e)/ndon: so in Tim. 42E it is the created gods, not the dhmiourgo/s, who make men. There, however, it is not said that human creatures were made within the earth: but compare the gennai=on yeu=dos of Rep. III. 414C h)=san de\ (i.e. the citizens of Plato's state) to/te th=| a)lhqei/a| u(po\ gh=s e)nto\s platto/menoi. The widespread tradition of autochthonous races among the Greeks no doubt helped to produce such anthropological theories, with which compare Empedocles (ap. Ritter and Preller, Hist. Philos.7 p. 143), ou)lofuei=s me\n prw=ta tu/poi xqono\s e)cane/tellon; Symp. 191C e)ge/nnwn kai\ e)/tikton (sc. primitive men) ou)k ei)s a)llh/lous a)ll' ei)s gh=n w(/sper oi( te/ttiges; and Polit. 272A e)k gh=s ga\r a)nebiw/skonto pa/ntes. It is to be noticed that Plato regularly uses e)nto/s (not e)/ndon) as a preposition: e)/ndon (so used) is the more poetic word.

e)k gh=s—kera/nnutai. Cf. Tim. 42E (of the creation of man) mimou/menoi (i.e. the created gods) to
 sfe/teron dhmiourgo/n, puro\s kai\ gh=s u(/dato/s te kai\ a)e/pos a)ro\ tou= ko/smou daneizo/menoi mo/pia w(s a)podoqhso/mena pa/lin ei)s tau)to
 ta\ lambano/mena cuneko/llwn. For ‘air and water’ is substituted here tw=n o(/sa puri\ kai\ gh=| kera/nnutai. Fire is the rarest and earth the densest of the four elements: Protagoras' theory is that air and water are produced by mixing these in different proportions, for kera/nnutai cannot mean merely that the elements interchange. Cf. the theory attributed by Aristotle to Parmenides: Met. I. 5. 986b. 33 du/o ta\s ai)ti/as kai\ du/o ta\s a)rxa\s pa/lin ti/qhsi, qermo
 kai\ yuxro/n, oi(=on
pu=r kai\ gh=n le/gwn. It is noteworthy that Plato himself regards all four elements as differentiated, although imperfectly, before the creation of the ko/smos by the dhmiourgo/s: cf. Tim. 53A ff. The chiasmus in gh=s kai\ puro/s followed by puri\ kai\ gh=| is part of Protagoras' art.
5. e)peidh\ d' a)/gein au)ta\ pro\s fw=s e)/mellon. Cf. Rep. III. 414D e)peidh\ de\ pantelw=s e)ceirgasme/noi h)=san kai\ h( gh= au)tou\s mh/thr ou)=sa a)nh=ke.

6. *promhqei= kai\ *)epimhqei=. In Gorg. 523D Prometheus again appears as the servant of Zeus, commissioned to put a stop to man's foreknowledge of his day of death: in Polit. 274C he is mentioned as the giver of fire to mortals. The Hesiodic and Aeschylean form of the legend, in which Prometheus steals the fire, does not appear in Plato, except at 321D nor is there any hint in his works of the story in Hesiod about the gift of Pandora —the source of human ills—to Epimetheus (Works and Days, 50 ff.), though it is worth noting that Plato like Hesiod makes the creation of woman posterior to that of man (Tim. 42B).

8. paraitei=tai—au)to\s nei=mai. The object clause, as usual with verbs like paraitei=sqai (deprecari), depends on the positive part of the verb (here ai)tei=sqai): see on Apol. 31B. au)to/s is ‘by himself’, without Prometheus' aid. We follow Cron and Turner in retaining the MSS. nei/mantos de/ mou as against Bekker's d' e)mou=: the antithesis, as Cron remarks, is between the actions—nei/mantos and e)pi/skeyai. The point to be noticed is that Afterthought invites Forethought to exchange offices with him: it is Afterthought whose duty it is to inspect (e)piske/yasqai: cf. Gorg. 526C o( de\ *mi/nws e)piskopw=n ka/qhtai).
10. ta\ d' a)sqene/stera—ta\ de/. B and T have tou\s d' a)sqeneste/rous—tou\s de/, a natural mistake, which can hardly be due to Plato.

12. e)mhxana=to du/namin ei)s swthri/an. Plato's own style rarely falls into verse: cf. Rep. X. 621B ei)s th
 ge/nesin a)/|ttontas w(/sper a)ste/ras. The whole passage is full of rare and often poetic rhythms, words, constructions, and turns of expression: e.g. a)/oplon fu/sin, smikro/thti h)/mpisxen, pthno
 fugh/n, tw=|de au)tw=| (for au)tw=| tou/tw|), a)i+stwqei/h, a)llhlofqoriw=n diafuga\s e)ph/rkese, eu)mari/an (as against eu)ma/reian), and many more: note also the effort after balance and variety in i(kanoi=s me
 a)mu=nai xeimw=na,
dunatoi=s de\ kai\ kau/mata (321A, toi=s me
 e)k gh=s—a)/llois de\—toi=s de\—e)/sti d' oi(=s. ‘Summum opinor’, says Heindorf, ‘in his imitantis philosophi appareret artificium, si quid de propria Protagorae dictione superesset’. See Introduction, p. xix.

13. smikro/thti h)/mpisxen. The usual construction would require smikro/thta: the change is perhaps due to the desire for balance with a(\ de\ hu)=ce mege/qei, but the same construction occurs below in l. 19 with a)mfiennu/s.

17. mh/ ti ge/nos a)i+stwqei/h. Aesch. Prom. 232 a)i+stw/sas ge/nos; ibid. 668 kerauno\n o(\s pa=n e)cai+stw/soi ge/nos. Note the emphasis with which Protagoras asserts the permanence of the genus: cf. below, 321Bswthri/an tw=| ge/nei pori/zwn.
19. eu)mari/an. So Schanz with BT: the editors generally read eu)ma/reian. The older form is intentionally used here: see above on l. 12.
23. u(podw=n is Cobet's correction for u(po\ podw=n of B and T. See below on 321Cgumno/n te kai\ a)nupo/dhton ktl.

24. ta\ de\ de/rmasin stereoi=s kai\ a)nai/mois. After ta\ de/ the MSS. read qrici\n kai/. The words seem to have been wrongly introduced from l. 20. This (the suggestion of Ast, adopted by Schanz and others) seems better than to read for qrici\n kai/ the words o)/nucin kai/.

30. ou) pa/nu ti = non satis: cf. note on Euthyphr. 2B ou)d' au)to\s pa/nu ti gignw/skw. ou) pa/nu is the English ‘not quite’, sometimes equivalent to ‘not at all’ by meiosis: the addition of ti makes the phrase a little less emphatic. pa/nu ou) is quite a different phrase and means ‘altogether not’.
31. katanalw/sas ta\s duna/meis. After ta\s duna/meis, the words ei)s ta\ a)/loga are found in T, but not in B.
35. e)mmelw=s pa/ntwn e)/xonta: like i(kanw=s tou= ba/qous e)/xonta in Theaet. 194D and the genitive after kalw=s e)/xein and the like.

36. gumno/n te kai\ a)nupo/dhtonkai\ a)/strwtonkai\ a)/oplon. Cf. the description of *)/erws in Symp. 203C: a)nupo/dhtos kai\ a)/oikos, xamaipeth\s a)ei\ w)
 kai\ a)/strwtos. a)nupo/dhton contrasts with u(podw=n in 321B(l. 23), and justifies Cobet's emendation for u(po\
podw=n. Aristotle (peri\ zw/|wn mori/wn, IV. 10, p. 687a. 23) alludes to this passage of the Protagoras: a)ll' oi( le/gontes w(s sune/sthken ou) kalw=s o( a)/nqrwpos, a)lla\ xei/rista tw=n zw/|wn (a)nupo/dhto/n te ga au)to
 ei)=nai/ fasi kai\ gumno
 kai\ ou)k e)/xonta o)/plon pro\s th
 a)lkh/n), ou)k o)rqw=s le/gousin.
37. e)n h)=|. See above on e)n th=| u(sterai/a| (318A. All the qnhta\ ge/nh then according to Protagoras issued forth on the same day. Plato thought otherwise: see on 320D l. 1.

38. e)xo/menos: so T: ‘sxo/menos B, sed in marg. vitii nota’ (Schanz). sxo/menos is occasionally found in this passive sense, especially in compounds (Sauppe quotes Soph. 250D sunesxo/meqa and Isocr. XIX. II fqo/h| sxo/menon), but the present participle is at least equally well attested here and suits the meaning better: cf. (with Kroschel) Laws, VI. 780B u(po\ pollh=s a)pori/as e)xome/nois.

40. th
 e)/ntexnon sofi/an su
 puri/. Aesch. Prom. 252-4 pro\s toi=sde me/ntoi pu=r e)gw/ sfin w)/pasa. kai\ nu=n flogwpo
 pu=r e)/xous' e)fh/meroi, a)f' ou(= ge polla\s e)kmaqh/sontai te/xnas—which is the usual form of the story. In Polit. 274C Plato attributes fire to Prometheus, and the arts to Hephaestus and Athena. su/n denotes a much closer connection than meta/: it is seldom used by Plato except in a few adverbial phrases, or in religious uses (like cu/n tisi *xa/risi kai\ *mou/sais Laws, III. 682A), or in semi-poetic passages like the present: see on ou)deni\ cu
 nw=| in Crito, 48C.
44. e)/sxen is ‘obtained’: see on e)/sxete in Apol. 19A. h)=n ga\r para\ tw=| *dii/ reminds one of Sophocles' *di/kh cu/nedros *zhno/s, O.C. 1382.

46. ou)ke/ti means that Prometheus had to draw the line there; he had been able to steal the fire, but farther he could not go—no doubt because time pressed. The same idiomatic use of ou)ke/ti)(h)/dh occurs above in 312Ema\ *di/', e)/fh, ou)ke/ti e)/xw soi le/gein: it is extremely common in Plato and in Greek generally: see note on Euthyphr. 3E and Cope on Arist. Rhet. A, 1. 1354b. 7 referred to there.

47. *dio\s fulakai/ are no doubt *kra/tos and *bi/a, as in the Prometheus. Cf. Hesiod, Theog. 385 ff. (quoted by Heindorf) kai\ *kra/tos h)de\ *bi/hn a)ridei/keta gei/nato te/kna (sc. *stu/c) tw=n ou)k e)/st'
a)pa/neuqe *dio\s do/mos ou)de/ tis e(/drh ou)d' o(do\s o(/pph| mh\ kei/nois qeo\s h(gemoneu/ei: a)ll' ai)ei\ pa\r *zhni\ baruktu/pw| e(drio/wntai.
ei)s de\ to\ th=s *)aqhna=s ktl. Protagoras reverts to the story of the theft. Similarly in 346Dbelow Socrates reverts to a part of the poem which he has quoted some time before in 345C
49. e)/mpuron te/xnhn is te/xnh which works by pu=r, as e)/ntexnos sofi/a in line 40 is sofi/a working by te/xnh.

52. tou= bi/ou—di' *)epimhqe/a. bi/ou is ‘means of living’ as in l. 43. The words di' *)epimhqe/a mean ‘thanks to Epimetheus’: cf. Ar. Clouds, 12-14 a)ll' ou) du/namai dei/laios eu(/dein dakno/menos u(po\ th=s dapa/nhs kai\ th=s fa/tnhs kai\ tw=n xrew=n, dia\ toutoni\ to\n ui(o/n, and in Rep. I. 354A ou) me/ntoi kalw=s ge ei(sti/amai, di' e)mauto/n, a)ll' ou) dia\ se/. The words are rejected by Schanz (after Sauppe), but without reason: the jingle (*pro-mhqe/a de\ di' *)epi-mhqe/a) is quite in Protagoras' style.

53. h(=|per le/getai. Aeschylus relates the punishment but not the trial: cf. Prom. 7-9 to\ so\n ga\r a)/nqos, pante/xnou puro\s se/las, qnhtoi=si kle/yas w)/pasen: toia=sde/toi a(marti/as sfe dei=qeoi=s dou=nai di/khn.

div.head: CHAPTER XII
div.p: The myth is continued (322A322D and used to justify the Athenians for listening to promiscuous political advisers, since according to it all men are endowed with politikh\ a)reth/—as indeed all men believe, otherwise they would not (as they do) regard as insane the man who does not at least pretend to possess justice and politikh\ a)reth/ generally.
1. qei/as mete/sxe moi/ras: moi=ra is ‘dispensation’, and refers to the e)/ntexnos sofi/a, which is qei/a because derived from Hephaestus and Athena.

2. [dia\ th
 tou= qeou= sugge/neian]. These words are open to objection on two grounds. The singular tou= qeou= is inaccurate— no single god has been mentioned as akin to man: nor can tou= qeou= well be taken as God in the monotheistic sense, or as generic for tw=n qew=n—both usages are alien to the whole tone of the myth. These difficulties might perhaps be got over by reading tou= qei/ou = tw=n qew=n, but another difficulty remains. The reference in th
 sugge/neian can only be to 320Dtupou=sin au)ta\ qeoi/, the creatures being regarded as children of their creators as
in Tim. 42E noh/santes oi( pai=des (the created gods) th
 tou= patro\s dia/tacin, but there it is not only man but all qnhta\ ge/nh that are in this sense ‘akin to gods’—why then should not the lower animals also have built themselves fanes? As the phrase is at best a bad case of loose thinking and inaccurate writing in an otherwise careful and elaborate piece of composition, I have followed Kral and Schanz in rejecting the whole phrase. The words were perhaps an (inaccurate) gloss on qei/as in qei/as moi/ras. For the sentiment which they express see the Editor's Introduction to the Euthyphro, p. xvi.
mo/non: man alone qei/as mete/sxe moi/ras: see note in loc. Cobet's mo/nos would be more grammatical, but the attraction of zw/|wn is too strong.
e)pexei/rei bwmou/s te i(dru/esqai ktl. Hom. Od. III. 48 pa/ntes de\ qew=n xate/ous' a)/nqrwpoi.
3. e)/peita. prw=ton me/n and e)/peita refer to logical sequence rather than temporal: Protagoras follows the maxim e)k *dio\s a)rxw/mesqa.
6. hu(/reto. MSS. eu(/reto, but see on 315Babove.

8. a)pw/llunto ou)=n u(po\ tw=n qhri/wn. Cf. Polit. 274B th=s ga\p tou= kekthme/nou kai\ ne/montos h(ma=s dai/monos a)rephmwqe/ntes e)rimelei/as, tw=n rollw=n au)= qhpi/wn, o)/sa xalera\ ta\s fu/seis h)=n, a)ragpiwqe/ntwn, au)toi\ de\ a)sqenei=s a)/nqpwtoi kai\ a)fu/laktoi gegono/tes dihrpa/zonto u(p' au)tw=n.
12. h(=s me/ros polemikh/. polemikh/ is recognised as a part of politikh/ in Rep. II. 373D ff.

13. sw/|zesqai kti/zontes po/leis. The insufficiency of the individual for his own wants is assigned as the cause of city life in Rep. II. 369B gi/gnetai toi/nun—po/lis, w(s e)gw)=|mai, e)peidh\ tugxa/nei h(mw=n e(/kastos ou)k au)ta/pkhs a)lla\ rollw=n e)ndeh/s: h)\ ti/n' oi)/ei a)rxh\n a)/llhn po/lin oi)ki/zein; ou)demi/an, h)= d' o)/s.

17. ai)dw= te kai\ di/khn. The editors cite Hesiod (Works and Days, 192) di/kh d' e)n xersi\ kai\ ai)dw\s ou)k e)/stai (of the ge/nos sidh/reon, where man is corrupt). ai)dw/s is a part of de/os (Euthyphr. 12C): it keeps men together by making them fear the censure of their fellows (Laws, I. 647A-B); cf. Hom. Il. XV. 561 ff. w)= fi/loi, a)ne/res e)/ste, kai\ ai)dw= qe/sq' e)ni\ qumw=|, a)llh/lous t' ai)dei=sqe kata\
kratera\s u(smi/nas. ai)dome/nwn d' a)ndrw=n ple/ones so/oi h)e\ pe/fantai: feugo/ntwn d' ou)/t' a)\r kle/os o)/rnutai ou)/te tis a)lkh/. di/kh is here the abstract principle ‘law’ like Latin ius: for the original meaning of the word see Verrall on Eur. Med. 411.
18. po/lewn ko/smoi—sunagwgoi/. The phraseology no less than the rhythm is highly poetical.

19. ti/na ou)=n tro/pon. For ou)=n retained in the indirect the editors cite Symp. 219D w(/ste ou)/q' o(/pws ou)=n o)rgizoi/mhn ei)=xon ou)/q' o(/ph| prosagagoi/mhn au)to\n hu)po/roun. Cobet's dw= for doi/h is attractive but unnecessary.

20. po/teron w(s ktl. ‘Eleganter omissum e)/fh, ut obliqua oratio statim in rectam transeat’ Heindorf, quoting (inter alia) Xen. Cyrop. I. 4. 28 e)ntau=qa dh\ to
 *ku=ron gela/sai te e)k tw=n rpo/sqen dakpu/wn kai\ ei)rei=n au)tw=| a)rio/nta qappei=n o(/ti rape/stai au)=qis o)li/gou xro/nou: w(/ste o(ra=n soi e)ce/stai ka)
 bou/lh| a)skardamuktei/. Sauppe quotes an exact parallel in 338Bbelow ei)=pon ou)=n e)gw\ o(/ti ai)sxro
 ei)/h brabeuth
 e(le/sqai tw=n lo/gwn. eite ga xei/rwn e)/stai ktl.
22. eis e)/xwn i)atrikh\n—i)diw/tais. This division of labour takes place as soon as men begin to unite in cities: cf. Rep. II. 369Eff.
28. ktei/nein w(s no/son po/lews. ktei/nein is poetical for the a)poktei/nein of prose.
30. *)aqhnai=oi: without the article as in 319Band 324C

33. ou)k a)ne/xontai, w(s su\ fh/|s: 319Cou)de/n ti ma=llon a)pode/xontai. The antithesis between ou)k a)ne/xontai w(s su\ fh/|s and ei)ko/tws w(s e)gw/ fhmi is a poor one, since ou)k a)ne/xontai has to be repeated with ei)ko/tws. We should expect some word like a)lo/gws before w(s su\ fh/|s, or perhaps ou)k ei)ko/tws has dropped out after fh/|s.

35. h(
 dei= dia\ dikaiosu/nhs—i)e/nai. The antecedent to h(/n is sumboulh/n not a)reth=s: cf. Laws, I. 632C (quoted by Heindorf) katidw
 de\ o( qei\s tou\s no/mous a(/pasin tou/tois fu/lakas e)pisth/sei, tou\s me
 (sc. fu/lakas) dia\ fronh/sews, tou\s de\ di' a)lhqou=s do/chs i)o/ntas. The phrase dia\ dikaiosu/nhs i)e/nai is equivalent to dikai/an ei)=nai as dia\ fili/as i)e/nai to fi/lon ei)=nai.

36. a(/pantos. Schanz reads panto/s on account of panti/ following: but Plato frequently interchanges a(/pas and pa=s; see on Euthyphr. 9E. It is natural that the more emphatic form a(/pantos should come first.
38. h)\ mh\ ei)=nai po/leis. h)/ = alioquin is regular with dei=, prosh/kei, and the like, in the preceding clause: cf. below 323c h)\ mh\ ei)=nai e)n a)nqrw/pois and 325A
au(/th—tou/tou ai)ti/a: asyndeton as in 318Atosou=tos o(/ ge h(me/teros lo/gos.

39. w(s tw=| o)/nti h(gou=ntai. The presence of tw=| o)/nti, as Sauppe remarks, shows that w(s depends on tekmh/rion in l. 42: cf. below, 324Cw(s me\n ou)=n ei)ko/tws a)pode/xontai—a)pode/deiktai/ soi.
52. prospoiou/menon dikaiosu/nhn: elsewhere in Plato prospoiei=sqai takes the infinitive. Thuc. 1. 137. 7 has h(\n yeudw=s prosepoih/sato.
w(s a)nagkai=on: o)/n need not be added, as Heindorf shows: cf. Rep. V. 449C w(s a)/ra peri\ gunaikw=n te kai\ pai/dwn panti\ dh=lon o(/ti koina\ ta\ fi/lwn e)/stai.

div.head: CHAPTER XIII
div.p: Protagoras now passes to the second part of his reply (323C24D), in which he seeks to prove by two arguments that men believe that virtue can be taught: (1) as we hold men responsible for a)diki/a, it is clear that we conceive of it as capable of being acquired (323C324A; (2) punishment is in point of fact intended to teach well-doing (324A324D.

4. ou) fu/sei h(gou=ntai ei)=nai—a)lla\ didakto/n. Sauppe (on 322C remarks that the giving of di/kh and ai)dw/s to all is inconsistent with the theory that politikh\ a)reth/ can be acquired by teaching. What Protagoras no doubt means is that while all men have a part in dikaiosu/nh (323A, because they possess di/kh and ai)dw/s, they may be improved by teaching; but it must be allowed that his words are hardly consistent with themselves. See Introduction, pp. xvii-xviii.

14. ta\ kala\ kai\ ta)nanti/a tou)tois. This, the MSS. reading, retained by Heindorf, and recently by Kral, is, we think, right. pau=ta in l. 12 does not have its antecedent in the previous sentence, but is explained by ta\ kala\ kai\ ta)nanti/a tou/tois. Protagoras in fact divides ‘goods’ into two classes, viz. (1) goods fu/sei, (2) goods e)c e)pimelei/as kai\ a)skh/sews kai\ didaxh=s, and calls the former kala/, the implied examples being personal beauty, stature and health. Schanz's rejection of ta\ kala/ is therefore needless.

The editors mostly read ta\ kaka/, but (in spite of Ficinus' haec mala eorumque contraria) this would seem to be precluded by the me/n and de/ in tau=ta me\n ga/r and o(/sa de\—a)gaqa/: the contrast requires that one class of goods shall be set over against another, and is much weakened if we put ‘evils’ in the foreground by reading ta\ kaka/. Further, tau=ta is too remote to be easily taken with ta\ kaka/ in the sense of ‘these evils’, whereas if we take the pronoun merely as anticipating ta\ kaka/, then the statement becomes too wide: for not all kaka/, not all a)gaqa/ (ta)nanti/a tou/tois, on this view), come to men fu/sei, as indeed the next clause states.
19. sullh/bdhn pa=n to\ e)nanti/on—a)reth=s. We have here the first hint of the unity of the different vices and (by implication) virtues: cf. below, 329C
22. ei) ga\r e)qe/leis—dida/cei. Cf. below, 342D
23. au)to/ se dida/cei: ‘fact will show you,: Theaet. 200E o( to\n potamo\n kaqhgou/menos—e)/fh a)/ra dei/cein au)to/; the idiom is a frequent one.

25. ou)dei\s ga/r kola/zei ktl. Plato's own theory of punishment so far agrees with this, but goes deeper: see Gorg. 525A ff. prosh/kei de\ panti\ tw=| e)n timwri/a| o)/nti, u(p' a)/llou o)rqw=s timwroume/nw|, h)\ belti/oni gi/gnesqai kai\ o)ni/nasqai h)\ rapadei/gmati toi=s a)/llois gi/gnesqai, i(/na a)/lloi o(rw=ntes pa/sxonta a(\ a)
 pa/sxh| fobou/menoi belti/ous gi/gnwntai. Vice (being ignorance) is disease of soul, as no/sos is of body: it is the business of the judge to cure the one as of the physician to cure the other: cf. Rep. IX. 591A-B and Gorg. 478D swfroni/zei
ga/r pou kai\ dikaiote/rous poiei= kai\ i)atrikh\ gi/gnetai ponhri/as h( di/kh: hence (ibid. 480B ff.) the sinner should go before the judge as readily as the patient to a doctor, and should even accuse his friends. In the ideal city the judges are to put to death incurable sinners just as the doctors will allow incurable patients to die: Rep. III. 409E ff. tw=n politw=n soi tou\s me
 eu)fuei=s ta\ sw/mata kai\ ta\s yuxa\s qepareu/sousi, tou\s de\ mh/, o(/soi me
 kata\ sw=ma toiou=toi, a)roqnh/|skein e)a/sousi, tou\s de\ kata\ th
 yuxh
 kakofuei=s kai\ a)nia/tous au)toi\ a)poktenou=sin. The same holds good of punishment after death: for Ardiaeus and the others in Rep. X. 616A, whose punishment is everlasting (ou)x h(/kei—ou)d' a)
 h(/cei deu=ro), are incurable—a)texnw=s paradei/gmata a)nhrthme/nous e)kei= e)n a(/|dou e)n tw=| desmwthpi/w|, toi=s a)ei\ tw=n a)di/kwn a)fiknoume/nois qea/mata kai\ nouqeth/mata—the majority are punished to purge them of the guilt contracted upon earth and teach them to choose more wisely their lot of life next time. The remedial view of punishment is embedded in the genius of the Greek language, as is shown by the punitive sense of swfroni/zein, dikaiou=n, eu)qu/nein. The older and sterner view (dra/santi paqei=n) appears more rarely in Plato's time.
27. h)di/khsen. See above on 319D

28. timwrei=tai. The editors quote Ar. Rhet. A, 10. 1369b. 12 diafe/rei de\ timwri/a kai\ ko/lasis: h( me\n ga\r ko/lasis tou= pa/sxontos e(/neka/ e)stin, h( de\ timwri/a tou= poiou=ntos, i(/na a)poplhrwqh=|. The distinction is not invariably observed in Plato, although he generally uses timwrei=sqai in passages where the gravity of the sin is more insisted upon.

29. ou) tou= parelhluqo/tos—a)ge/nhton qei/h. Turner (on 324B quotes Laws, XI. 934A ou)x e(/neka tou= kakourgh=sai didou\s th
 di/khn, ou) ga to\ gegono\s a)ge/nhton e)/stai pote/ ktl. The phrase ou) ga a)
 to/ ge praxqe
 a)ge/nhton qei/h represents a common proverbial saying: cf. Simonides, Frag. 69 to\ ga gegenhme/non ou)ke/t' a)/rekton e)/stai (Sauppe) with Bergk's note, and the impressive application of the saying in Aesch. Ag. 1019-21 to\ d' e)ri\ ga=n a(/rac reso
 qana/simon rpora/poiq' a)ndpo\s me/lan ai(=ma ti/s a)
 pa/lin a)gkale/sait' e)paei/dwn;
36. kola/zontai: the middle (in the present) is rare: Heindorf quotes Ar. Wasps, 405 nu=n e)kei=no nu=n e)kei=no tou)cu/qumon w(=| kolazo/mesqa ke/ntron e)nte/tat' o)cu/.

div.head: CHAPTER XIV
div.p: Here begins the third part of Protagoras' reply: 324E328D In this chapter he begins to show that virtue is in point of fact taught to all by showing that it would be absurd to suppose that it is not.

1. loiph\ a)pori/a. For the omission of the article before a relative clause (Heindorf suggested the insertion of h( after loiph/) Sauppe quotes Rep. III. 413E fu/lac au(tou= w)\n a)gaqo\s kai\ mousikh=s h(=s e)ma/nqanen. The a)pori/a was raised by Socrates in 319Dff.

3. dida/skousin. Contrast below 325Bta\ me\n a)/lla dida/skontai tou\s ui(ei=s and ibid. tou\s ui(ei=s dida/skontai, said of the parents as dida/skousin (in the usual sense of dida/skontai) is said here and in Meno, 94B. Similarly in Prot. 320Ae)pai/deue is used where we should expect e)paideu/eto: cf. e)paideu/sato in Meno, 93D.
a(\ didaska/lwn e)/xetai. See note on 319Eabove.
6. ou)ke/ti mu=qon a)lla\ lo/gon. Gorg. 523A o(\n su\ me\n h(gh/sei mu=qon, w(s e)gw\ oi)=mai, e)gw\ de\ lo/gon: w(s a)lhqh= ga\p o)/nta soi le/cw a(\ me/llw le/gein.
12. dikaiosu/nh—to\ o(/sion ei)=nai. Thus for the first time Protagoras definitely speaks of the virtues in language implying their unity: cf. 323E

14. a)ndro\s a)reth/n: a)ndro/s is somewhat loftier and more impressive than a)nqrw/pou (cf. Rep. VIII. 565E bi/on a)ndro\s a)fani/zwn). For the sentiment cf. Rep. VI. 501B cummignu/ntes te kai\ kerannu/ntes e)k tw=n e)pithdeuma/twn to\ a)ndrei/kelon, a)p' e)kei/nou tekmairo/menoi, o(\ dh\ kai\ *(/omhros e)ka/lesen e)n toi=s a)nqrw/pois e)ggigno/menon qeoeide/s te kai\ qeoei/kelon.

15. meta\ tou)tou: not meq' ou(=, see on 313Akai\ e)n w(=|. For the use of meta/ cf. Phaed. 69A ff. (mh\) h)=| e)kei=no mo/non to\ no/misma
o)rqo/n, a)nq' ou(= dei= a(/panta tau=ta katalla/ttesqai, fro/nhsis, kai\ tou/tou me\n kai\ meta\ tou/tou (w)nou/mena/ te kai\ piprasko/mena) tw=| o)/nti h)=| kai\ a)ndrei/a ktl.
18. kai\ pai=da kai\ a)/ndra kai\ gunai=ka: nearly equivalent to ‘not only child but etc.’: pai=da is put first as the natural object of kola/zein—‘et nos ergo manum ferulae subduximus’ (Juv. 1. 15).
20. u(pakou/h| is more than obey: the word means ‘to hear and answer’ (cf. Crito, 43A): tr. ‘respond’, sc. by becoming better (as explained in l. 19).

21. w(s a)ni/aton o)/nta—a)poktei/nein: Rep. III. 410A tou\s— kata\ th\n yuxh\n kakofuei=s kai\ a)nia/tous au)toi\ a)poktenou=si. In the next line au)tou= in au)tou= pefuko/tos is still this ‘one thing’, viz. a)ndro\s a)reth/.

24. w(s qauma/sioi gi/gnontai. The MSS. have w(s qaumasi/ws gi/gnontai, which could only mean ‘in what a strange way are produced’—a meaning irrelevant here. The point is that it is qaumasto/n if ‘good men’—virtue having been proved to be teachable—teach their sons everything except virtue. qauma/sioi (with Kroschel and other editors) seems the simplest of the many emendations proposed: cf. Euthyd. 305B qauma/sioi/ ei)sin oi( toiou=toi a)/ndres. The mistake may have arisen from the influence of the common qaumasi/ws w(s. Next best is Hirschig's qaumasi/ws gi/gnontai a)gaqoi\ oi( a)gaqoi\ (cf. 328Eou)k ei)=nai a)nqrwpi/nhn e)pime/leian h)=| a)gaqoi\ oi( a)gaqoi\ gi/gnontai) or qaumasi/ws gi/gnontai oi( a)gaqoi\ a)gaqoi/: cf. Meno, 89B oi( a)gaqoi\ a)gaqoi\ gi/gnontai and Heindorf's emendation on 326Cbelow. As to gi/gnontai ‘Saepius a Platone id quod argumentatione colligitur, gi/gnesqai dicitur, ut p. 355Afhmi\ u(mi=n tou/tou ou(/tws e)/xontos geloi=on to\n lo/gon gi/gnesqai o(/tan le/ghte ktl., Euthyd. p. 298E ou)kou=n o( ku/wn path\r w)\n so/s e)stin, w(/ste so\s path\r gi/gnetai o( ku/wn’ (Kroschel). The same use of gi/gnesqai is common in Aristotle.
27. ta\ me\n a)/lla a)/ra. For the form of the sentence and for a)/ra here and in l. 33 cf. note on Crito, 50E h)\ pro\s me\n a)/ra.
28. dida/skontai (but not of course a)/ra) is interrogative: so ou) dida/skontai in l. 33.

29. e)f' w)=|. This, and not e)f' w)=n (as asserted by Schanz), is after all the reading of B: see Adamson in Cl. Rev. VII, 445. In itself, e)f' w(=n (so T) is not indefensible: e)f' w(=n (i.e. e)pi\ tou/twn a(\)
ktl. would mean ‘in the case of subjects which if they have not learnt’ (mh\ maqou=si), the latent a(/ depending on maqou=si. This use of e)pi\ with the genitive is common in Plato, e.g. Rep. VII. 524E w(/sper e)pi\ tou= daktu/lou e)le/gomen. But e)f' w(=| (which Heindorf had already conjectured) is simpler and better. For the misplacement of te in h(/ te zhmi/a see note on 316Dabove.

32. w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n is to be taken with cullh/bdhn, which goes with the verbal noun a)natropai/: ‘almost wholesale subversion of their house’. cullh/bdhn means ‘not kata\ smikro/n, but so as to embrace everything’: cf. Rep. 1. 344AB turanni\s h(\ ou) kata\ smikro\n ta)llo/tria kai\ la/qra| kai\ bi/a| a)fairei=tai—a)lla\ cullh/bdhn, and Theognis, 147 e)n de\ dikaiosu/nh| sullh/bdhn pa=s' a)reth\ 'ni. For w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n see on 317A
34. oi)/esqai/ ge xrh/: a way of answering one's own question: Crito, 53D, 54B.

div.head: CHAPTER XV
div.p: In this chapter Protagoras shows that the whole scheme of Athenian education is intended to teach a)reth/.
1. me/xri ou(=per a)\n zw=si, i.e. oi/ paideuo/menoi: in 326Dff. it is shown that education does not end when school is left, but goes on through life.

2. e)peida
 qa=tton seems not to occur elsewhere in the Platonic writings: in Alcib. I, 105A is e)a
 qa=tton. ta/xista is more usual after such conjunctions. Kroschel quotes an imitation of this passage from De Rep. Laced. 2. 1 e)peida
 ta/xista oi( pai=des au)toi=s ta\ lego/mena cuniw=sin, eu)qu\s me
 e)r' au)toi=s raidagwgou\s qera/pontas e)fista=sin, eu)qu\s de\ pe/mpousin ei)s didaska/lwn maqhsome/nous kai\ gra/mmata kai\ mousikh
 kai\ ta\ e)n palai/stra|.
5. o(/pws be/ltistos: so BT: there is no reason for inserting w(s after o(/pws with Kroschel and Turner: be/ltistos does not mean better than all others, but very good.
par' e(/kaston ktl. ‘Est eo ipso tempore quo quidque vel fit vel dicitur’ (Heindorf).
7. to\ me\n di/kaion ktl. Sauppe well quotes Ter. Ad. 417-18 where a father nouqetei= his son ‘Hoc facito—Hoc fugito—Hoc laudi est—Hoc vitio datur’. Cf. Hor. Sat. I. 4. 105 ff.

9. ta\ me
 poi/ei, ta\ de\ mh\ poi/ei: ta\ me
 is not di/kaion, kalo/n, o(/sion, but quite general: ‘this do, that do not’. The ta/de me
— ta/de de/ of T is unnecessary; cf. to\ me
—to\ de/ in l. 7. The symmetry of the sentence is worth noting (a, b, b, a): first to\ me
—to\ de/, next to/de me
—to/de de/ twice, last ta\ me
—ta\ de/, the end recalling the beginning. Cf. note on kai\ kako
 kai\ ai)sxro/n in Crito, 49B.

e)a
 me
 e(kw
 pei/qhtai: without apodosis: see Goodwin, Moods and Tenses (1889), p. 179. This idiom occurs more than once in Homer: it is perhaps a remnant of the days when the conditional particles introduced a main sentence: certainly the Greeks were not conscious of any such ellipse as eu)= e(/cei.

10. w(/sper cu/lon diastrefo/menon. cu/lon is ‘a piece of wood’, not necessarily a dead log, as appears from Hdt. III. 47 ei)ri/oisi a)po\ cu/lou (of the cotton tree) and other exx. in L. and S. The growing child is compared to a tree growing up and becoming crooked (note the present diastrefo/menon—kampto/menon). Plato frequently applies the metaphors ‘crooked’, ‘warped’ and the like to victims of vice and vicious education: cf. Gorg. 525A pa/nta skolia\ u(po\ yeu/dous kai\ a)lazonei/as; Theaet. 173A smikroi\ de\ kai\ ou)k o)rqoi\ ta\s yuxa/s.

11. eu)qu/nousin—plhgai=s. Cf. Arist. *)aqhn. polit. ch. 8 tou\s a(marta/nontas hu)/qunen kuri/a ou)=sa tou= zhmiou=n kai\ kola/zein (of the Areopagitic council). For eu)qu/nein (here passing into the meaning of ‘chastise’) see note on 324Aou)dei\s ga\r kola/zei. To illustrate plhgai=s Sauppe quotes the well-known line of Menander o( mh\ darei\s a)/nqrwpos ou) paideu/etai.

12. ei)s didaska/lwn pe/mpontes. It appears from 326Cthat there was no regular age for going to school; the parents decided in each case. Plato ordains (Laws, VII. 809E) that children shall learn gra/mmata (i.e. reading and writing, ibid. 810B) from 10 to 13, and the lyre from 13 to 16.
polu\ ma=llon—eu)kosmi/as. Protagoras' description of the aim of Athenian education agrees with the account of the *di/kaios lo/gos in the Clouds, 961 ff.
16. w(/sper to/te: above, 325Ce)peida\n qa=tton sunih=| tis ta\ lego/mena.

17. e)pi\ tw=n ba/qrwn: i.e. as they sit on the benches: cf.
above 315C paratiqe/asin represents the works of the poets as intellectual food: cf. Theaet. 157C parati/qhmi e(ka/stwn tw=n sofw=n a)pogeu/sasqai.

18. poihtw=n a)gaqw=n: Homer especially, and also Hesiod, Theognis, Phocylides. Cf. Laws, VII. 810E, from which passage it also appears that extracts were frequently made for committing to memory (e)kmanqa/nein).

19. a)nagka/zousin: meta\ lu/phs ga\r h( ma/qhsis Arist. Pol. VIII. 1339a. 28 (quoted by Sauppe). So Niceratus in Xenophon, Symp. III. 5 says that his father h)na/gkase/ me pa/nta ta\ *(omh/ron e)/ph maqei=n.

20. die/codoi means finished narratives or descriptions (cf. lo/gw| diecelqw/n and diecie/nai in 320C. It is to be noted that so far we have not got beyond poi/hsis yilh/ (i.e. unaccompanied by music): lyric poetry begins to be studied when the lyre has been learnt (l. 25).

23. e(/tera toiau=ta: for the phrase see on Apol. 26A. The accusative (internal) depends on e)pimelou=ntai as in 325Ce)pimelou=ntai pa=san e)pime/leian and Laws, VII. 812E a)lla\ tau=ta me\n o( paideuth\s e)pimelei/sqw: the whole phrase is equivalent to e(te/ran toiau/thn swfrosu/nhs te e)pime/leian poiou=ntai. Verbs taking the external object in the genitive or dative are not precluded from taking the internal object in the accusative.

26. ei)s ta\ kiqari/smata e)ntei/nontes. e)ntei/nein ei)s is to stretch into, i.e. to ‘put into’: whence e)ntei/nein e)s ku/klon xwri/on tri/gwnon ‘to describe a triangle in a circle’ (Meno, 87A); peri\ ga/p toi tw=n roihma/twn w)=n reroi/hkas e)ntei/nas tou\s tou= *ai)sw/rou lo/gous of adapting to metre (Phaed. 60D); and here of accompanying poems on the lyre: the boys learn the poems and tunes (made by the poet) together, while the Citharist plays the lyre. Plato in the Laws, VII. 812D ff. requires the kiqari/smata to be identical with the tune to which the poem is sung: dei=—toi=s fqo/ggois th=s lu/pas rposxph=sqai—to/n te kiqapisth
 kai\ to
 raideuo/menon, a)rodido/ntas rpo/sxopda ta\ fqe/gmata toi=s fqe/gmasi: th
 d' e(tepofwni/an kai\ roikili/an th=s lu/pas, a)/lla me
 me/lh tw=n xopdw=n i(eisw=n, a)/lla de\ tou= th
 melw?di/an cunqe/ntos roihtou=—ra/nta ta\ toiau=ta mh\ prosfe/rein ktl.

27. r(uqmou/s te kai\ a(rmoni/as. r(uqmoi/ times or rhythms (cf. Rep. III. 399E ff.), a(rmoni/ai scales (ibid. 398Dff.). r(uqmo/s and a(rmoni/a between them make up mousikh/ in the narrower sense: see Symp. 187A ff., where music is defined as peri\ a(rmoni/an kai\ r(uqmo\n e)rwtikw=n e)pisth/mh—peri\ a(rmoni/an since it reconciles o)cu/ and baru/, peri\ r(uqmo/n since it reconciles taxu/ and bradu/.

28. oi)keiou=sqai tai=s yuxai=s tw=n pai/dwn. Sauppe quotes Rep. III. 401D kuriwta/th e)n mousikh=| trofh/, o(/ti ma/lista katadu/etai ei)s to\ e)nto\s th=s yuxh=s o)/ te r(uqmo\s kai\ a(rmoni/a kai\ e)rrwmene/stata a(/ptetai au)th=s.

29. eu)ruqmo/teroi kai\ eu)armosto/teroi. See Rep. III. 400C ff., where, after it is shown that to\ eu)/ruqmon and to\ eu)a/rmoston imply eu)logi/a, Plato continues (400D) eu)logi/a a)/ra kai\ eu)apmosti/a kai\ eu)sxhmosu/nh kai\ eu)puqmi/a eu)hqei/a| a)kolouqei=, ou)x h(\n a)/noian ou)=san u(rokopizo/menoi kalou=men w(s eu)h/qeian, a)lla\ th\n w(s a)lhqw=s eu)= te kai\ kalw=s to\ h)=qos kateskeuasme/nhn dia/noian.
33. ei)s paidotri/bou: Protagoras passes to gumnastikh/, the second great division of Greek education: Rep. II. 376E.

34. u(phretw=si th=| dianoi/a|. Plato asserts that the true object of gumnastikh/ is not to cultivate the body, but to educate the soul to the proper mean between hardness and softness: Rep. III. 410C ff. On the soul as the mistress of the body see Phaedo, ch. 43.

37. ma/lista oi( ma/lista duna/menoi. The first ma/lista is due to Heindorf: it is necessary to the meaning. Most of the editors insert the word ma/lista not after poiou=sin but after duna/menoi, explaining its loss by the presence of ma/lista following: but it comes (we think) more naturally after poiou=sin.

41. e)k didaska/lwn a)pallagw=sin: e)k is rejected by Cobet (cf. Gorg. 514C e)peidh\ tw=n didaska/lwn a)phlla/ghmen): but the phrase is just as stereotyped as ei)s didaska/lwn, to which (in l. 39) it forms an appropriate contrast—in neither of the two cases were the Greeks (in all probability) conscious in common parlance of an ellipse. Sauppe quotes a fragment of Ar. Banqueters, 42 ou)k eu)qu\s a)pedi/draskes e)k didaska/lou; Plutus, 84 e)k *patrokle/ous e)/rxomai, and other parallels.
42. a)nagka/zei manqa/nein: hardly to be taken literally, but only in the sense that ignorance was no excuse for breaking the laws.

43. kata\ tou/tous zh=n. After zh=n occur in the MSS. the words kata\ para/deigma. ‘Facile succurrat cuivis kata\ tou/tous zh=n kaqa/per para/deigma—quamquam talia notanda potius quam statim corrigenda’ says Heindorf. Most recent editors bracket or reject the words, which are open to objection on several grounds, that the laws are not an example but a rule of life, and Plato does not use para/deigma precisely in this way, as well as from the harsh omission of w(s. The suggestion of Sauppe that the words are a gloss on kata\ tou/tous by a scribe referring to the illustration which follows—‘as for example’— has much probability.
44. grammatistai: see on grammatistou=, 312B

45. u(pogra/yantes gramma\s th=| grafi/di should be understood of tracing (by dots or otherwise) the outlines of the lines (grammai/) which form letters. These outlines would be filled up by the pupil: see Blümner, Griechische Privataltherthümer, p. 315. The usual view (since Heindorf) has been to regard the grammai/ as horizontal lines ruled for guidance; ‘ut pueri in schola directe s. ad lineam scribere iubentur, ita in vita quae agunt ad legis normam iis dirigenda sunt’ (Kroschel). Such a view is, however, inconsistent with the meaning of u(pogra/fein and of u(fh/ghsis, and (in view of Plato's statements as to the nature of Law) renders the simile inexact. u(pogra/fein in Plato regularly refers to an outline drawing (as u(potupou=sqai to moulding in outline Tim. 76E) and is opposed to a)perga/sasqai and (in Aristotle) to a)nagra/fein, e.g. Rep. VIII. 548C-D ou)kou=n— au(/th me
 h( rolitei/a ou(/tw gegonui=a kai\ toiau/th a)/n tis ei)/h, w(s lo/gw| sxh=ma rolitei/as u(rogpa/yanta mh\ a)kpibw=s a)repga/sasqai dia\ to\ e)capkei=n me
 i)dei=n kai\ e)k th=s u(rogpafh=s to/n te dikaio/taton kai\ to
 a)dikw/taton, and Theaet. 172E, where a litigant's a)ntwmosi/a is called u(pografh/—a sort of outline drawing w(=n e)kto\s ou) r(hte/on, but which his speech must simply a)perga/sasqai. u(fhgei=sqai is similarly used, only with the added idea of guiding: e.g. Rep. III. 403D-E ou)kou=n ei) th
 dia/noian i(kanw=s qerapeu/santes paradoi=men au)th=| ta\ peri\ to\ sw=ma a)kribologei=sqai, h(mei=s de\ o(/son tou\s tu/pous u(fhghsai/meqa—o)rqw=s a(
 poioi=men; and Laws, X. 890C dei= tau=ta ou(/tw pra/ttein dianooume/nous o(/ph|per a)
 o( nomoqe/ths u(fhgh/shtai gra/fwn. The point of the simile is this. As the child draws his pen between the outlines of the lines forming letters
(making e.g. into ), so we must keep our actions between certain outlines, which are the laws. Plato invariably regards no/moi as only tu/poi, within which our actions should fall: cf. Rep. II. 383C panta/pasin—e)/gwge tou\s tu/pous tou/tous sugxwrw=, kai\ w(s no/mois a)
 xrw/?mhn (whence no/mous u(pogra/fein here and in Laws, V. 734E): see also Polit. 294A ff. to\ d' a)/riston ou) tou\s no/mous e)sti
 i)sxu/ein, a)ll' a)/ndpa to
 meta\ fponh/sews basiliko
—o(/ti no/mos ou)k a)/n rote du/naito to/ te a)/piston kai\ to\ dikaio/taton a)kpibw=s ra=sin a(/ma repilabw
 to\ be/ltiston e)rita/ttein. ai( ga\p a)nomoio/thtes tw=n te a)nqpw/rwn kai\ tw=n rpa/cewn—ou)de
 e)w=sin a(rlou=n e)n ou)deni\ repi\ a(ra/ntwn kai\ e)ri\ ra/nta to
 xpo/non a)pofai/nesqai te/xnhn ou)d' h(ntinou=n—for which reason in the Republic (VI. 497D) there must always be a power above the laws. The explanation which we have given does not disagree with the account of Seneca in his Epistles, XV. 2. 51 ‘Pueri ad praescriptum discunt. Digiti illorum tenentur et aliena manu per literarum simulacra ducuntur’: it is supported by Quintilian, I. 1. 27 ‘cum vero iam ductus sequi coeperit, non inutile erit eas (sc. literas) tabellae quam optime insculpi, ut per illos velut sulcos ducatur stilus’. It is probable that both these authors had the present passage in view.
It should be noted that gra/fein no/mous was a regular phrase: cf. the image in Rep. VI. 501A.

48. w(\s de\ kai\. w(/s for ou(/tws is rare in Attic prose: Heindorf quotes (inter alia) Rep. VII. 530D kinduneu/ei w(s pro\s a)stronomi/an o)/mmata pe/phgen, w(\s pro\s e)narmo/nion fora\n w)=ta pagh=nai. For de/ see above on 318C

53. eu)qu=nai regularly denotes the ‘putting straight’ or examination of a magistrate when his office expired. It is not clear whether Protagoras' philological zeal does not cause him to stretch a point in giving to the word a wider signification: but see on eu)qu/nousin in 325D

div.head: CHAPTER XVI
div.p:
Protagoras at last comes to the difficulty raised by Socrates in 319E Virtue having been proved to be teachable, it is only from a lack of natural aptitude that good men's sons sometimes turn
out badly: compared with men who have never been taught virtue, even they are good. Protagoras concludes with a manifest bid for pupils.
3. e)/mprosqen: viz. at 324E
5. ou)de/na dei= i)diwteu/ein: equivalent to pa/ntas dei= ei)=nai dhmiourgou/s: no one must be a layman in a)reth/.

10. e)di/daske kai\ e)pe/plhtte to\n mh\ kalw=s au)lou=nta. As e)di/daske is the important word, e)pe/plhtte has no effect on the construction, but is in effect enclitic: see on 317Ce)ndei/casqai kai\ kallwpi/sasqai.

17. ei) ou)=n ou(/tw. ou)=n marks the reversion to the original protasis, viz. ei) mh\ oi)=o/n t' h\n—kai\ tou=to ktl., from lusitelei= to no/mima being parenthetical: it therefore seems better to print a colon rather than a full stop after no/mima.
22. e)llo/gimos hu)ch/qh. Proleptic adjectives with au)ca/nw are common: Heindorf cites (inter alia) Rep. VIII. 565C tou=ton tre/fein te kai\ au)/cein me/gan.

25. a)ll' ou)=n au)lhtai/ g' a)/n: a)/n for gou=n was Shilleto's conjecture, which can hardly fail to be right. a)ll' ou)=n—ge is an emphatic ‘but at all events’; cf. Gorg. 496D manqa/nw: a)ll' ou)=n to/ ge peinh=n au)to\ a)niaro/n.
27. ou(/tws oi)/ou kai\ nu=n. Sauppe's w)/|ou ka)\n nu=n seems to be quite needless: the conclusion is naturally put as a command— ‘so in the present case, you are to think’.

28. tw=n e)n no/mois kai\ a)nqrw/pois. So BT. a)nqrw/pois in this emphatic sense is a little awkward with a)nqrw/pous two lines below and a)nqrw/pois said seven lines below of savages (though the word is qualified in both cases), but the text is probably right: cf. 323Ca)nagkai=on ou)de/na o(/ntin' ou)xi\ a(mw=s ge/ pws mete/xein au)th=s (sc. th=s dikaiosu/nhs), h)\ mh\ ei)=nai e)n a)nqrw/pois. Of the suggested emendations the most reasonable is perhaps Sauppe's e)n no/mois kai\ e)nno/mois a)nqrw/pois—which he has now given up in favour of the MSS. reading.
29. au)to/n is not emphatic: to be di/kaios is to be a dhmiourgo\s dikaiosu/nhs, cf. 326Eth=s a)reth=s—ou)de/na dei= i)diwteu/ein.

31. mh/te—mh/te—mh/te—mhde/. mhde/ introduces the climax: see note on ou)/te—ou)de/ ge in Apol. 19D and Cope on Ar. Rhet. A, 4. 4. Presently a)ll' ei)=en is used rather than a)ll' ei)si/ (in spite of e)sti/n in l. 31) because the hypothetical nature of the case is becoming more prominent. For the passage of a relative clause into a main clause (oi(/ is not to be repeated after a)lla/) see on 313A

33. a)ll' ei)=en a)/grioi/ tines. It appears not only from Athenaeus (v. 218D), but from Suidas and others, that the play in question was called *)/agrioi. The few fragments of it which remain (see Kock's Comicorum Atticorum Fragmenta, I, 146-50) give us no indication of the plot or treatment. The probability is that the *)/agrioi formed the chorus (cf. the names *nefe/lai, *ba/traxoi etc.), ‘ad quos’—as we should infer from the words of Plato— ‘Athenienses quidam, pauci sine dubio, vitae civilis in sua urbe pertaesi (misa/nqrwpoi) sicut Pithetaerus et Euelpides, accedebant imprudenter sperantes se inter homines immanes meliorem iustioremque quam in civitate sua vitam inventuros esse’ (Kock). Plato was perhaps thinking of the same play again in Rep. VI. 496D w(/sper ei)s qhri/a a)/nqrwpos e)mpesw/n, ou)/te cunadikei=n e)qe/lwn ou)/te i(kano\s w)\n ei)=s pa=sin a)gri/ois a)nte/xein.

oi(=oi/ per ou(\s pe/rusin: so BT, and there is no sufficient reason for altering the text to oi(/ous pe/rusin (with Sauppe, after Athenaeus V. 218D) or oi(/ous per pe/rusin with Schanz. Plato does not always avail himself of the liberty of attraction: a parallel is quoted from Crat. 432E i(/na komidh=| h)=| toiou=ton oi(=o/n per ou(= o)/noma/ e)stin.

34. pe/rusin. Athenaeus, V. 218D e)dida/xqhsan de\ oi( *)/agrioi e)p' *)aristi/wnos a)/rxontos, i.e. Ol. 89 4 = 421/420 B.C. For the bearing of the date of the *)/agrioi on the question when the dialogue of the Protagoras is assumed to have taken place see Introduction, p. xxxiii.
*ferekra/ths. The fragments of Pherecrates—a poet of the old comedy who gained his first victory in 438 B.C.—are given in Kock's Comicorum Atticorum Fragmenta, I, 145-209.

e)di/dacen e)pi\ *lhnai/w|. The *lh/naion (also called li/mnai and te/menos tou= *dionu/sou) was an enclosure sacred to Dionysus on the south-east slope of the Acropolis. Cf. Photius s.v. *lh/naion: peri/bolos me/gas *)aqh/nhsin, e)n w(=| tou\s a)gw=nas h)=gon, pro\ tou= to\
qe/atron oi)kodomhqh=nai, o)noma/zontes e)pi\ *lhnai/w|. The phrase ‘at Lenaeum’ seems to have survived even after all plays were given in the Dionysiac theatre, as by this time they were, and to have been understood as equivalent to ‘at the Lenaean festival’ (cf. Ar. Ach. 504 ou(pi\ *lhnai/w| t' a)gw/n), for which the expressions e)n *lhnai/ois and (e)dida/xqh) ei)s *lh/naia are more usual in the didascaliae (see Müller's Bühnenalterthümer, p. 316, n. 3). The Lenaea took place in the month Gamelion.
36. w(/sper oi( e)n e)kei/nw| tw=| xorw=|, sc. geno/menoi. gi/gnesqai e)n is ‘to come to be in or among’, ‘to fall among’. e)n tw=| proqu/rw| e)geno/meqa of 314Cis the same idiom.

misa/nqrwpoi. So the MSS. The various suggested emendations (h(mia/nqrwpoi Heinrich, mica/nqrwpoi Jacobs, mesa/nqrwpoi Lehrs) proceed on the supposition that the word is an epithet of the a)/grioi, which is most improbable: ‘alii sunt a)/grioi, alii misa/nqrwpoi, neque in illa sermonis iunctura’ (sc. if we regard the w(/sper clause as explaining toi=s toiou/tois) ‘scribendum w(/sper sed oi(=oi/ per fuit’ (Heindorf).

37. *eu)ruba/tw| kai\ *frunw/nda|. Two proverbial scoundrels of real life: see Suidas s.vv. *eu)ru/batos ponhro/s, a)po\ tou= remfqe/ntos u(ro\ *kpoi/sou e)ri\ cenologi/an meta\ xphma/twn, w(/s fhsin *)/efopos, ei)=ta metabalome/nou rpo\s *ku=pon: h)=n de\ *)efe/sios ktl. *fpunw/ndas tw=n e)ri\ ronhpi/a| diabebohme/nwn, o(\s ce/nos w)\n kata\ ta\ *reloronnhsiaka\ die/tpiben *)aqh/nhsin:—e)k tou/tou tou\s ronhpou\s *frunw/ndas kalou=si. They are frequently mentioned in Greek literature: see Blaydes on Ar. Thesm. 861. Blaydes remarks that -w/ndas is a Boeotian termination: cf. *)epameinw/ndas, *xarw/ndas and the like.
40. ou)dei/s soi fai/netai ei)=nai. ei)=nai is Heindorf's emendation for e)=q' of the Bodleian. For the asyndeton with w(/sper see above on 311E
41. ti/s dida/skalos tou= e(llhni/zein. The same illustration occurs in Alc. I. 111A.

46. tou/tous e)/ti ti/s a)
 dida/ceien repeats ti/s a)
—dida/ceien tou\s tw=n xeirotexnw=n ui(ei=s: and ou) r(a/|dion oi)=mai ei)=nai—tou/twn dida/skalon fanh=nai is a variety on ou)d' a)
 ei(=s fanei/h, which the ou)de/ g' a)/n of l. 42 might lead us to expect would be repeated—
but the sentence is a slight anacoluthon. This is better than to take a)/n of ou)de/ g' a)/n in l. 42 with ei)=nai of l. 47.
49. ou(/tw de\ a)reth=s. On ou(/tw de/ see above, note on 318C

50. ka)
 ei): this idiom is somewhat rare in Plato, e.g. Meno, 72C ka)
 ei) pollai\ kai\ pantodapai/ ei)sin, e(/n ge/ ti ei)=dos a)/pasai e)/xousin: it is extremely common in Aristotle. The a)/n shows that the idiom must have arisen from cases where the apodosis contained a verb with which a)/n could go, e.g. ka)
 ei) a)poqnh/|skoi, eu)= e)/xoi. Such cases as Symp. 185A ka)
 ei)/ tis—e)capathqei/h, kalh\ h( a)pa/th, where the verb after ei) is in the optative, preserve traces of the origin of the construction.
53. o)nh=sai/ tina pro/s. o)nh=sai is Dobree's correction for noh=sai: cf. Rep. X. 601D ei)/per oi)=o/s t' h)=n pro\s a)reth\n o)nh=sai a)nqrw/pous.

56. to\n tro/pon th=s pra/cews tou= misqou=. Ar. Eth. Nic. IX. 2. 1164a. 24 o(/per fasi\ kai\ *prwtago/ran poiei=n: o(/te ga\r dida/ceien a(dh/rote, timh=sai to\n maqo/nta e)ke/leuen o(/sou dokei= a)/cia e)pi/stasqai kai\ e)la/mbane tosou=ton. This is more than Plato says: see next note.

58. a)pode/dwken: but kate/qhken (gnomic aorist) two lines lower down. It is not necessary to reject a)pode/dwken (with Sauppe and Schanz) or to read a)pe/dwken (with Kroschel and Kral). a)pode/dwken is hardly to be explained as a gnomic perfect (Goodwin), certain examples of which are rare, if not unknown, but is to be taken in its natural sense: ‘if he prefers, he has already paid . . . if not etc.’: this is also Heindorf's view. Unless the pupil had paid in advance, Protagoras left the fee to his own conscience and (according to his own account, w(/ste kai\ au)tw=| dokei=n tw=| maqo/nti) generally fared better, even though (if Diog. Laert. IX. 52 may be trusted) his fee was 100 minae. If Protagoras made no bad debts, he escapes the censure of Plato in Gorg. 519C, where it is said that, if teachers of dikaiosu/nh do not receive their fees, it only shows that they have failed to teach their subject and deserve no fees.

59. e)lqw
 ei)s i(ero/n. ‘Tactis sacris aramve tenentes veteres iurare satis est notum’ Heindorf, quoting Aeschin. in Timarch.
§ 114 labw
 ei)s th
 e(autou= xei=ra ta\ i(era\ kai\ o)mo/sas mh\ labei=n dw=ra—ei)lhfw\s h)le/gxqh.
67. tw=nde. Protagoras is more encouraging than Socrates in 319E

div.head: CHAPTER XVII
div.p: Here begins Socrates' criticism of Protagoras' speech. The question is first raised—Is Virtue one, or many? The connection between this question and the speech of Protagoras is that if Virtue has a unity in knowledge, it is teachable, otherwise not: see Introduction, p. xviii.

2. e)pideica/menos. e)pidei/knusqai and e)pi/deicis are regularly used of a Sophistic display: e.g. Gorg. 447A polla\ ga\r kai\ kala\ *gorgi/as h(mi=n o)li/gon pro/teron e)pedei/cato, Crat. 384B th\n penthkonta/draxmon e)pi/deicin. e)pidei/knumi is also sometimes used in the same way, e.g. Euthyd. 274D and below, 347B in 320Cabove a)ll' e)pi/deicon is intended to suggest this meaning, which comes out more clearly in e)pidei/cw two lines below.
2. e)pi\ me\n polu\n xro/non goes with e)/blepon and e)/ti with kekhlhme/nos.
7. w)= pai= *)apollodw/rou: with mock solemnity: so 335Dw)= pai= *(ipponi/kou, Rep. II. 368A w)= pai=des e)kei/nou ta)ndro/s.
8. w)=de in the sense of deu=ro is noted as a Platonic idiom by the lexicographers. The usage is found in tragedy, but no other example is quoted from Plato.
10. a)nqrwpi/nhn e)pime/leian: cf. Meno, 99E a)reth\ a)\n ei)/h ou)/te fu/sei ou)/te didakto/n, a)lla\ qei/a| moi/ra| paragignome/nh a)/neu nou=.
13. e)pekdida/cei—e)cedi/dacen: see on 311A
16. ta/x' a)\n kai\ toiou/tous lo/gous: kai/ goes with toiou/tous —‘even such’, ‘just such’: tou/tou should not be inserted (with Sauppe, Schanz, Kral) before toiou/tous.

18. w(/sper bibli/a. Hermann wished to read ou)x w(/sper bibli/a, since the orators do make a speech when spoken to: but the point is that like books they do not answer the questions asked, or put questions themselves, as the true dialectician does:
cf. Phaedr. 275D deino
 ga/r pou—tou=t' e)/xei grafh/, kai\ w(s a)lhqw=s o(/moion zwgpafi/a|. kai\ ga\p ta\ e)kei/nhs e)/kgona e(/sthke me
 w(s zw=nta, e)a
 d' a)ne/ph| ti, semnw=s ra/nu siga=|. tau)to
 de\ kai\ oi( lo/goi: do/cais me
 a)
 w(/s ti fponou=ntas au)tou\s le/gein, e)a
 de/ ti e)/ph| tw=n legome/nwn boulo/menos maqei=n, e)/n ti shmai/nei mo/non tau)to
 a)ei/: below, 347E and Hipp. Min. 365Dto
 me
 *(/omhron—e)a/swmen, e)reidh\ kai\ a)du/naton e)ranepe/sqai, ti/ rote now=n tau=ta e)roi/hse ta\ e)/ph. A similar objection applies to laws: see Polit. 294A (quoted above on 326D.
20. w(/sper ta\ xalki/a. The MSS. have xalkei=a, but (as Kroschel points out) in Crat. 430A ei)/ ti xalki/on kinh/seie krou/sas. xalkei=a would mean ‘smithies’.

21. makro\n h)xei= kai\ a)potei/nei: a)potei/nei is used absolutely as in Gorg. 458B kai\ nu=n i)/sws po/rrw a)potenou=men. Cf. Euthyd. 300Bo(/tan ou)=n li/qous le/gh|s kai\ cu/la kai\ sidh/ria, ou) sigw=nta le/geis; ou)/koun a(/ ge e)gw/, e)/fh, pare/rxomai e)n toi=s xalkei/ois (MSS. xalki/ois), a)lla\ fqeggo/mena kai\ bow=nta me/giston ta\ sidh/ria le/gei.

23. do/lixon katatei/nousi tou=lo/gou. dolixo/n is the reading of B and T, but (1) the adjective dolixo/s seems to be exclusively poetic, the word surviving in Plato's time only in the form do/lixos for dolixo\s dro/mos (cf. for the change of accent ka/kh and kakh/, *fai=dros and faidro/s and the like); (2) dolixo\s tou= lo/gou would be a rare construction, though not without parallels, e.g. pollh
 th=s xw/ras in Xen. Cyrop. III. 2. 2 and th/s mari/lhs suxnh/n in Ar. Ach. 350: a)mh/xanon th=s eu)daimoni/as of Apol. 41C is different; (3) after the expressive simile which we have had, ‘a long speech’ sounds very weak. On the other hand do/lixos tou= lo/gou, the suggestion of Stephanus, is strongly supported by 335E where Socrates compares Protagoras, because he plays the r(h/twr and not the dialectician, to a dolixodro/mos: nu=n d' e)sti
 w(/srep a)
 ei) de/oio/ mou *kpi/swni tw=| *(imepai/w| dpomei= a)kma/zonti e(/resqai h)\ tw=n dolixodpo/mwn tw| h)\ tw=n h(mepodpo/mwn diaqei=n te kai\ e(/pesqai, and the editors quote a number of parallels to the metaphor, such as Plut. Phoc. 23. 3 kalw=s e)/fh pro\s to\ sta/dion, to
 de\ do/lixon tou= pole/mou fobou=mai; Epicrates in Kock's Com. Att. Frag. II, 283 e)pei\ de\ do/lixon toi=s e)/tesin h)/dh tre/xei, Ar. Clouds, 430 tw=n *(ellh/nwn ei)=nai/ me le/gein e(kato
 stadi/oisin a)/riston and Frogs, 91 plei=n h)\ stadi/w| lali/stera, Eupolis (Kock, I, 281) (of Pericles) o(po/te pare/lqoi d' w(/sper a(gaqoi\ dromh=s e)k de/ka podw=n h(/|rei le/gwn tou\s r(h/toras. Dropping the sporting metaphor
we may say ‘spin out a league of verbiage against you’. The do/lixos was 24 sta/dia, the sta/dion being covered 12 times both ways: cf. Pind. Ol. III. 33.

25. w(s au)ta\ dhloi=. The MSS. read au)ta/, which most recent editors change to au)to/ with Stephanus, regarding the idiom as analogous to that in 324Aau)to/ se dida/cei, but in this idiomatic use of au)to/ the verb is generally, if not always, in the future. au)to/ pou le/gei in Ar. Eq. 204 and the cases quoted by Blaydes in loc. are different, since in each case au)to/ has a definite antecedent expressed. w(s au)ta\ dhloi= is simply ‘as things themselves’, i.e. ‘as facts show’: the reference is to the speech which Protagoras has just delivered. Cf. Ar. Pol. IV. 12. 1331a. 21 dh=lon w(s au)ta\ prokalei=tai ktl. and (with Heindorf) Xen. Cyr. VI. 1. 7 ou)k oi)=da me\n e)/gwge, ei)/ ti dei= lo/gwn, o(/pou au)ta\ ta\ e)/rga dei/knusi to\ kra/tiston.
29. ei)/ moi a)pokri/naio to/de. The optative follows smikrou= tino\s e)ndeh/s ei)mi pa/nt' e)/xein as virtually equivalent to pa/nt' a)\n e)/xoimi (Heindorf).

30. ei)/per a)/llw| tw| a)nqrw/pwn peiqoi/mhn a)/n, kai\ soi\ pei/qomai. The fullness of expression is no doubt intentional: Socrates politely dwells upon his compliment. The objections to the syntax are twofold: (1) a)/n with the optative in protasis; (2) ei)/per (in clauses of this kind) with its verb expressed. Cases of the potential optative in the protasis are given by Goodwin, M.T. p. 192 (e.g. Xen. Mem. I. 5. 3 ei)/ ge mhde\ dou=lon a)krath= decai/meq' a)/n, pw=s ou)k a)/cion au)to/n ge fula/casqai toiou=ton gene/sqai;): for ei)/per with verb expressed Heindorf cites Meno, 98B a)ll' ei)/per ti a)/llo fai/hn a)
 ei)de/nai (o)li/ga d' a)
 fai/hn) e(
 d' ou)=n kai\ tou=to e)kei/nwn qei/hn a)
 w(=n oi)=da. Socrates' nu=n de\ pe/peismai (hardly serious) in 328Eis not inconsistent with peiqoi/mhn a)/n, since he at once qualifies his assent by plh
 smikro/n ti/ moi e)mpodw/n: it is sufficiently represented here by kai\ soi\ pei/qomai. We therefore agree with Heindorf, Wayte, and Turner in retaining the MSS. reading: other editors mostly read either ei)/per a)/llw? tw| a)nqrw/pwn peiqoi/mhn a)
 kai\ soi/, or drop peiqoi/mhn a)/n and retain kai\ soi\ pei/qomai.
33. e)/leges ga/r: 332Cdikaiosu/nh and ai)dw/s are looked on as two distinct virtues.
34. pollaxou=: 324E325A cf. 323Aand E.

div.head: CHAPTER XVIII
div.p: Socrates elicits from Protagoras (1) that while Virtue as a whole is one, the single virtues differ from each other and from the whole like the parts of the face, that it is possible to possess one virtue without possessing all, and that in all there are five virtues, justice, temperance, holiness, bravery, wisdom, of which the last is greatest (329D330A; (2) that the virtues differ from each other not only in themselves, but in their du/namis (330A330B; (3) that justice is just, and holiness holy (330B330E. The refutation of Protagoras does not begin till the next chapter.

3. prosw/pou: prosw/pou is treated as an abstract conception —‘parts of face’: cf. yuxh/ in 313Cka/phlos tw=n a)gwgi/mwn a)f' w(=n yuxh\ tre/fetai, Rep. IV. 435C ei)s fau=lo/n ge au)=—skw=mma e)mrertw/kamen repi\ yuxh=s, ei)/te e)/xei ta\ tpi/a ei)/dh tau=ta e)n au(th=? ei)/te mh/. In Aristotelian language, the face is a)nomoiomere/s.

6. a)llh/lwn kai\ tou= o(/lou: so the MSS. and Heindorf (who suggests a)llh/lwn te kai\ tou= o(/lou): recent editors mostly omit either a)llh/lwn or ta\ e(/tera tw=n e(te/rwn. ta\ e(/tera tw=n e(te/rwn should be taken quite generally, tw=n e(te/rwn (and thus, by implication, ta\ e(/tera) having its meaning defined by the clause a)llh/lwn kai\ tou= o(/lou. ta\ e(/tera tw=n e(te/rwn could be dropped without injury to the sense, but hardly a)llh/lwn: without a)llh/lwn Plato would have written ou)de\n diafe/rei to\ e(/teron tou= e(te/rou kai\ tou= o(/lou: cf. 330Aa)=r' ou)=n ou(/tw kai\ ta\ th=s a)reth=s mo/ria ou)k e)/stin to\ e(/teron oi(=on to\ e(/teron (not ta\ e(/tera oi(=a ta\ e(/tera); and so 330E 331A 331D 349B 359A

10. metalamba/nousin—mori/wn—a)/llo. metalamba/nein, mete/xein, metadido/nai and the like take an accusative of the part as well as a genitive of the whole. metalamba/nein mo/rion = ‘to
receive a part of a whole’: metalamba/nein mori/ou = ‘to receive a part of a part’.

13. a)ndrei=oi/ ei)sin a)/dikoi de/: cf. Laws, I. 630B pisto\s me\n ga\r kai\ u(gih\s e)n sta/sesin ou)k a)/n rote ge/noito a)/neu cumra/shs a)peth=s. diaba/ntes d' eu)= kai\ maxo/menoi e)qe/lontes a)roqnh/|skein e)n tw=| role/mw| w(s fpa/zei *tu/ptaios tw=n misqofo/pwn ei)si\ ra/mrolloi, w(=n oi( rlei=stoi gi/gnontai qpasei=s kai\ a)/dikoi kai\ u(bpistai\ kai\ a)fpone/statoi sxedo\n a(pa/ntwn.
14. kai\ tau=ta: for sofi/a and a)ndrei/a have not yet been named—only dikaiosu/nh and swfrosu/nh and o(sio/ths. See Introd. p. xxxi.
16. kai\ me/gisto/n ge sofi/a: Protagoras speaks as a sofisth/s, glorifying his profession.

17. a)/llo, to\ de\ a)/llo: equivalent to to\ me
 a)/llo, to\ de\ a)/llo. to\ de/, ta\ de/, etc., without preceding to\ me/n, ta\ me/n, etc., is a frequent idiom. Crat. 399A polla/kis e)pemba/llomen gra/mmata, ta\ d' e)cairou=men, Soph. O.T. 1229 oi)=mai ga ou)/t' a)
 *)/istron ou)/te *fa=sin a)
 ni/yai kaqapmw=| th/nde th
 ste/ghn o(/sa keu/qei, ta\ d' au)ti/k' ei)s to\ fw=s fanei= kaka/.

18. w(/sper ta\ tou= prosw/pou: we have placed the mark of interrogation before w(/sper: see on a)/llo ge in 311E The sentence w(/sper ta\ tou= prosw/pou ou)k e)/stin o)fqalmo\s oi(=on ta\ w)=ta thus corresponds exactly to a)=r' ou)=n ou(/tw kai\ ta\ th=s a)reth=s mo/ria ou)k e)/stin to\ e(/teron oi(=on to\ e(/teron. For ta\ tou= prosw/pou followed by its parts in the same case cf. below 349Ae)kei=na—ta\ me/n—ta\ de/ and Theaet. 151A oi(=s o(/tan pa/lin e)/lqwsi—e)ni/ois me\n—a)pokwlu/ei sunei=nai, e)ni/ois de\ e)a=|. For the asyndeton regular in explanatory and ampliative clauses see note on Apol. 22A.
25. a)ll' ou(/tws, e)/fh, e)/xei, w)= *sw/krates. So T: B has only a)ll' ou(/tws, e)/fh. The longer form of answer is more suited to Protagoras' style.
31. h( dikaiosu/nh pra=gma/ ti/ e)stin. Cf. below 332Aa)frosu/nhn ti kalei=s; 332C 358D Plato frequently begins a train of reasoning in this way.

32. kai\ e)moi/: so T: B has kai/ moi. kai\ e)moi/ seems slightly
better than ka)moi/, as forming a more effective balance to e)moi\ me/n in the same line.

33. w)= *prwtago/ra te kai\ *sw/krates: but e)me/ te kai\ se/ as Greek usage requires. Protagoras is addressed first on the principle seniores priores and honoris causa; contrast 311D and cf. 353A(Kroschel).

34. ei)/peton: contrast 311Dei)pe/ moi, w)= *sw/krate/s te kai\ *(ippo/krates, where see note. The dual gives prominence to the notion in koinh=| skeyw/meqa (l. 29). The connection of this part of the argument with the rest is this: in 330A330Bit is said that no one part of virtue is oi(=on to\ e(/teron, e.g. that dikaiosu/nh is not oi(=on o(sio/ths (major premise); here it is said that dikaiosu/nh is di/kaion, o(sio/ths o(/sion (minor premise): from which the conclusion (in the next chapter) is drawn that dikaiosu/nh is not o(/sion, nor o(sio/ths di/kaion. This stage of the argument is therefore neither ‘tautological nor unmeaning’, as Grote (quoted by Turner) asserts.
45. oi(=on a)no/sion ei(=nai h)\ oi(=on o(/sion. Notice the identification of the ‘not o(/sion’ with a)no/sion: see below on 331A

47. eu)fh/mei, w)= a)/nqrwpe. w)= a)/nqrwpe is somewhat brusque: so w)= a)/nqrwpoi in 314Dabove. a)/nqrwpe without w)= would border on rudeness: e.g. Gorg. 518C i)/sws a)\n ou)=n h)gana/kteis, ei)/ soi e)/legon, a)/nqrwpe, ou)de\n e)pai+/eis peri\ gumnastikh=s. eu)fh/mei is frequent to express shocked surprise, real or feigned: e.g. Rep. I. 329C Meno, 91B (*(hra/kleis, eu)fh/mei, w)= *sw/krates), Gorg. 469A, Euthyd. 301A.

div.head: CHAPTER XIX
div.p: Socrates endeavours to refute Protagoras and to show that Justice and Holiness are identical. If o(sio/ths is not oi(=on dikaiosu/nh, nor dikaiosu/nh oi(=on o(sio/ths, it will follow (says Socrates) that o(sio/ths is a)/dikon and dikaiosu/nh a)no/sion. This is absurd, and therefore o(sio/ths is di/kaion and dikaiosu/nh is o(/sion. Protagoras will only admit that there is a certain likeness between the two virtues.

4. ou(/tws—w(s. w(/ste for w(s would be more usual: cf. Rep. II. 365De)c w(=n ta\ me\n pei/somen, ta\ de\ biaso/meqa, w(s pleonektou=ntes di/khn mh\ dido/nai. Perhaps the w(s of Phaedo, 108E pe/peismai—w(s prw=ton me/n—mhde\n au)th=| dei=n mh/te a)e/ros ktl. is the same in kind: cf. the old English ‘so as’. Here ou(/tws—w(s with the infinitive is natural in view of toiou=ton oi(=on in the vicinity: 330Cand D.
9-10. su\—so/s: notice the mock asperity: I expected better things of you.
14. ou)k a)/ra e)sti/n: the interrogation begins here and a)/ra is illative.

15. a)ll' oi(=on mh\ o(/sion. So far we are entitled to go, but in to\ de\ a)no/sion (l. 17) the contrary and the contradictory are confused, as is frequently the case in Plato's dialogues: see note on Euthyphr. 7A qeomise/s, where are cited Alcib. II, 138D ff., Rep. IV. 437C; add Phileb. 48B ff., where fqo/nos is said to be joy at a friend's misfortune because envy of a friend's success implies joy at his ill-luck (cf. ibid. 50A), and Euthyd. 276B ou)kou=n ei) mh\ sofoi/, a)maqei=s; pa/nu ge. Plato was not unaware of the rules of logic in this matter (see Symp. 201E-202A), but the tendency of Greek thought and life was not to rest content with negations; whence words like a)nwfelh/s, a)/fqonos acquired a positive significance, and Solon could enact (*)aqhnai/wn politei/a ch. 8 ad fin.) o(\s a)\n stasiazou/shs th=s po/lews mh\ tiqh=tai ta\ o(/pla mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn, a)/timon ei)=nai kai\ th=s po/lews mh\ mete/xein. Part of the argument in the next chapter suffers from the same flaw: see on 332A l. 3.

16. a)ll' a)/dikon a)/ra: Heindorf's emendation for a)lla\ di/kaion a)/ra, the reading of the best MSS., which to\ de\ a)no/sion proves to be wrong and shows how to correct. Heindorf's correction was afterwards confirmed by a Paris MS. a)/ra is illative. For to\ me/n unexpressed (the words are equivalent to a)lla\ to\ me\n a)/dikon a)/ra) before to\ de/ see on 330Aa)/llo, to\ de\ a)/llo.
20. o(/ti is ‘because’, not ‘that’: see note on l. 22 below.

21. dikaio/ths o(sio/thti. Socrates gives the words the same termination to suggest their closer likeness (‘justness’ to ‘holiness’);
dikaio/ths is found also in Gorg. 508A as a balance to kosmio/thta. Plato was fond of this suffix and coined by it the word poio/ths Theaet. 182A.

22. kai\ ma/lista pa/ntwn—oi(=on dikaiosu/nh. Kroschel objects to the emphasis, and inclines to doubt the genuineness of this clause. If o(/ti in l. 20 is translated as ‘because’ and not as ‘that’, the difficulty disappears. tau)ta\ a)\n tau=ta in l. 20 thus means simply that dikaiosu/nh is o)/sion and o(sio/ths di/kaion (ll. 18-19), which is the meaning also assigned to tau)ta\ a)\n tau=ta by Protagoras in his reply (ll. 25 ff.). Socrates (for Protagoras) will reply that dikaiosu/nh is o(/sion and o(sio/ths di/kaion for two main reasons: (1) because dikaio/ths is the same as o(sio/ths—this he does not much insist on—or because dikaio/ths is o(/ tio(moio/taton o(sio/thti—this he insists on more: (2) because dikaiosu/nh is oi(=on o(sio/ths and o(sio/ths oi(=on dikaiosu/nh—this he insists on most of all (ma/lista pa/ntwn), and with reason, because it expressly refutes Protagoras' assertion in 330AB. On the other hand if o(/ti is translated as ‘that’, Kroschel's objections can hardly be got over—viz. that h)/toi tau)to/n—dikaiosu/nh is not the same as Socrates' reply on his own behalf; that the words are ignored both by Protagoras in his reply and by Socrates himself in 333B and that the emphasis of ma/lista pa/ntwn is strained and unnatural.

26. a(plou=n: opposed to a)lla/ ti/ moi dokei= e)n au)tw=? dia/foron ei)=nai in 27. Plato uses a(plou=n, as opposed to diplou=n, dia/foron, su/nqeton, peplegme/non, poiki/lon and the like, of that which is uniform, simple, true without any difference or qualifications: Bonitz in Hermes, II (1867), 307 ff.
30. mh/ moi: see on mh\ ou(/tws in 318B

31. to\ ei) bou/lei tou=to—e)le/gxesqai, cf. below, 333Cto
 ga\p lo/gon e)/gwge ma/lista e)ceta/zw, sumbai/nei me/ntoi i)/sws kai\ e)me\ to
 e)rwtw=nta kai\ to
 a)pokrino/menon e)ceta/zesqai. Here to/, as often, introduces a quotation.
32. to\ d' e)me/ te kai\ se\ tou=to le/gw: tou=to (cf. l. 31) belongs to the to\ d' e)me/ te kai\ se/ and not to le/gw in the usual sense of tou=to le/gw ‘I mean this’.

36. to\ ga\r leuko\n tw=| me/lani. Anaxagoras went so far as to
say that snow was black (because it is still water, though congealed): Ritter and Preller, § 128, n. b.
37. o(/ph|: an old emendation for o(\ mh/.
42. tau=ta: the parts of the face.

45. ka)
 pa/nu smikro
 e)/xh| to\ o(/moion. This (the MSS. reading) is successfully defended by Kroschel. The emphasis is on the first part of the sentence (‘it is not right to call what has some likeness like—any more than to call what has some unlikeness unlike—even if the likeness be very small’), to which accordingly ka)
 pa/nu smikro
 e)/xh| to\ o(/moion reverts: compare Socrates' reply, which says nothing of to\ a)no/moion, in the next sentence. The German editors (except Cron and Kroschel) either reject to\ o(/moion (Schanz, Sauppe, Bertram) or read to\ a)no/moion h)\ to\ o(/moion (Heindorf) or reject altogether the words ou)de\ ta\ a)no/moio/n ti e)/xonta a)no/moia (Kral).

div.head: CHAPTER XX
div.p: Without establishing more surely the identity of justice and holiness, Socrates now seeks to prove the identity of temperance and wisdom, and begins to discuss the relation between temperance and justice.

The proof that temperance and wisdom are the same is briefly as follows: a)frosu/nh is the opposite of sofi/a, and also of swfrosu/nh: but a thing can have but one opposite: therefore sofi/a and swfrosu/nh are identical. It is admitted at once that a)frosu/nh and sofi/a are opposites: the proof that a)frosu/nh is e)nanti/on swfrosu/nh| is of some length and (as well as the assertion that a thing can have but one opposite) assumes the identity of the contrary and contradictory. The usual sense of a)frosu/nh (intellectual folly) and the meaning natural from its derivation (as the opposite of swfrosu/nh) are also—as is natural to one who holds that vice is ignorance—identified, and the whole argument is unnecessarily spun out.
1. a)frosu/nhn ti kalei=s. See above on 330C

3. po/teron de\ o(/tan. Here begins the proof that swfrosu/nh is e)nanti/on a)frosu/nh|. (1) to\ o)rqw=s and w)feli/mws pra/ttein is swfronei=n,
and swfrosu/nh is that by which one swfronei=; (2) to\ mh\ o)rqw=s pra/ttein is a)fro/nws pra/ttein and ou) swfronei=n: from which it is inferred that a)fro/nws pra/ttein is the opposite of swfro/nws pra/ttein, or (as is worked out at inordinate length) that a)frosu/nh is the opposite of swfrosu/nh. In equating mh\ o)rqw=s with a)fro/nws pra/ttein in (2) Socrates again confounds contradictory and contrary: see on 331A

5. h)\ tou)nanti/on. So Stallbaum, after Heindorf's h)\ tou)nanti/on pra/ttein: the MSS. have h)\ ei) tou)nanti/on e)/pratton, which is faulty both because it in no way corresponds to the answer swfronei=n and because ei) with the imperfect is here unsuitable. In h)\ tou)nanti/on it will be observed that Socrates already allows no middle position between swfronei=n and its opposite: see above on l. 3.

17. fe/re dh/. From here to l. 24 Socrates tries to prove that a thing can have but one e)nanti/on. This is true only if we confine e)nanti/on to the meaning of ‘contradictorily opposite’ throughout, e.g. if we are always content merely to assert that the e)nanti/on of kalo/n is mh\ kalo/n: as soon as we say that its e)nanti/on is ai)sxro/n we have given to the thing two opposites (one of them multiform)—since mh\ kalo/n is not ai)sxro/n but may be anything in the whole world except kalo/n. This part of the argument is therefore also vitiated by neglecting the difference between contrary and contradictory terms.
24. a)nalogisw/meqa: of reckoning up and reflecting as in Rep. I. 330E X. 618C.
30-1. u(po\ swfrosu/nhs—u(po\ a)frosu/nhs. This has not been admitted in so many words, but with swfrosu/nh| and a)frosu/nh| for u(po\ swfrosu/nhs and u(po\ a)frosu/nhs: 332B l. II: cf. C, l. 16.
37. e)/mprosqen: 332A
41. to/ does not belong to e(/n but to the clause e(\n e(ni\ mo/non e)nanti/on ei)=nai: cf. to\ ei) bou/lei tou=to in 331C e)kei=non refers to ch. XVIII.

46. ou) pa/nu mousikw=s—sunarmo/ttousin. ‘In his lenem
agnosco Sophistae irrisionem, qui supra §43’ (326B ‘pa/nta to\n bi/on tou= a)nqrw/pou eu)ruqmi/as te kai\ eu)armosti/as dei=sqai dixisset’, Heindorf.

49. plei/w de\ mh/. B reads plei/osin, *t plei/osi: plei/w is a suggestion of Heindorf's, adopted by most editors. The nominatives e(\n mo/non in l. 48 and sofi/a and swfrosu/nh in 50 are strongly in favour of plei/w. If plei/osin is retained, it must be regarded as a blemish in Plato's style.

56. ta) loipa/. If dikaiosu/nh = o(sio/ths and swfrosu/nh = sofi/a it remains to identify either dikaiosu/nh or o(sio/ths with either swfrosu/nh or sofi/a in order to prove the identity of these four virtues. Socrates begins to prove that dikaiosu/nh = swfrosu/nh.

57. o(/ti a)dikei=: o(/ti (cf. below, 333D and Parm. 155E) is equivalent to kata\ tou=to o(/: cf. Rep. I. 340D e)pei\ au)ti/ka i)atro\n kalei=s su\ to\n e)camapta/nonta repi\ tou\s ka/mnontas kat' au)to\ tou=to o(\ e)camarta/nei; o(/ ti the relative and o(/ti the conjunction shade into one another here. There is much to be said for Cron's view that the words should be written alike: see on Apology, Appendix II, p. 123.

59. polloi/ ge/ fasin. In Rep. I. 348B ff., Thrasymachus asserts that a)diki/a is eu)bouli/a, a)reth/, kalo/n and i)sxuro/n: compare also Polus in Gorg. 469B ff. Notice that Protagoras' own opinion —that a)diki/a is not compatible with swfrosu/nh—makes for the identification of dikaiosu/nh and swfrosu/nh.

62. to
 tw=n pollw=n: on account of the tw=n here, Heindorf wished to insert oi( before polloi/ in l. 59, but such a view could hardly be said to be held by the majority: cf. Rep. I. 348E ei) ga lusitelei=n me
 th
 a)diki/an e)ti/qeso, kaki/an me/ntoi h)\ ai)sxpo
 au)to\ w(molo/geis ei)=nai w(/srep a)/lloi tine/s, ei)/xomen a)/n ti le/gein kata\ ta\ nomizo/mena le/gontes ktl. As Sauppe points out, the article tw=n refers only to the above-mentioned polloi/. With the situation cf. Rep. VII. 527E ff. sko/pei ou)=n au)to/qen pro\s pote/rous diale/gei: h)\ ou) rpo\s ou)dete/pous a)lla\ sautou= e(/neka to\ me/giston roiei= tou\s lo/gous, fqonoi=s mh
 ou)d' a)
 a)/llw? ei)/ ti/s ti du/naito a)p' au)tw=n o)/nasqai;
63. ei)/t' ou)=n—ei)/te: see on Apol. 34E.

div.head: CHAPTER XXI
div.p: Before Socrates has completed his proof that swfrosu/nh and dikaiosu/nh are identical, Protagoras takes occasion to deliver an irrelevant though carefully constructed harangue on a)gaqa/.

1. e)kallwpi/zeto. Cf. Phaedr. 236D pau=sai pro/s me kallwpizo/menos: sxedo\n ga\r e)/xw o(\ ei)pw\n a)nagka/sw se le/gein; so also trufa=n, cf. Euthyphr. 11 E e)peidh\ de/ moi dokei=s su\ trufa=n, au)to/s soi cumproqumh/somai, where see note.
5. e)/stw. Protagoras has already disclaimed this view in 333B
7. o(/ti a)dikou=sin: Hirschig suggested o(/ ti a)dikou=sin, but see on 333B Schanz rejects the words, but without sufficient reason.

8. eu)= pra/ttousin a)dikou=ntes. eu)= is here primarily of success, and kakw=s of failure, but the collocation of eu)= pra/ttein with a)dikei=n is intended to suggest that the view which Protagoras is defending is a paradox. Plato frequently makes use of the double sense (as we should call it; but see on Euthyphr, 3A) of eu)= pra/ttein, eu)= zh=n and the like, to imply that the virtuous life is the happy one: e.g. Alcib. I, 116B ff.; Rep. I. 353E ff.; Charm. 172A, 173D; cf. Euthyd. 281C.
9. le/geis ou)=n a)gaqa/. Socrates proceeds to elucidate the definition of eu)= in eu)= pra/ttein.

11. w)fe/lima toi=s a)nqrw/pois: Xen. Mem. IV. 6. 8 a)/llo d' a)/n ti fai/hs a)gaqo\n ei)=nai h)\ to\ w)fe/limon; ou)k e)/gwg', e)/fh. to\ a)/pa w)fe/limon a)gaqo/n e)stin o(/tw| a)\n w)fe/limon h)=|; dokei= moi, e)/fh. Plato, Rep. II. 379B ti/ de/; w)fe/limon to\ a)gaqo/n; nai/.

14. a)gwnia=n kai\ parateta/xqai. The martial metaphor in the desiderative a)gwnia=n is carried on by parateta/xqai, which is the MSS. reading, and means literally ‘to be set in array’, cf. Thuc. IV. 43. 3 ou(=toi ga\r paratetagme/noi h)=san e)/sxatoi. For the metaphorical use cf. Rep. III. 399B e)n pa=si tou/tois paratetagme/nws kai\ karterou/ntws a)munoume/nou th\n tu/xhn. The whole clause describes the outward demeanour of Protagoras, which causes Socrates to fear an imminent personal conflict. Kock's parateta/sqai, accepted by Schanz, does not suit, since parateta/sqai
means ‘to be tired, worn out’, e.g. Euthyd. 303B kai\ gelw=nte kai\ krotou=nte . . . o)li/gou pareta/qhsan, cf. Ar. Clouds, 213. It is noteworthy that suntetagme/nws and suntetame/nws are frequently found as variants in Platonic MSS.

19. ou)damw=s, e)/fh. The argument is here broken off, and not (in its present form) again resumed. If Socrates had continued, Protagoras would doubtless have asserted that what is w)fe/limon for man is for him a)gaqo/n. The argument has therefore been: swfronei=n, it is said, is a)dikei=n. But swfronei=n = eu)= fronei=n = eu)= bouleu/esqai if (but only if) eu)= pra/ttein (i.e. w)fe/lima pra/ttein) accompanies eu)bouli/a. In other words w)fe/lima pra/ttein = a)dikei=n is the stage which we have reached—a thesis which it is the object of the Republic and of a large part of the Gorgias to refute.

polla\ oi)=d' a(/. The speech which follows may be from some work by Protagoras (so recently Zeller in the Archiv für Geschichte der Philosophie, V, 2, 177), perhaps his peri\ a)retw=n, mentioned by Diog. Laert. IX. 8. 55 (since a)reth/ is a general word for excellence). Zeller points out that just as the notion ‘true’ was conceived by Protagoras (in his pa/ntwn me/tron a)/nqrwpos) as relative, so here the notion ‘good’ is represented as relative and varying with that to which it is relative.

20. a)nqrw/pois me
—w)fe/lima: a)nqrw/pois me/n has no antithesis expressed: were the antitheses expressed in full, the sentence would be very cumbrous, running somewhat as follows: e)/gwge polla\ oi)=d' a(\ a)nqrw/pois me
 <ta\ me
> a)nwfelh= e)sti/, kai\ siti/a—mupi/a, <toi=s de\a)/llois zw/|ois kai\ futoi=s w)fe/lima>, ta\ de/ ge w)fe/lima <toi=s a)nqrw/pois, toi=s de\ a)/llois a)nwfelh=>. For me/n without a balancing clause see on to\ me
 katagelasqh=nai in Euthyphr. 3C, and on 330Aabove for ta\ de/ without a preceding ta\ me/n. a)nwfelh= is ‘hurtful’, as frequently: see above on oi(=on mh\ o(/sion in 331A With Protagoras' classification of w)fe/lima—a)nwfelh=—ou)de/tera cf. Gorg. 467E a)=r' ou)=n e)/stin ti tw=n o)/ntwn, o(\ ou)xi\ h)/toi a)gaqo/n g' e)sti
 h)\ kako
 h)\ metacu\ tou/twn ou)/te a)gaqo
 ou)/te kako/n (where see Thompson's note) and below, 351D

23. ou)deni/: Schanz follows Naber in reading ou)de/si against the MSS. both here and in Euthyd. 302C. The plural would be more appropriate here, but what is denied of all individuals is
denied of the species, and the dative plural of ou)dei/s seems to lack authority.

27. ei) d' e)qe/lois—pa/nta a)po/llusin. Heindorf suggests ei) d' e)qe/leis—the indicative being generally used in this phrase, e.g. Alcib. I, 122B ei) d' au)= e)qe/leis ei)s plou/tous a)poble/yai ktl., ai)sxunqei/hs a)\n e)pi\ sautw=|—but Goodwin, M.T. p. 188, § 500, quotes a precisely similar example from Thuc. II. 39. 5 kai/toi ei) p(aqumi/a| ma=llon h)\ ro/nwn mele/th|—e)qe/loimen kinduneu/ein, repigi/gnetai h(mi=n ktl. In both examples the present in the apodosis contains a reference to the future.

29. futoi=s—pa/gkakon. Theophr. Hist. Plant. IV. 16. 5 pole/mion ga\r dh\ kai\ tou=to (sc. to\ e)/laion) pa=si: kai\ e)/laion e)pixe/ousi toi=s u(rolei/mmasi tw=n p(izw=n: i)sxu/ei de\ ma=llon to\ e)/laion e)n toi=s ne/ois kai\ a)/rti fuome/nois: a)sqene/stera ga/r ktl.
tai=s qrici\n—a)nqrw/pou. Arist. peri\ zw/|wn gene/sews V. 5. 785a. 30 ff. says that a mixture of oil and water is a remedy against grey hairs.
33. e)ntau=qa, i.e. e)n tw=| a)nqrw/pw|.
35. tau)to/n. This form, not tau)to/, of the neuter of o( au)to/s is almost regular in Plato: see on 314B
37. me/llei, sc. o( a)sqenw=n: see on 319D

38. o(/son mo/non ‘just enough to’. Cf. Rep. III. 416E de/xesqai misqo
 th=s fulakh=s tosou=ton, o(/son mh/te repiei=nai au)toi=s. . .mh/te e)ndei=n, Theaet. 161B e)gw\ de\ ou)de
 e)pi/stamai ple/on plh
 braxe/os, o(/son lo/gon par' e(te/rou sofou= labei=n kai\ a)pode/casqai metri/ws.

th\n dusxe/reian—o)/yois. The nausea is of course that felt by a sick person at the smell of food: so far there is therefore no reason for holding r(inw=n to be corrupt and reading xumw=n (as Kroschel formerly read), still less eu)krinw=n with Bergk. But it is not clear how oil could thus prevent nausea, nor does there seem to be any parallel among the ancients to such a statement. It is known that the ancients (like many modern peoples) used oil in cooking much as we use butter (see Blümner's Privataltherthümer, p. 228), but the present passage seems rather to point to the use of some kind of fragrant oil sprinkled on the food after it was cooked. The Greeks were at all events not unfamiliar with the use of scents in banqueting: see Xen. Symp.
II. 2 ff. Kroschel thinks Plato is making fun of Protagoras by putting into his mouth the word ‘r(inw=n pro pikrw=n vel xumw=n’, but this view will hardly command assent.

div.head: CHAPTER XXII
div.p: This and the next three chapters form a kind of interlude. In this chapter Socrates, protesting against Protagoras' long replies, remembers an engagement and is about to go, and Callias beseeches him to stay.
9. kai\ braxute/ras poi/ei. Hirschig would reject the words, but they explain the metaphor in su/ntemne: see on 314Akubeu/h|s te kai\ kinduneu/h|s.
13. o(/sa e)moi\ dokei=. Cf. Gorg. 461D ti/ de/; ou)k e)ce/stai moi le/gein o(po/sa a)\n bou/lwmai;

17. kai\ au)= braxe/a. Sauppe cites Gorg. 449C kai\ ga\r au)= kai\ tou=to e(/n e)stin w(=n fhmi/, mhde/na a)\n e)n bpaxute/pois e)mou= ta\ au)ta\ ei)rei=n. *tou/tou mh\n dei=, w)= *gopgi/a: kai/ moi e)ri/deicin au)tou= tou/tou roi/hsai, th=s braxulogi/as, makrologi/as de\ ei)sau=qis; cf. also Gorg. 461D and Phaedr. 267B.

22. w(s o( a)ntile/gwn—ou(/tw dielego/mhn. Asyndeton is frequent in such sentences: cf. Rep. II. 359B (cited by Heindorf) ei) toio/nde poih/saimen th=| dianoi/a|, do/ntes e)cousi/an—ei)=t' e)pakolouqh/saimen ktl. See on 311E

24. e)ge/neto *prwtago/rou o)/noma. With e)ge/neto o)/noma (for which Kroschel reads e)le/geto o)/noma) cf. Apol. 20D ti/ pot' e)/stin tou=to o(\ e)moi\ pepoi/hke to/ te o)/noma kai\ th
