 diabolh/n: gi/gnesqai is the usual passive to poiei=n. With the sentence generally cf. Euthyphr. 4E-5A, where Euthyphro says ou)de
 ga a)/n mou o)/felos ei)/h, w)= *sw/kpates, ou)de/ tw| a)
 diafe/poi *eu)qu/fpwn tw=n rollw=n a)nqpw/rwn, ei) mh\ ktl.: see note in loc. for more parallels.
25. ou)k h)/resen—kai\—ou)k e)qelh/soi. The combination of indicative and optative in the same sentence in indirect speech is fairly common: Goodwin, M.T. p. 261, § 670.
28. h(ghsa/menos. Heindorf conjectures h(ghsa/menos ou)=n, but ou)=n may be dispensed with after a short parenthesis.

36. ta\ makra\ tau=ta a)du/natos. Meno, 94B i)/na de\ mh\ o)li/gous oi)/h? kai\ tou\s faulota/tous *)aqhnai/wn a)duna/tous gegone/nai tou=to to\ pra=gma; Rep. VI. 478A e)f' e(te/rw| a)/ra e(/tero/n ti duname/nh e(kate/ra au)tw=n pe/fuken.

38. i(/na sunousi/a e)gi/gneto. For this construction see note on Crito, 44D ei) ga\r w)/felon—oi(=oi/ t' ei)=nai—i)/na oi(=oi/ t' h)=san. A secondary tense of the indicative is found with i)/na and o(/pws (without a)/n) in final clauses dependent on a wish which can no longer be fulfilled, or on the apodosis to an impossible protasis: Goodwin, M.T. p. 120, § 333. The idiom is frequent in Plato and sometimes corrupted by scribes, e.g. Meno, 89B h(mei=s a)\n paralabo/ntes—e)fula/ttomen—i(/na mhdei\s au)tou\s die/fqeiren, a)ll' e)peidh\ a)fi/kointo ei)s th\n h(liki/an, xrh/simoi gi/gnointo tai=s po/lesin—where perhaps we should read a)fi/konto and e)gi/gnonto. See Cobet's Variae Lectiones, pp. 102, 359.

45. tri/bwnos. The ordinary clothing of an Athenian consisted of a xitw/n, or shirt, with a i(ma/tion or short mantle worn above it. The tri/bwn was a short cloak of coarse material worn by the Spartans and sometimes by the Laconisers in other states to take the place of both xitw/n and i(ma/tion. It was the ordinary garment of Socrates (Symp. 219B), and was afterwards much affected by the more ascetic philosophers, such as the Cynics (Diog. Laert. VI. I. 13). Its use was supposed to be a mark of sturdy simplicity and austerity of manners.

48. ou)d' a)\n e(no/s. The two parts of ou)dei/s are sometimes separated by a)/n or a preposition, often with the effect (as here) of increasing the emphasis by making ou)de/ = ne—quidem, cf. below 343Dou)de\ pro\s e)/na lo/gon.

51. w)= pai= *(ipponi/kou: see on 328Dabove. With a)ei\ me
— a)ta/r Sauppe compares Rep. II. 367E kai\ e)gw\ a)kou/sas a)ei\ me
 dh\ th
 fu/sin tou= te *glau/kwnos kai\ tou= *(adeima/ntou h)ga/mhn, a)ta\p ou)=n kai\ to/te pa/nu ge h(/sqhn.

52. filosofi/an. The original meaning of the word filosofi/a
was ‘love of knowledge for its own sake’, no particular kind of knowledge being specified. The verb filosofei=n is first found in Hdt. I. 30 w(s filosofe/wn gh=n pollh\n qewri/hs ei(/neken e)pelh/luqas. In the present passage (as in Thuc. II. 40 filosofou=men a)/neu malaki/as) the word retains its original wider meaning, viz, ‘love of knowledge’ in general; but side by side with this in Plato it has the more restricted meaning of ‘Philosophy’, e.g. Rep. VI. 496A pa/nsmikron dh/ ti. . .lei/petai tw=n kat' a)ci/an o(milou/ntwn filosofi/a|. The wider meaning is also found in Aristotle, where he calls Theology the ‘Highest Study’ (prw/th filosofi/a), and elsewhere.

55. *kri/swni. Criso of Himera, a famous stadiodro/mos, won three times at Olympia, viz. Olymp. 83, 84 and 85 (448, 444 and 440 B.C.). His chastity during his prime as an athlete is mentioned in Laws, VIII. 840A. dromei= a)kma/zonti is rejected by some editors, but dromei= should be taken with *(imerai/w| and a)kma/zonti with e(/pesqai: ‘to keep up with Criso, the runner of Himera, when he was in his prime’—presumably at the assumed date of this dialogue he was past his a)kmh/.
56. dolixodro/mwn: dolixodro/moi ei)si\n oi( to\n do/lixon tre/xontes, says the scholiast: see on 329A
h(merodro/mwn. Heindorf quotes Livy, XXXI. 24. 4 ‘Hemerodromos vocant Graeci ingens die uno cursu emetientes spatium.’ Such was Phidippides; see Hdt. VI. 105 h(merodro/mhn te kai\ tou=to meletw=nta.

57. diaqei=n te kai\ e(/pesqai. dia- in compounds frequently denotes competition: for diaqei=n cf. Theaet. 148C ei)=ta diaqe/wn tou= a)kma/zontos kai\ taxi/stou h(tth/qhs. As the emphasis is on e(/pesqai (‘keep up with’), diaqei=n te kai\ e(/pesqai is equivalent to diaqe/onta e(/pesqai: cf. note on 317Ce)ndei/casqai kai\ kallwpi/sasqai, where kai\ kallwpi/sasqai is (so to speak) enclitic as diaqei=n te kai/ is proclitic (cf. the English ‘Some—must be talked over by the hour before they could reach the humblest decision, which they only left the office to return again (ten minutes later) and rescind’).

61. sugkaqei=nai: intransitive as in Rep. VIII. 563A oi( de\ ge/rontes cugkaqie/ntes toi=s ne/ois: so pare/xw for pare/xw e)mauto/n
below, 348Ae(/toimo/s ei)mi/ soi pare/xein a)pokrino/menos: cf. also e)kei=noi/ te a)pe/kruyan (sc. e(autou/s) Thuc. V. 65. 5. The omission of the reflexive pronoun is a well-recognised way of making transitive verbs into intransitive.

66. xwri/s. Soph. O.C. 808 xwri\s to/ t' ei)pei=n polla\ kai\ ta\ kai/ria. ‘In talibus locis di/xa, xwri/s etc. non, ut vulgo, seiunctionem et separationem, sed diversitatem et oppositionem significant’ (Kroschel). The usage is frequent in Plato. dhmhgorei=n is contionari—platform oratory.

68. o(ra=|s. Almost like our colloquial ‘don't you know’ (when used parenthetically and without interrogative force): the a)lla/ belongs in strict logic to di/kaia dokei= le/gein. Heindorf quotes parallels from Aristophanes, e.g. Peace, 330-1 ou)ka)\n o)rxhsai/meq', ei)/per w)felh/saime/n ti/ se. a)ll' o(ra=t', ou)/pw pe/pausqe. Where o(ra=|s or o(ra=te stand in this way as the first word of a sentence, editors generally regard the usage as interrogative, e.g. Eur. Orest. 581 o(ra=|s; *)odusse/ws a)/loxon ou) kate/ktane.

70. kai\ su/. So the original hand in T: B has kai/ soi. If we read kai\ soi/, the construction is a)ciw=n au(tw=| te e)cei=nai diale/gesqai o(/pws bou/letai kai\ soi\ e)cei=nai ktl., but Protagoras has nowhere asked that Socrates should be permitted to converse as he likes: quite the contrary. With su/ the construction is kai\ su\ di/kaia dokei=s le/gein a)ciw=n diale/gesqai o(/pws a)\n ktl., i.e. and your demand that Protagoras should converse as you wish likewise seems fair. Protagoras asked to be allowed to use his own style in 335A Socrates requested that Protagoras should converse as Socrates wished in 334D 335C 335E Alcibiades' defence of Socrates in the next chapter seems also to imply the reading su/ here. The only objection to this view lies in the position of te after au(tw=|: we should expect it to follow *prwtago/ras. te is however frequently misplaced (see above on 316D. soi/ can only be retained if we either (1) take kai\ soi/ as altogether independent of a)ciw=n— which is barely possible, or (2) regard Plato as guilty of inaccurate writing.

div.head: CHAPTER XXIII
div.p: Alcibiades defends Socrates, and together with Critias and Prodicus hopes that the conversation will be continued.

1. ou) kalw=s le/geis, w)= *kalli/a. The jingle is intentional:
Handsome is that handsome says. Plato loves to play upon the names of his interlocutors (w)= lw=?ste *pw=le in Gorg. 467B): see Riddell's Digest of Idioms, § 323, and cf. the Editor's notes on Euthyphr. 2E, 4E, 5C.
5. lo/gon te dou=nai kai\ de/casqai. We should expect te to follow dou=nai: see on 316D

10. e)kkrou/wn. ‘Vox ducta a pugilatu, cuius proprium krou/ein de rep. IV. p. 422B ou)d' ei) e)cei/h—u(pofeu/gonti (tw=| pu/kth|) to\n pro/teron ai)ei\ prosfero/menon a)nastre/fonta krou/ein etc.’ Heindorf. The simple verb is used metaphorically in Theaet. 154E of beating arguments with arguments, h)/dh a)\n—sunelqo/ntes sofistikw=s ei)s ma/xhn toiau/thn a)llh/lwn tou\s lo/gous toi=s lo/gois e)krou/omen, and the compound in Phaedr. 228E e)kke/krouka/s me e)lpi/dos. Here the idea is of beating off, staving off by force, i.e. here by makrhgori/a: e)kkrou/ein di/khn is used by Demosthenes of staving off a trial by sukofanti/a and the like.

14. ou)x o(/ti: ‘not but what’. The idiom (as if ou) le/gw o(/ti, omitto quod) is tolerably common in Plato, e.g. Gorg. 450E ou)x o(/ti tw=| r(h/mati ou(/tws ei)=pes, Theaet. 157B to\ d' ei)=nai pantaxo/qen e)cairete/on, ou)x o(/ti h(mei=s—h)nagka/smeqa—xrh=sqai au)tw=|.
16. xrh\ ga\r ktl.: said apologetically.

20. filo/nikos. The MSS. read filo/neikos and presently sumfiloneikei=n. It is however clear that the word comes from filo- and ni/kh, not from filo- and nei=kos (in which case the form would be filoneikh/s: compare filokerdh/s, filokudh/s, but filo/timos, filo/docos, filo/qhros and the like). Schanz has found only two traces of the original spelling with iota in Plato's MSS. (A, B, T): viz. in Laws, XI. 935B, where Paris A has a)ristei/wn pe/ri filonikh/sh|, and Alcib. I, 122C, where filoniki/an appears as a correction for filoneiki/an in T. We might in consequence be tempted to suppose that Plato himself wrote filo/neikos through the influence of a false etymology, were it not that the derivation from ni/kh alone suits the meaning, and that in more than one passage he shows himself conscious of the connection of the word with ni/kh, notably in Rep. IX. 586C ti/ de/; peri\ to\ qumoeide\s
ou)x e(/tera toiau=ta a)na/gkh gi/gnesqai, o(\s a)\n au)to\ tou=to diapra/tthtai h)\ fqo/nw| dia\ filotimi/an h)\ bi/a| dia\ filoniki/an (filoneiki/an *a) h)\ qumw=| dia\ duskoli/an, rlhsmonh\n timh=s te kai\ ni/khs kai\ qumou= diw/kwn a)/neu logismou= te kai\ nou=; Cf. also ibid. 581A-B. The orthography of this word is an old subject of dispute (see Stallbaum on Rep. VIII. 545A); Schanz (Preface to vol. VI, p. X) declares himself, after a full discussion, for filo/nikos.

24. o( *pro/dikos—e)/fh. Prodicus contrives to make his remarks an e)pi/deicis on o)rqo/ths o)noma/twn, which was his leading subject of instruction: see Euthyd. 277E and cf. above on 314C The distinctions drawn by Prodicus are on the whole sound if somewhat wiredrawn and pedantic. The carefully balanced style of the speech finds a parallel in the story of Heracles in Xen. Mem. II. I. 21 ff.: cf. especially §§ 31-3.

26. koinou\s—a)kroata/s—i)/sous. koino/s and i)/sos are found as epithets of a)kroath/s in the orators: e.g. Dem. De Cor. 7 ta\ tou= le/gontos u(ste/pou di/kaia eu)noi+kw=s rposde/cetai kai\ rapasxw
 e(auto
 i)/son kai\ koino
 a)mfote/pois a)kpoath
 ou(/tw th
 dia/gnwsin poih/setai peri\ pa/ntwn, and Andoc. in Alcib. § 7 de/omai d' u(mw=n, tw=n lo/gwn i)/sous kai\ koinou\s h(mi=n e)pista/tas gene/sqai (Heindorf).

29. tw=| me\n sofwte/rw| ple/on ktl. In other words i)so/ths gewmetrikh/ and not i)so/ths a)riqmhtikh/ should be observed by the audience (Gorg. 508A): the regard paid to the speakers should be in proportion to their merit.

33. a)mfisbhtei=n—e)ri/zein. Cicero's translation of this sentence is preserved by Priscian (Nobbe's Cicero, p. 1313): ‘Nunc a vobis, a Protagora et Socrate (leg. o Protagora et Socrates), postulo, ut de isto concedatis alter alteri, et inter vos de huiuscemodi rebus controversemini, non concertetis.’
38. eu)dokimoi=te kai\ ou)k e)painoi=sqe. Heindorf suggests that a)ll' ou)k should be written for kai\ ou)k, or kai/ omitted; but kai/ is occasionally used in this way.

39. a)/neu a)pa/ths is opposed to para\ do/can yeudome/nwn: eu)dokimei=n implies that he with whom one eu)dokimei= is sincere. e)n lo/gw| as opposed to para\ tai=s yuxai=s suggests Shak. ‘Mouthhonour, breath, which the poor heart would fain deny, but dare not’.

42. eu)frai/nesqai is connected by Prodicus with fro/nhsis (fronh/sews metalamba/nonta): for a fantastic derivation of the kindred eu)frosu/nh see Crat. 419D panti\ ga dh=lon o(/ti a)po\ tou= eu)= toi=s rpa/gmasi th
 yuxh
 cumfe/pesqai tou=to e)/labe to\ o)/noma, eu)ferosu/nhn, to/ ge di/kaion: o(/mws de\ au)to\ kalou=men eu)frosu/nhn. Cf. Ar. Top. II. 6, p. 112b. 22 *pro/dikos dih|rei=to ta\s h(dona\s ei)s xara
 kai\ te/ryin kai\ eu)frosu/nhn. The Greek usage of this word hardly conformed to the rule laid down by Prodicus.
44. au)th=| th=| dianoi/a|: au)th=? is ‘by itself’, i.e. without the body, as au)tw=| in au)tw=| tw=| sw/mati is without the mind. h(du/ is introduced to give the derivation of h(/desqai.

div.head: CHAPTER XXIV
div.p: Hippias, anxious for a compromise, proposes the selection of an umpire in a speech marked by his characteristic doctrines and style.

If we may judge from this speech, Hippias must have been devoted to metaphor: e.g. tu/rannos, prutanei=on in D, w(/sper u(po\ diaithtw=n in E, and in 338Ae)fei=nai kai\ xala/sai ta\s h(ni/as, ka/lwn e)ktei/nanta ou)pi/a| e)fe/nta, re/lagos lo/gwn, a)rokpu/yanta gh=n, me/son ti temei=n, r(abdou=xon and pru/tanin. Zeller (Archiv für Geschichte der Philosophie, V, 2, 175) thinks that the opening part of the speech may have come from some book of which Hippias was himself the author.
2. a)pede/canto means simply ‘assented’: cf. Theaet. 162E.
4. h(ma=s is Heindorf's correction for u(ma=s; ‘uti mox h(ma=s ou)=n ai)sxro/n etc., neque video cur se a ceteris h. l. segreget Hippias’.

5. fu/sei ou) no/mw|. The opposition between fu/sis and no/mos frequently appears attributed to different sophists or their representatives in the Platonic dialogues: the historical Hippias was a leading champion of fu/sis (see Introduction p. XX). Usually, however, no/mos is represented as a convention binding men together into friendship and fu/sis (whose teaching is that might is right) as responsible for the enmity of man to man in the savage state: e.g. Rep. II. 358D ff., Gorg. 482D ff. From the natural principle of ‘Like to like’ is here deduced something like the Stoic doctrine of the kinship between wise men.

to\ ga\r o(moi=on tw=| o(moi/w|: Gorg. 510B fi/los moi dokei= e(/kastos e(ka/stw| ei)=nai w(s oi(=o/n te ma/lista, o(/nrep oi( ralaioi/ te kai\ sofoi\ le/gousin, o( o(moi=os tw=? o(moi/w|; Laws, IV. 716C. The proverb appears in the most various forms in Greek literature from Homer (Od. XVII. 218 w(s ai)ei\ to\n o(moi=on a)/gei qeo\s w(s to\n o(moi=on) downwards. For more examples of its use in Plato see Stallbaum on Gorg. loc. cit.
7. tu/rannos—bia/zetai. Hippias has in view the lines of Pindar quoted in Gorg. 484B no/mos o( pa/ntwn basileu\s qnatw=n te kai\ a)qana/twn—a)/ge. dikaiw=n to\ biaio/taton u(perta/ta| xeiri\ ktl.

11. prutanei=on th=s sofi/as. The prytaneum (like the temple of Vesta at Rome) was the religious centre of a Greek po/lis. It was sacred to *(esti/a, in whose honour fire was always kept burning, and contained what was called the ‘Common Hearth’ of the city: see Frazer in Journal of Philology, XIV, 145-72. The editors refer to Athenaeus, v. 187D th
 *)aqhnai/wn ro/lin, to\ th=s *(ella/dos mousei=on, h(
 o( me
 *ri/ndapos *(ella/dos e)/peisma e)/fh, *qoukudi/dhs d' e)n tw=| ei)s *eu)piri/dhn e)rigpa/mmati *(ella/dos *(ella/da, o( de\ *pu/qios e(sti/an kai\ prutanei=on tw=n *(ellh/nwn.

16. sumbh=nai—w(/sper u(po\ diaithtw=n h(mw=n sumbibazo/ntwn. sumbai/nw forms a passive to sumbiba/zw as pa/sxein to poiei=n, whence u(po/: see note on Apol. 17A. sumbiba/zw is regular in the sense of bringing together, effecting an arrangement between: cf. (with Sauppe) Thuc. II. 29. 6 cunebi/base de\ kai\ to\n *perdi/kkan toi=s *)aqhnai/ois. Note that h(mw=n has no preposition with it—this is frequent (but not universal) in similes where w(/sper and a preposition precede the object compared, and the effect is almost to make the simile an identification: if on the other hand the object compared comes first, the preposition must be expressed twice. Cf. Theaet. 170A w(/sper pro\s qeou\s e)/xein tou\s e)n e(ka/stois a)/rxontas (which might have been pro\s tou\s e)n e(ka/stois a)/rxontas w(/sper pro\s qeou\s e)/xein) and see notes on Crito, 46C, Euthyphr. 2C.
19. li/an: with zhtei=n: kata\ braxu/ as in Gorg. 449B a)ll' e)qe/lhson kata\ braxu\ to\ e)rwtw/menon a)pokri/nesqai.
20. e)fei=nai kai\ xala/sai ta\s h(ni/as toi=s lo/gois. For the metaphor Kroschel compares Laws, III. 701C kaqa/per a)xa/linon kekthme/non to\ sto/ma, bi/a| u(po\ tou= lo/gou fero/menon ktl.

22. h(mi=n: so most editions: BT have u(mi=n, which can hardly be right, as Hippias is at this moment addressing Socrates alone. ‘Pro u(mi=n dici potuit soi/, sed u(min recte explicari nequit’ (Kroschel).

23. pa/nta ka/lwn e)ktei/nanta. paroimi/a e)pi\ tw=n pa/sh| proqumi/a| xrwme/nwn, says a scholiast (quoted by Sauppe). This nautical metaphor means to stretch out every reefing rope and so set all sail: ka/lws does not refer to the sheet, which is pou/s. kinei=n, sei/ein, e)cie/nai, e)fie/nai, e)klu/ein are also found with ka/lwn in much the same sense.

ou)ri/a| e)fe/nta: see on sugkaqei=nai 336A For the asyndeton before these words Heindorf compares Euthyphr. 4C sundh/sas tou\s ro/das kai\ ta\s xei=pas au)tou=, katabalw\n ei)s ta/fpon tina/, re/mrei deu=ro a)/ndra ktl.

24. pe/lagos tw=n lo/gwn. Sauppe aptly refers to Symp. 210D e)pi\ to\ polu\ pe/lagos tetramme/nos tou= kalou=. Similar metaphors abound in Plato: e.g. Euthyd. 293A sw=sai h(ma=s—e)k th=s trikumi/as tou= lo/gou, Rep. V. 472A i)/sws ga\r ou)k oi)=sqa o(/ti mo/gis moi tw\ du/o ku/mate e)kfugo/nti nu=n to\ me/giston kai\ xalerw/taton th=s trikumi/as e)pa/geis ktl.

a)pokru/yanta: like Virgil's ‘protinus aerias Phaeacum abscondimus arces’ (Aen. III. 291): cf. the use of katadu/w in Callimachus, Epigr. 2 h(/lion e)n le/sxh| katedu/samen and Virgil's imitation ‘saepe ego longos Cantando puerum memini me condere soles’ (Ecl. IX. 51).

25. me/son ti—temei=n. te/mnein o(do/n like secare viam is a natural metaphor. Cf. Pindar, Isthm. VI. 22 muri/ai d' e)/rgwn kalw=n te/tmhnq' e(kato/mpedoi e)n sxerw=| ke/leuqoi, Pl. Laws, VII. 803E to\ me\n tw=n tu/pwn ei)/rhtai kai\ kaqa/per o(doi\ te/tmhntai kaq' a(\s i)te/on ktl. Here me/son ti temei=n = me/shn tina\ o(do\n temei=n.

w(\s ou)=n poih/sate kai\ pei/qesqe. w(/s (so B: T has w(s) is best understood as for ou(/tws—a rare usage, except after a preceding w(s or w(/sper as in 326D but it is found in Thuc. III. 37. 5 (with ou)=n and a form of poiei=n as here) w(\s ou)=n xrh\ kai\ h(ma=s poiou=ntas— parainei=n. For poih/sate the MSS. read poih/sete, which is very harsh before pei/qesqe, and is probably a mistake for poih/sate, due to the influence of the common construction of o(/pws with 2nd person fut. ind. It is, however, possible that this use of the
future as well as the use of w(/s for ou(/tws was characteristic of Hippias' style.

26. r(abdou=xon—pru/tanin. r(abdou=xos, e)pista/ths and brabeuth/s are said of umpires or presidents at games: r(abdou/xous ei)=pe tou\s krita\s tou= a)gw=nos, says the schol. on Ar. Peace, 733; for e)pista/ths cf. Laws, XII. 949A gumnikw=n te kai\ i(ppikw=n a)/qlwn e)pista/tas kai\ brabe/as. pru/tanis is an old word with lofty associations for ruler or prince. Cron thinks Hippias made this proposal with a view to being chosen President himself; he was probably still sitting on his qro/nos, cf. 315B 317D
27. to\ me/trion mh=kos: Phaedr. 267B au)to\s (sc. o( *pro/dikos) eu(rhke/nai e)/fh w(=n dei= lo/gwn te/xnhn: dei=n de\ ou)/te makrw=n ou)/te braxe/wn, a)lla\ metri/wn.

div.head: CHAPTER XXV
div.p: Socrates protests against appointing an umpire, and in order that the conversation may go on is willing that Protagoras should become the interrogator. The others assent, Protagoras reluctantly.

2. e)me/ ge. The MSS. read te not ge; ge is due to Heindorf. The position of te is usually explained as due to displacement (see on 316D, e.g. by Kroschel ‘nam haec dicit Socrates; omnes laudabant meque et Callias retinebat et (omnes) orabant ut praesidem deligerem’: but *kalli/as can hardly be coupled in this way with an unexpressed pa/ntes. If te is right it must be taken (with Turner) as coupling the whole clause e)me\ o( *kalli/as ou)k e)/fh a)fh/sein with kai\ e(le/sqai e)de/onto e)pista/thn: this is possible, but strikes us as harsh.
8. a)lla\ dh/ like at enim introduces a possible objection: see on Crito, 54A. The fuller form of the comparative (belti/ona and the like) is less common in Plato than the contracted.

10. w(/ste. Heindorf cites (inter alia) Phaedr. 269D to\ me
 du/nasqai, w)= *fai=dre, w(/ste a)gwnisth
 te/leon gene/sqai. The insertion of w(/ste with the usual infinitive after a)du/naton increases the emphasis of a)du/naton by making it appear more than a mere auxiliary notion. Badham's conjecture a)du/naton o)
 u(mi=n i)/ste deserves mention for its ingenuity. For *prwtago/rou see above, note on 318D

13. to/ g' e)mo
 ou)de
 diafe/rei. Gorg. 458D to/ g' e)mo
 ou)de
 kwlu/ei. to/ g' e)mo/n is frequent in Plato for quantum ad me attinet.
16. ei) mh\ bou/letai. For the asyndeton see above on 330A
27. pa/nu me\n ou)k h)/qelen: ou)k h)/qelen is virtually one word: ‘was very reluctant’. The phrase is quite different from ou) pa/nu: see on ou) pa/nu ti in 321Babove.

div.head: CHAPTER XXVI
div.p: Here begins an episode (lasting down to the end of ch. XXXII), in which Protagoras cross-examines Socrates upon a poem of Simonides. For the bearing of this episode on the general subject of the dialogue see Introduction, pp. xxiii ff.: and for the different restorations of the poem Appendix I.

3. peri\ e)pw=n deino\n ei)=nai. e)pw=n is ‘verses’. As education in poetry formed part of the usual curriculum at Athens, it was natural for the Sophists to pose as poetical critics, and Sauppe gives a number of references to show that they did so: it will suffice to quote Isocrates, Panath. 18 a)panth/santes ga/r tine/s moi tw=n e)rithdei/wn e)/legon, w(s e)n tw=| *lukei/w| sugkaqezo/menoi tpei=s h)\ te/ttapes tw=n a)gelai/wn sofistw=n kai\ ra/nta fasko/ntwn ei)de/nai— diale/gointo repi/ te tw=n a)/llwn roihtw=n kai\ th=s *(hsio/dou kai\ th=s *(omh/rou poih/sews ktl.: cf. below 347A where Hippias says he has a speech ready on the poem, and Hipp. Minor, 363Cff. kai\ a)/lla rolla\ kai\ rantodara\ h(mi=n e)ride/deiktai kai\ repi\ roihtw=n te a)/llwn kai\ peri\ *(omh/rou. Protagoras appears as a critic of poetry in Ar. Poet. 19, p. 1456b. 15 ff. (where he censures Homer o(/ti eu)/xesqai oi)o/menos e)pita/ttei ei)pw\n ‘mh=nin a)/eide qea/’) and in Soph. El. 14, p. 173b. 19 ff. The popularity of such discussions as the present may be inferred from the well-known scene between Euripides and Aeschylus in the Frogs, 1119 ff.

8. nu=n dialego/meqa: so B and T: the editors mostly read nu=n dh\ (nundh\) dielego/meqa. nu=n does not mean ‘at this present moment’, but simply ‘now’, ‘on the present occasion’, = e)n th=| nu=n sunousi/a|: translate ‘about the same subject as you and I are now discussing’, i.e. about the subject of our present discussion. A discussion which has never been finished (see on 334A
and is to be resumed (cf. 338Ee)peida\n i(kanw=s e)rwth/sh|, pa/lin dw/sein lo/gon, and 338D ought not to be spoken of as past. We have in fact in nu=n dialego/meqa an indication that the subject of the dialogue is the same throughout: see Introduction pp. xvii ff. nu=n in kai\ dh\ kai\ nu=n (l. 6) is simply ‘in the present case’ and introduces the application of the general statement contained in h(gou=mai—lo/gon dou=nai: cf. Apol. 17D-18A w(/sper ou)=n a)\n—kai\ dh\ kai\ nu=n.
peri\ a)reth=s. According to Diog. Laert. IX. 8. 55, Protagoras wrote a book having the title peri\ a)retw=n.

10. *simwni/dhs. It is a saying of Simonides of Ceos (ca. 556-468 B.C.) that forms the text on which the discussion in the first book of the Republic is based: see Rep. I. 331D ff. Plato seems also to allude to him in two other places, viz. Rep. II. 365C e)peidh\ to\ dokei=n, w(s dhlou=si/ moi oi( sofoi/, kai\ ta\n a)la/qeian bia=tai kai\ ku/rion eu)daimoni/as ktl. and Rep. VI. 489B ou) ga\r e)/xei fu/sin— tou\s sofou\s e)pi\ ta\s plousi/wn qu/ras i)e/nai a)ll' o( tou=to komyeusa/menos e)yeu/sato (compare Ar. Rhet. II. 16. 1391a. 8 ff. with Cope's note).

*sko/pan. The Scopadae were a ruling family at Crannon and Pharsalus in Thessaly. Simonides seems to have frequently been their guest, and wrote poems in their honour: the most famous is that referred to by Cicero, de Or. II. § 352-3.

12. a)gaqo/n is here more than morally good: it includes bodily and external as well as internal well-being: whence xersi/n te kai\ posi/ as well as no/w|: see also note on 344B l. 4 below. The notion of external well-being belonged to the word from very early times: see Grote, III, 45, n. 3: ‘good’ and ‘bad’ are applied in Theognis and Solon ‘to wealth as contrasted with poverty— nobility with low birth—strength with weakness—conservative and oligarchical politics as opposed to innovation’. This sense survived in classical times in the political meaning of kalo\s ka)gaqo/s, e.g. Xen. Hell. II. 3. 12, Pl. Rep. VIII. 569A.

13. tetra/gwnon. Simonides avails himself of a Pythagorean notion: among the Pythagoreans the number 4 was sacred, as being the first square number: see Ritter and Preller7, § 54. The expression tetra/gwnos a)nh/r became afterwards almost proverbial for a perfect man: Sauppe refers to Ar. Rhet. III. 11. 1411b. 27 ol(=on to\n a)gaqo\n a)/ndra fa/nai ei)=nai tetra/gwnon: a)/mfw ga\r te/leia.
16. kai\ pa/nu moi—memelhko/s. From this and 347A where the same is implied of Hippias, it would seem that the poem was thought to be difficult.
19. e)/fhn e)gw\ kalw=s te kai\ o)rqw=s. This, Bergk's emendation, is generally accepted. B has e)/fhn e)gw/ te kai\ o)rqw=s: *t e)/fhn e)/gwge kai\ o)rqw=s.

24. e)mmele/ws—ne/metai. e)mmele/ws belongs to ei)rhme/non, and ne/metai is poetic for nomi/zetai: cf. (with Sauppe) Soph. O.R. 1080 e)gw\ d' e)mauto
 pai=da th=s tu/xhs ne/mwn. The story is (schol. to Plato, Hipp. Maior, 304E quoted by Sauppe) that Pittacus, when ruler of Mitylene, on hearing of Periander's rapid conversion into a tyrant, sat down at an altar and begged to be released of his rule, assigning as his reason w(s xalepo
 e)sqlo
 e)/mmenai. The scholiast adds that Solon when he heard the remark capped it with xalepa\ ta\ kala/. Pittacus is mentioned side by side with Bias and Simonides as one of the sofoi\ kai\ maka/rioi a)/ndres in Rep. I. 335E.
29-31. o(mologei=sqai—o(mologei=n. The middle is said of things, and the active of persons, according to the general rule.

34. o)li/gon de\ tou= poih/matos ei)s to\ pro/sqen: these words as well as proi+o/ntos tou= a)/|smatos in 339Care in favour of the supposition that some verses are wanting between a)/neu yo/gou tetugme/non and ou)de/ moi e)mmele/ws: see Appendix I, pp. 213-14.
40. to\ pro/teron: adverbial.

41. qo/rubon pare/sxen kai\ e)/painon. qo/rubos denotes only ‘noise’, ‘tumult’ (cf. Rep. VI. 492C qo/rubon—tou= yo/gou kai\ e)pai/nou): kai\ e)/painon is needed to show that the noise was favourable. So above, 334Ca)neqoru/bhsan w(s eu)= le/goi. With pare/xein in this sense cf. the phrase pare/xein ge/lwta in Gorg. 473E and Theaet. 174C.

43. w(sperei\ u(po\ a)gaqou= pu/ktou plhgei/s. For the metaphor cf. Euthyd. 303A e)gw\ me\n ou)=n—w(/sper plhgei\s u(po\ tou= lo/gou e)kei/mhn a)/fwnos. Socrates describes the effect of Protagoras' questions on himself in words which recall the descriptions of his own dialectic in its effect on others: cf. e.g. Meno, 80 A ff.

44. e)skotw/qhn te kai\ ei)liggi/asa. So BT: the second hand in T corrects to i)liggi/asa. According to Suidas (quoted by Schanz in Preface to Vol. VII, p. v) the Greeks wrote ei)liggiw=, but i)/liggos. In Plato's MSS. ei)liggiw= is somewhat less frequent than i)liggiw=.
45. w(/s ge—a)lhqh=: see on 309A
46. e)gge/nhtai: B and T have e)kge/nhtai: e)gge/nhtai is Heindorf's correction, now found in a Vienna MS. (Kral's I): cf. Phaedo, 86E i(/na xro/nou e)ggenome/nou bouleusw/meqa ti/ e)rou=men.
49. so\s me/ntoi—poli/ths. Iulis in Ceos was their native place. me/ntoi is ‘surely’. Notice the emphasis on so/s and compare se/ in ll. 50 and 55.

50. parakalei=n is future: cf. Theaet. 183D a)lla/ moi dokw=— ou) pei/sesqai au)tw=|, Phaedr. 228C dokei=s su\ ou)damw=s me a)fh/sein: tr. ‘therefore I think I will call you to my assistance’. e)gw/ and se/ are contrasted in view of the illustration which is about to follow.

w(/sper e)/fh ktl.: w(/sper corresponds to kai\ e)gw/ in l. 55: as, according to Homer, Scamander called on Simois, so look you, I call upon you. For w(/sper used in this way see above, note on 330A The other editors take dokw= ou)=n e)gw\ parakalei=n se/ with the w(/sper clause, and, regarding parakalei=n as a present, print a full stop after sxw=men in the quotation; but (1) there is a certain awkwardness in the repetition ‘I think I am summoning you’ and ‘so look you, I am summoning you’; (2) the quotation does not finish with sxw=men, but e)kpe/rsh| in l. 56 belongs to it also—a point which is against separating fi/le kasi/gnhte—sxw=men from the following clause. In the view which we have taken a fresh start begins with w(/sper, after which the actual summons follows in the present a)ta\r kai\ e)gw\ se\ parakalw=.

51. e)/fh *(omhros. Il. XXI. 305 ff. ou)de\ *ska/mandros e)/lhge to\ o(\n me/nos a)ll' e)/ti ma=llon xw/eto *rhlei/wni—*simo/enti de\ ke/klet' a)u/sas: *fi/le kasi/gnhte, sqe/nos a)ne/pos a)mfo/tepoi/ rep sxw=men, e)rei\ ta/xa a)/stu me/ga *pria/moio a)/naktos e)kpe/rsei. This e)kpe/rsei explains the occurrence of e)kpe/rsh| in l. 56, although (as Heindorf shows) the same metaphor is occasionally found in tragedy (but hardly in prose), e.g. Trach. 1104 tuflh=s u(p' a)/ths e)kpepo/rqhmai ta/las.
55. a)ta/r: cf. above 335D

57. mousikh=s: ‘culture’, as often; here not without some
sarcasm, in reference to Prodicus' o)noma/twn o)rqo/ths, exemplified in 337Aff.

58. bou/lesqai—e)piqumei=n. bou/lesqai is of will, e)piqumei=n of desire. The distinction is generally well marked in Plato: see note on Apol. 25C and cf. Cope on Ar. Rhet. II. 19. 9. Prodicus does not touch on this example in his speech in 337, but it is quite in Plato's way to select a fresh example (cf. Theaet. 147A-B, 166E by the side of 159C, 169A-B), which may in this case be supposed to come from Prodicus' lectures (cf. 341A. We should expect the article to be repeated with e)piqumei=n, as the two words are to be distinguished (cf. below in l. 63 to\ gene/sqai kai\ to\ ei)=nai); but the article is sometimes dropped with the second of two words even when the words are contrasted, e.g. Euthyphr. 9C to\ o(/sion kai\ mh/. Here the effect of its omission is perhaps to suggest that the two notions are after all more like than different.

63. gene/sqai—ei)=nai. The distinction though long ago recognised by the philosophers was not always present in ordinary speech: otherwise (as Kroschel points out) Protagoras' censure of Simonides would be too absurd, and Socrates' pretended bewilderment out of place. But that Simonides in this poem drew a distinction between gene/sqai and ei)=nai is certain: whether it was the same distinction as Socrates himself draws later is another question; see on geno/menon de\—a)du/naton in 344B
69. to\ au)to/n. B and T here have to\ au)to/n, which Schanz retains: the form occurs on inscriptions and once or twice in Plato's MSS.: v. Schanz, XII, vii.

70. e)/legen, to\ xalepo
 gene/sqai. So Heindorf. e)/legen is ‘said’, not ‘meant’, and the sentence is intended to prove what is stated in the last sentence, viz. that Pittacus ou\ to\ au)to
 e(autw=| e)/legen (said), a)ll' a)/llo. to/ goes with the whole clause xalepo
 gene/sqai e)sqlo/n; the emphasis is on gene/sqai: for which reason to\ e)/mmenai in the next line (for to\ e)/mmenai e)sqlo
 xalepo/n) suffices. It is unnecessary to read (with Schanz and Kroschel) e)/lege(n) xalepo/n, to\ gene/sqai e)sqlo/n, or e)/lege xalepo/n, gene/sqai e)sqlo/n with Sauppe.

75. *pro/dikos o(/de kai\ a)/lloi polloi/. Socrates dissociates
himself from the others, because he is about to give a different solution of Simonides' apparently contradictory statements (in 344Bff.).

76. *(hsi/odon: in Works and Days, 289 ff. th=s d' a)reth=s i(dpw=ta qeoi\ rpora/poiqen e)/qhkan a)qa/natoi: makpo\s de\ kai\ o)/pqios oi)=mos e)s au)th
 kai\ tphxu\s to\ rpw=ton: e)rh
 d' ei)s a)/kpon i(/khtai, r(hidi/h dh)/peita pe/lei, xaleph/ per e)ou=sa. This passage was very famous in antiquity: Plato cites it again in Rep. II. 364C, Laws, IV. 718E. Hesiod in effect says it is difficult to become good, but easy to be good. Simonides himself refers to Hesiod's verses in Frag. 58 (Bergk) e)/sti tis lo/gos ta
 a)reta
 nai/ein dusamba/tois e)pi\ re/tpais, nu=n de/ min qew=n xw=pon a(gno
 a)mfe/rein. . .ou)d' a)ranta=n blefa/pois qnatw=n e)/sorton, w(=| mh\ dake/qumos i(dpw\s e)/ndoqen mo/lh| q' i(/khtai/ t' e)s a)/kron a)ndrei/as.
80. e)kth=sqai: to be taken with r(hi+di/hn. B and T read kth=sqai, but cf. 340E For the form see above on 319A

div.head: CHAPTER XXVII
div.p: After some dialectical skirmishing, Socrates volunteers to give a continuous exposition of the poem.
6. i)w/menos mei=zon to\ no/shma poiw=. Socrates is thinking of the proverb kako\n kakw=| i)a=sqai.

8. poihtou=—e)kth=sqai. The poet is not of course Hesiod but Simonides. Socrates nowhere said that in censuring Pittacus Simonides implies that it is easy to ‘keep virtue’, i.e. to be virtuous: the quotation from Hesiod was put in the mouth of Prodicus and a)/lloi polloi/ (340C. At the same time Protagoras might fairly turn Socrates' fallacies (see on 331A against himself and say that if Simonides said it was ‘not difficult’ to be virtuous, he meant that it was ‘easy’ to be so.
12. kinduneu/ei ga/r toi: the art of Prodicus (Socrates means) can lay as good claims to antiquity as yours: cf. 316D

13. qei/a tis ei)=nai pa/lai. Kroschel's reading ei)=nai kai\ palaia/ would somewhat change the meaning, which is ‘has long been an art divine’: divine because practised by poets and the like, cf. Rep. I. 331E a)lla\ me/ntoi—*simwni/dh| ge ou) r(a/|dion a)pistei=n:
sofo\s ga\r kai\ qei=os a(nh/r: above 315Eand note. In h)/toi a)po\ *simwni/dou there is an allusion to 316D
16. ou)x w(/sper e)gw/, sc. ei)mi/. The idiom is frequent in Plato, e.g. Symp. 179E ou)x w(/sper *)axille/a—e)ti/mhsan kai\ ei)s maka/rwn nh/sous a)pe/pemyan.
maqhth/s. Socrates calls himself a disciple of Prodicus also in Crat. 384B, Meno, 96D, Charm. 163D.
18. to\ xalepo\n tou=to. to/ marks xalepo/n as a quotation: see above on 331C
20. a)ll' w(/sper ktl. The application of the illustration follows in 341B ll. 27 ff. i)/sws ou)=n kai\ to\ xalepo\n—u(polamba/nousin, where see note.

22. *prwtago/ras sofo\s kai\ deino/s e)stin. The h)\ a)/llon tina/ is neglected, and *prwtago/ras takes us back to se/: cf. note on e)ndei/casqai kai\ kallwpi/sasqai in 317C The collocation sofo\s kai\ deino/s is tolerably frequent in ironical characterisations, e.g. Theaet. 173B deinoi/ te kai\ sofoi\ gegono/tes, w(s oi)/ontai.
23. e)rwta=| explains nouqetei=, whence the asyndeton explicativum: see on 335Aabove.

24. to\ ga\r deino\n—kako/n e)stin. Prodicus' canon—which rests on the derivation of deino/n from de/os—is not borne out by Greek usage, except to this extent, that when a man is called deino/s, it is generally implied that he is more clever than good.

25. deinou= plou/tou ktl. Genitives of exclamation in the Platonic dialogues are generally (as Turner remarks) preceded by an interjection, e.g. Euthyd, 303A puppa\c w)= *(hra/kleis kalou= lo/gou and ibid. w)= *po/seidon deinw=n lo/gwn. Here of course the exclamation is left out as irrelevant: the only relevant point is the use of deino/s.

27. i)/sws ou)=n kai\ to\ xalepo/n. Sauppe remarks that we should expect ou(/tw kai\ to\ xalepo/n to introduce the apodosis to the w(/sper clause (341A l. 20); kai/ is however enough to show that we have reached the application; ou)=n is introduced on account of the parenthesis from to\ ga\r deino/n to kakou= o)/ntos; and i)/sws marks the suggestion as only tentative.
31. fwnh/n: ‘dialect’ as often, e.g. Phaedo, 62A kai\ o( *ke/bhs—i)/ttw *zeu/s, e)/fh, th=| au(tou= fwnh=| ei)pw/n.
32. kako/n, e)/fh. Prodicus enters into the spirit of the joke: in view of C and D it would be absurd to take this seriously: see note on a)lla\ pai/zein in D below.

37. ta\ o)no/mata—o)rqw=s diairei=n: cf. above, 340Aand below, 358Ath\n de\ *prodi/kou tou=de diai/resin tw=n o)noma/twn paraitou=mai. Prodicus pretends to regard Simonides (cf. 341 A) as a teacher like himself of o)noma/twn diai/resis.
38. a(/te *le/sbios w)/n: had he been *kei=os, he would have learnt o)noma/twn diai/resis forsooth in its natural home.
39. e)n fwnh=| barba/rw|: a malicious exaggeration inspired by the odium philologicum.

47. a)lla\ pai/zein. The editors suppose that Socrates is here turning the tables on Prodicus, who it is supposed meant his criticism seriously, but the tone of the passage seems to imply that Prodicus is in league with Socrates to make fun of Protagoras, who is represented throughout the whole dialogue as lacking all sense of humour. It would not be wit, but sheer buffoonery, in Plato to represent Prodicus as seriously believing that Simonides had censured Pittacus for having said: ‘It is bad to be good.’

48. kai\ sou= dokei=n a)popeira=sqai. dokei=n is not pleonastic after oi)=mai but means ‘think fit’—a very idiomatic use, cf. Aesch. Ag. 16 o(/tan d' a)ei/dein h)\ minu/resqai dokw=. See Class. Rev. III, 148, where Mr Arthur Sidgwick discusses and illustrates this usage.

53. ou) dh/pou tou=to/ ge le/gwn. ou) dh/pou goes with le/gwn, which is ‘meaning’ not ‘saying’, and tou=to is explained by kako\n e)sqlo\n e)/mmenai. For the asyndeton see on 335A and for the use of ei)=ta cf. 311Aand Symp. 200A po/teron e)/xwn au)to\ ou(= e)piqumei= te kai\ e)ra=|, ei)=ta e)piqumei= te kai\ e)ra=|, h)\ ou)k e)/xwn;

54. tou=to ge/ras. Heindorf reads tou=to to\ ge/ras as in 344C but ge/ras may be regarded as predicative and going closely with a)pe/neime, so that tou=to—tou=to balance each other. Sauppe compares Symp. 179C eu)ariqmh/tois dh/ tisin e)/dosan tou=to ge/ras oi( qeoi/.

55. a)ko/laston—ou)damw=s *kei=on. This seems to be the earliest passage making allusion to the sobriety and uprightness
of the Ceans, to which, perhaps, Aristophanes sarcastically alludes in Frogs, 970 (ou) *xi=os, a)lla\ *kei=os). In Laws, I. 638B (quoted by Sauppe) Plato cites the subjugation of the Ceans by the Athenians as a proof that victory does not always favour the more virtuous side. Strabo (X. 486) quotes from Menander the lines kalo\n to\ *kei/wn no/mimo/n e)sti, *fani/a: o( mh\ duna/menos zh=n kalw=s ou) zh=| kakw=s and explains them by saying that a Cean law required those above the age of 60 to take hemlock so as to make their country's produce suffice to feed the others.
59. o(\ su\ le/geis tou=to refers to peri\ e)pw=n 338E For the idiom cf. the usual to\ so\n dh\ tou=to, e.g. Symp. 221B.

div.head: CHAPTER XXVIII
div.p: Socrates introduces his exposition of the poem with a paradoxical theory that Sparta is the oldest home of philosophers. The wise men of old accordingly expressed their wisdom in pithy Laconic sayings, and such a saying is that of Pittacus. Simonides, as a rival craftsman, wrote this entire poem to overthrow that saying.

This chapter is intended as a kind of counterblast to Protagoras' claim on behalf of sofistikh/ in 316Dff. In general tone as well as in many of the particular statements it is elaborately ironical; but it should be remembered that Plato thought highly in many respects of the Cretan and Spartan constitutions and borrowed much from them in constructing his ideal city.

3. filosofi/a ga ktl. Cf. 316De)gw\ de\ th
 sofistikh
 te/xnhn fhmi\ me
 ei)=nai palaia
 ktl.

4. tw=n *(ellh/nwn: ‘among the Greeks’. The genitive belongs rather to e)n *krh/th te kai\ *lakedai/moni than to plei/sth: cf. Thuc. II. 18. 1 o( de\ strato\s—a)fi/keto th=s *)attikh=s e)s *oi)no/hn. Similarly in gh=s e)kei=, gh=s belongs to e)kei= rather than to plei=stoi: there would seem to be no exact parallel to justify us in taking plei=stoi gh=s together. For the meaning of sofistai/ see on 312C
5. e)carnou=ntai kai\ sxhmati/zontai. sxhmati/zesqai of ‘posing’ as in Soph. 268A a)gnoei= tau=ta a(\ pro\s tou\s a)/llous w(s ei)dw\s e)sxhma/tistai.
7. ou(\s—e)/lege tou\s sofista/s: viz. in 316D The attraction is common enough, e.g. Crito, 48C a(\s de\ su\ le/geis ta\s ske/yeis peri/ te a)nalw/sews xrhma/twn kai\ do/chs ktl. and below, 359D
10. th\n sofi/an. So B and the second hand in T: the first hand omits the words (so Schanz, Kroschel and Kral).

12. tou\s—lakwni/zontas. The editors refer to Ar. Birds, 1281 e)lakwnoma/noun a(/pantes a)/nqrwpoi to/te, e)ko/mwn, e)pei/nwn, e)rru/pwn, e)swkra/twn and Demosth. kata\ *ko/nwnos 34 meq' h(me/ran me\n e)skuqpwra/kasi kai\ lakwni/zein fasi\ kai\ tpi/bwnas e)/xousi kai\ a(pla=s u(pode/dentai. The Laconisers in Athens were tolerably numerous: Plato himself (Rep. VIII. 544C) places h( *krhtikh/ te kai\ *lakwnikh\ politei/a nearest in merit to his ideal city.

12. oi( me\n w)=ta/ te kata/gnuntai: thanks, of course, to boxing: cf. Gorg. 515E tw=n ta\ w)=ta kateago/twn (i.e. tw=n lakwnizo/ntwn) a)kou/eis tau=ta, w)= *sw/krates, and Martial, VII. 32. 5 ‘at uvenes alios fracta colit aure magister’.

13. i(ma/ntas perieili/ttontai. The i(ma/ntes were thongs of leather bound round the knuckles for greater efficacy in boxing: Hom. Il. XXIII. 685. The caestus, being loaded with balls of lead, was a much more brutal instrument (Virg. Aen. v. 404-5).

14. braxei/as a)nabola/s: ‘short cloaks’ in imitation of the tri/bwn (the national Spartan dress: see on 335D. a)nabolh/ (here almost concrete) and a)naba/llesqai were said of the i(ma/tion, to wear which rightly and like a gentleman was e)pi\ decia\ a)naba/llesqai (Theaet. 175 E), not e\p' a)ristera/ (Ar. Birds, 1567-8, a passage which seems decisive against reading e)pide/cia in this phrase). From Suidas (s.v. a)naba/llei—a)naba/llesqai de\ to\ i(ma/tion, ou) periba/llesqai le/gousin) we may infer that a)nabolh/ refers not to the throwing back of the i(ma/tion over the shoulder (since in point of fact it was thrown back over the left shoulder) but to pulling it round the back (from left to right) before throwing the end over the left shoulder in front.

15. w(sdh\—kratou=ntas is ‘quasi vero—his superent’ (Kroschel). For the construction cf. (with Kroschel) Rep. I. 345E ou)k e)nnoei=s o(/ti ou)dei\s e)qe/lei a)/pxein e(kw/n, a)lla\ misqo\n ai)tou=sin, w(s ou)xi\ au)toi=sin w)fe/leian e)some/nhn e)k tou= a)/rxein a)lla\ toi=s a)rxome/nois; Madvig's Gk Syntax, p. 168.

19. cenhlasi/as. Heindorf quotes (inter alia) Ar. Birds, 1012 w(/sper e)n *lakedai/moni cenhlatou=ntai and Plut. Lyc. 27. 6 tou\s
a)qroizome/nous e)p' ou)deni\ xrhsi/mw| kai\ pareisre/ontas ei)s th\n po/lin a)ph/launen (sc. *lukou=rgos), ou)x, w(s *qoukudi/dhs (II. 39) fhsi/, dediw\s mh\ th=s rolitei/as mimhtai\ ge/nwntai kai\ rpo\s a)peth/n ti xph/simon e)kma/qwsin, a)lla\ ma=llon o)/rws mh\ dida/skaloi kakou= tinos u(pa/rcwsin. The reasons assigned by Plutarch are no doubt the true ones.

22. ou)de/na e)w=sin—e)cie/nai. Plut. Lyc. 27. 5 ou)d' a)podhmei=n e)/dwke (*lukou=rgos) toi=s boulome/nois kai\ plana=sqai cenika\ suna/gontas h)/qh kai\ mimh/mata bi/wn a)paideu/twn kai\ politeuma/twn diafora/n, a)lla\ kai\ tou\s a)qroizome/nous etc. (see last note). In Laws, XII. 950C ff. (quoted by Sauppe) Plato lays down similar though less stringent regulations as to a)podhmi/a.
23. w(/sper ou)de\ *krh=tes. There seems to be no other authority for this statement, but (as Sauppe remarks) the resemblance between the Cretan and Spartan institutions is well known.

26. a)lla\ kai\ gunai=kes. Women in Sparta held a position of much greater power and influence than in the rest of Greece, partly at least in consequence of their superior education, physical and otherwise: cf. Ar. Pol. II. 9. 1269b. 32 polla\ diw|kei=to u(po\ tw=n gunaikw=n e)pi\ th=s a)rxh=s au)tw=n (sc. tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn) and see Grote, 11, 383 ff. Heindorf remarks that wise and pregnant sayings by Spartan women (such as are given in pseudo-Plutarch's *lakainw=n a)pofqe/gmata, e.g. the famous te/knon, h)\ ta\n h)\ e)pi\ ta=s) were probably already current in Plato's time.
28. ei) ga\r e)qe/lei—eu(rh/sei. Cf. 324A

32. e)ne/balen r(h=ma—sunestramme/non. The aorist is like ‘behold! he has thrown in’: it expresses rapidity by representing the action as no sooner begun than over. The idiom is very frequent in Plato: Turner refers to Stallbaum on Rep. III. 406D e)a
 de/ tis au)tw=| mikra
 di/aitan prosta/tth|—taxu\ ei)=pen o(/ti ou) sxolh\ ka/mnein. With sunest ramme/non cf. Ar. Rhet. II. 24. 1401a. 5 sunest ramme/nws—ei)pei=n; the metaphor is apparently from an animal gathering itself for a spring (cf. Ar. Hist. Anim. IX. 48. 631a. 27 sustre/yantes e(autou\s fe/rontai w(/sper to/ceuma and Plato, Rep. I. 336B sustre/yas e(auto
 w(/sper qhri/on h(=ken e)f' h(ma=s).

33. w(/sper deino\s a)kontisth/s. With the metaphor compare Theaet. 165D kai\ a)/lla muri/a a(\ e)lloxw=n a)
 peltastiko\s a)nh misqofo/pos e)n lo/gois e)po/menos—e)mbalw
 a)
 ei)s to\ a)kou/ein—h)/legxen a)
 e)pe/xwn kai\ ou)k a)niei\s ktl., ibid. 180A a)ll' a)/n tina/ ti e)/rh|, w(/sper e)k fare/tras r(hmati/skia ai)nigmatw/dh a)naspw=ntes a)potoceu/ousin.
34. paido\s mhde\n belti/w. The phrase is almost proverbial: see on Crito, 49B pai/dwn ou)de\n diafe/rontes.
38. fqe/ggesqai, here of an impressive (almost mystic) utterance, as often in Greek, e.g. Ar. Clouds, 315 au(=tai ai( fqegca/menai tou=to to\ semno/n.

39. *qalh=s o( *milh/sios ktl. This list of the seven wise men is remarkable as excluding Periander, who was canonised later (Diog. Laert. I. 13). Plato refused to allow that a tyrant could be truly sofo/s (Rep. IX. 587D) or even (in the true sense of the term) powerful: see Rep. I. 336A oi)=mai au)to\ (sc. the view that justice is doing good to friends and evil to enemies) *peria/ndrou ei)=nai h)\ *repdi/kkou h)\ *ce/pcou h)\ *)ismhni/ou tou= *qhbai/ou h)/ tinos a)/llou me/ga oi)ome/nou du/nasqai plousi/ou a)ndro/s.

Myson (the least known of the seven) figures as early as Hipponax (Frag. 45, quoted by Sauppe) kai\ *mu/swn o(\n *(wpo/llwn a)nei=pen a)ndrw=n swfrone/staton pa/ntwn. According to a tradition preserved in Diog. Laert. I. 106 the Pythian priestess, being asked by Anacharsis to say if there was any man wiser than himself, replied *oi)tai=o/n tina/ fhmi *mu/swn' e)ni\ *xhni\ gene/sqai sou= ma=llon prapi/dessin a)rhro/ta peukali/mh?si: but another account placed his birthplace in Chen in Laconia, and a third (reading *)htei=o/n tina/ fhmi for *oi)tai=o/n tina/ fhmi in the oracle) in Etea, which was variously placed in Laconia and in Crete. Sauppe remarks that the presence of *lakedaimo/nios with *xi/lwn seems to show that Plato did not regard Laconia as Myson's birthplace, but favoured the view which made him a native of Chenae by Mount Oeta. Thales (fl. ca. 585 B.C., the eclipse of which year he is said to have predicted) is mentioned in two other passages in Plato (in neither of which is his philosophical teaching—that the a)rxh/ is u(/dwr—referred to), once as an author of useful inventions (Rep. X. 600A), and once as the hero of an anecdote illustrating the philosopher's want of worldly wisdom (Theaet. 174A). Pittacus (fl. ca. 612 B.C.) and Bias of Priene in Ionia (contemporary with or earlier than Hipponax, who refers to him in
Diog. Laert. I. 84) are mentioned together again in Rep. I. 335E *bi/anta h)\ *pittako\n—h)/ tin' a)/llon tw=n sofw=n te kai\ makari/wn a)ndrw=n. Cleobulus of Lindus in Rhodes and Chilon of Sparta (both about the beginning of the 6th cent. B.C.) are not again referred to by Plato.

The traditions relating to the wise men and many of the aphorisms with which they are credited are given in Diog. Laert. I. 22-122: for the authorities for their lives, and for their sayings, see Mullach's Fragmenta Philos. Graec. II, 203-34. This passage of the Protagoras, apparently the earliest in which seven are named together, probably contributed in large measure to the canonisation of the wise men.
42. *lakedaimo/nios: Heindorf would read o( *lakedaimo/nios, but Plato may well have said ‘a Lacedaemonian, Chilon’.

46. ei)rhme/na: ou(=toi. The sentence beginning with ou(=toi shows how one is to learn au)tw=n th\n sofi/an toiau/thn ou)=san; the asyndeton (as Heindorf observes) resembles that after shmei=on de/, tekmh/rion de/ and the like. Here ou(=toi kai\ ktl. is so far removed from kai\ katama/qoi—ou)=san that we might have expected ou(=toi ga\r kai/ or (as Kroschel reads) o(/ti for ou(=toi, but the emphatic ou(=toi (parallel to ou(=toi in l. 43 above) renders the explanatory particle unnecessary. Hermann's correction ei)rhme/na a(/ for ei)rhme/na—adopted by Sauppe—gives a wrong meaning; for a)parxh/ ‘first-fruits’ (l. 47) coming after kai\ koinh=| cunelqo/ntes, in marked antithesis to e(ka/stw| ei)rhme/na, cannot mean merely the sayings of each individual—as it will have to mean if a(/ is read, a(/ being then in apposition to a)parxh/n. Kral's r(h/mata braxe/a a)ciomnhmo/neuta <skopw=n> e(ka/stw| ei)rhme/na, a(\ ou(=toi ktl. suffers from the same fault, besides that it is very unlikely that skopw=n should have fallen out.

47. koinh=| cunelqo/ntes—a)ne/qesan. The editors cite Pausanias, X. 24. I e)n de\ tw=| prona/w| tw=| e)n *delfoi=s gegramme/na e)sti
 w)felh/mata a)nqpw/rois ei)s bi/on—ou(=toi ou)=n oi( a)/ndpes a)fiko/menoi e)s *delfou\s a)ne/qesan tw=| *)aro/llwni ta\ a)?do/mena *gnw=qi sauto
 kai\ *mhde
 a)/gan. The same explanation of the presence of these maxims on the temple at Delphi meets us in other authors; but in each case the author is obviously borrowing the story from Plato. Plato states that these two maxims were the cream of the wisdom of the wise men: it would be hardly too much to say that upon them the whole structure of Greek ethical philosophy was based. For the construction, and for the practice of thus dedicating wisdom
to a god, Kroschel aptly quotes Diog. Laert. IX. 6 a)ne/qhke (sc. *(hra/kleitos) d' au)to\ (sc. to\ peri\ fu/sews bibli/on) ei)s to\ th=s *)arte/midos i(ero/n.

51. tou= dh\ e(/neka tau=ta le/gw; Plato frequently enlivens his style by such self-interrogations: Sauppe quotes (inter alia) Gorg. 457E tou= dh\ e(/neka le/gw tau=ta; Apol. 40B ti/ ou)=n ai)/tion ei)=nai u(polamba/nw;
tw=n palaiw=n th=s filosofi/as. tw=n palaiw=n in this emphatic place suggests the contrast with Protagoras and the new/teroi whose tro/pos is makrologi/a.
53. kai\ dh\ kai/ marks the application to the present case: cf. Apol. 18A w(/sper ou)=n a)\n ktl.—kai\ dh\ kai\ nu=n.
56. kaqe/loi: cf. 344C Sauppe quotes Theocr. 22. 115 (of Polydeuces overcoming Amycus) *dio\s ui(o\s a)dhfa/gon a)/ndra kaqei=len.

59. tou/tou e(/neka, i.e. tou= eu)dokimei=n e(/neka. tou/tw| in tou/tw| e)pibouleu/wn is tou/tw| tw=| r(h/mati: with the construction cf. Rep. IV. 443B eu)qu\s a)rxo/menoi th=s po/lews oi)ki/zein and see Stallbaum on Rep. I. 342B.
59. kolou=sai. Hdt. VII. 10. 5 file/ei ga\r o( qeo\s ta\ u(pere/xonta pa/nta kolou/ein (Sauppe).

div.head: CHAPTER XXIX
div.p: Socrates develops his theory of the poem and applies it to the first two lines, not without much sophistry.
3. maniko/n. Notice the extreme dogmatism of Socrates, suggesting a weak case: cf. ou)de\ pro\s e(/na lo/gon (l. 5).
5. ou)de\ pro\s e(/na lo/gon: see on 335D pro\s lo/gon = eu)/logon or eu)lo/gws is frequent in Plato: see on 351E

6. e)a\n mh/ tis u(pola/bh| ktl. The natural interpretation of the me/n (since it follows a)gaqo/n, not gene/sqai) is this. While it is difficult ‘gene/sqai’ truly good, it is yet possible to reach a fair standard of a)reth/. The antithesis is implied if not actually expressed in the sequel: see 345Dand 346C Cf. Introduction, p. xxiv.
8. le/gontos tou= *pittakou=: a fresh start is made, to explain w(/sper e)ri/zonta le/gein.
9. ei)pei=n but le/gein in l. 7: the past tense is used because Socrates is about to put Simonides' meaning in the form of an actual address in past time to Pittacus.

10. w(s a)lhqw=s to be taken with xalepo/n e)stin: see below, 344A(l. 22). Here again Socrates' interpretation is opposed to the natural sense of the passage, according to which a)laqe/ws in the poem goes with a)gaqo/n, and has nothing to do with xalepo/n.
11. e)pi\ tou/tw|—th\n a)lh/qeian. tou/tw| is tw=| a)gaqw=|, and th\n a)lh/qeian = to\ ‘a)laqe/ws’.
13. eu)/hqes—*simwni/dou. As well might Socrates say it is eu)/hqes to use the word a)/ristos.

14. u(perbato/n is used in its technical grammatical sense, Heindorf quotes Long. de Sublim. 22 e)/stin de\ (sc. ta\ u(p erbata\) le/cewn h)\ noh/sewn e)k tou= kat' a)kolouqi/an kekinhme/nh ta/cis kai\ oi(onei\ xarakth\r e)nagwni/ou pa/qous a)lhqe/statos.

15. u(peipo/nta. There is no need to explain u(peipo/nta here as ‘interpreting’ (a sense for which no exact parallel is quoted). u(peipei=n is used here in its regular sense ‘to say before’, ‘to say first’, as in Ar. Wasps, 54-5 fe/re nun katei/pw toi=s qeatai=s to
 lo/gon, o)li/g' a)/tq' u(peipw
 prw=ton au)toi=sin tadi/. The meaning is: if we would arrive at Simonides' meaning, we must regard the adverb a)laqe/ws as transposed, and speak the words of Pittacus first (u(peipo/nta to\ tou= *pittakou=): i.e. instead of saying a)/ndr' a)gaqo
 me
 a)laqe/ws gene/sqai xalepo/n first, and quoting Pittacus' saying afterwards, we should begin with xalepo
 e)sqlo
 e)/mmenai (line 18 ei)po/nta *)=w a)/nqrwpoi, xalepo
 e)sqlo
 e)/mmenai), and make a)/ndr' a)gaqo/n etc. follow as Simonides' answer (ll. 19-22), putting a)laqe/ws last. ou(twsi/ pws shows that u(peipo/nta is to be explained in the sequel, viz. from w(/sper a)/n to a)laqe/ws in l. 22.
18. ei)po/nta: i.q. to\n me\n ei)po/nta: see on 330A Note the precision in the use of the tenses (ei)po/nta, but a)pokrino/menon).

20. ou) ga\r ei)=nai a)lla\ gene/sqai me/n. Cf. Crito, 43D ou)/toi dh\ a)fi=ktai a)lla\ dokei= me/n moi h)/cein ktl. me/n without following de/ is frequent in a clause introduced by a)lla/, the antithesis being contained in the preceding negative clause.
22. ou(/tw fai/netai. After fai/netai the MSS. have to/: ‘vel expungendum vel in toi mutandum hoc to/’ says Heindorf. For pro\s lo/gon see on 351E
24. ta\ e)pio/nta: see Appendix I, p. 214.

29. tu/pon. Socrates' criticism of the poem so far has been di' a)kribei/as: cf. Rep. II. 414A w(s e)n tu/pw|, mh\ di' a)kribei/as ei)rh=sqai. See also note on u(pogra/yantes gramma\s th=| grafi/di in 326Dabove.
30. panto\s ma=llon is frequent in Plato for ‘assuredly’: cf. Crito, 49B.

div.head: CHAPTER XXX
div.p: Socrates expounds the next section of the poem in accordance with his theory of the purport of the whole and finds therein his own doctrine that ill doing comes from want of knowledge.

1. meta\ tou=to—dielqw/n. This sentence is somewhat difficult. tou=to means from a)/ndr' a)gaqo/n to a)/neu yo/gou tetugme/non. The reference in o)li/ga dielqw/n must be to the verses omitted between tetugme/non and ou)de/ moi e)mmele/ws etc. The logical object of le/gei is the sentence (in l, 4) geno/menon de\ diame/nein etc., which is Socrates' paraphrase of ou)de/ moi e)mmele/ws, etc., but the grammatical object begins with o(/ti gene/sqai—the stress being, as often happens, thrown upon the de/ clause: ‘While it is truly difficult to become a good man (albeit possible for some length of time), to continue in that state after you have become good and to be a good man, etc.’ gene/sqai me\n a)/ndra a)gaqo/n, etc., is not, as Socrates says, meta\ tou=to, but his desire to expound the tu/pon to\n o(/lon of the poem throughout (dia\ panto\s tou= a)/|smatos) leads him to begin at the beginning, even at the cost of an error not unnatural in conversational style. See Appendix I, pp. 214-15.
w(s a)\n ei) le/goi lo/gon: ‘as if he were making a speech’, i.e. not a poem. The speech begins at gene/sqai me/n, for o(/ti here introduces oratio recta.

3. oi/=on te me/ntoi e)pi/ ge xro/non tina/. These words do not give the gist of the lost lines: still less are they to be assigned (with Bonghi) to the poem itself, for (as Aars remarks, ‘Das Gedichtdes Simonides’ in Platons Protagoras (1888), p. 12, n. 3) it is implied by Socrates in 343Dff. that me/n in gene/sqai me/n has no expressed
antithesis: they are educed by Socrates himself from xalepo
 a)laqe/ws. Cf. below 346Epa/ntas de\ e)pai/nhmi kai\ file/w e(kw
 (e)ntau=qa dei= e)n tw=| e(kw/n dialabei=n le/gonta) o(/stis e(/rdh| mhde
 ai)sxro/n, a)/kwn d' e)/stin ou(\s e\gw\ e)painw= kai\ filw=. The likeliest supposition is that of Blass—that the lost verses contained a further elaboration of the idea in a)gaqo
 a)laqe/ws.

4. geno/menon de\...a)du/naton. Socrates correctly apprehends the gist of Simonides' objection to the saying of Pittacus, although Simonides himself no doubt read more into the e)/mmenai of Pittacus than Pittacus intended it to express. Simonides here takes e)/mmenai to denote a permanent state, and gene/sqai as not permanent, although in a)/ndra d' ou)k e)/sti mh\ ou) kako
 e)/mmenai he himself uses e)/mmenai more loosely: see below on 344E l. 26. It is however most improbable that Simonides meant by gene/sqai ‘to become’, i.e. ‘to be made’, as Socrates everywhere implies: by a)/ndr' a)gaqo
 me
 gene/sqai a)laqe/ws he meant only ‘that a man should prove himself truly good’, i.e. quit him like a perfect man: cf. Hdt. VII. 224 *lewni/dhs—pi/ptei a)nh geno/menos a)/ristos, Xen. Anab. IV. 1. 26 e)rwta=n ei)/ tis au)tw=n e)/stin o(/stis a)nh a)gaqo\s e)qe/loi gene/sqai. The usage is thoroughly idiomatic.
6. a)lla\ qeo\s a)\n mo/nos—ge/ras. Plato, Symp. 204A qew=n ou)dei\s filosofei= ou)d' e)piqumei= sofo\s gene/sqai: e)/sti ga/r.
8. a)/ndra d' ou)k e)/sti—kaqe/lh|: see below on 344E l. 30.
12-14. ou) to\n kei/menon—to\n de\ kei/menon ou)/. For the repetition compare (with Sauppe) Gorg. 521E ou) pro\s xa/rin le/gwn—a)lla\ pro\s to\ be/ltiston, ou) pro\s to\ h(/diston.
15. o)/nta pote\—kaqe/loi. pote/ goes with kaqe/loi as with kataba/loi in l. 13.
19. kai\ i)atro\n tau)ta\ tau=ta. tau)ta\ tau=ta is virtually adverbial as in Meno, 90D ou)kou=n kai\ peri\ au)lh/sews kai\ tw=n a)/llwn ta\ au)ta\ tau=ta;
20. e)gxwrei= kakw=? gene/sqai. Socrates says gene/sqai, although Simonides said e)/mmenai; see on E (l. 26) below.

21. par' a)/llou poihtou=. Xen. Mem. 1. 2. 20 marturei= de\ kai\ tw=n poihtw=n o(/ te le/gwn ‘e)sqlw=n me
 ga a)p' e)sqla\ dida/ceai: h)
 de\ kakoi=si summi/sgh|s, a)polei=s kai\ to
 e)o/nta no/on’, kai\ o( le/gwn ‘au)ta
a)nh a)gaqo\s tote\ me
 kako/s, a)/llote d' e)sqlo/s’. The first of these quotations is known (see Meno, 95D) to be from Theognis, so that it seems clear that the second must be from some other poet. It is difficult to resist the impression that the author of this line intended a)gaqo/s, kako/s, and e)sqlo/s to have a political sense, and was alluding to the ups and downs of an aristocrat's life in times of civil dissension: cf. Theognis, 1109-10 *ku/rn', oi( pro/sq' a)gaqoi\ nu=n au)= kakoi/, oi( de\ kakoi\ rpi
 nu=n a)gaqoi/: ti/s ken tau=t' a)ne/xoit' e)sorw=n; Euripides, Hecuba, 595 ff. (quoted by Cron) pointedly contradicts the sentiment of this line (as interpreted by Socrates): a)/nq rwpoi d' a)ei\ o( me
 ponhro\s ou)de
 a)/llo plh
 kako/s, o( d' e)sqlo\s e)sqlo/s, ou)de\ sumfora=s u(/po (alluding to Simonides' poem) fu/sin die/fqeir', a)lla\ xrhsto/s e)st' a)ei/.

25. eu)mh/xanon kai\ sofo\n kai\ a)gaqo/n. eu)mh/xanos is identified with a)gaqo/s by means of the middle step sofo/s, sofi/a being a)gaqo/n because it is one of the virtues. See on tw=| e)pista/th| kai\ e)pai(\onti in Crito, 47B.

26. ou)k e)/sti mh\ ou) kako\n e)/mmenai. If Simonides had consistently carried out the distinction between ge/nesis and ou)si/a attributed to him (in part rightly: see on 344B l. 4), he would have used gene/sqai, not e)/mmenai here. Socrates throughout interprets e)/mmenai as equivalent to gene/sqai in this part of the poem, in spite of his previous distinction: but so (apparently) did Simonides: see on 344B

28. to\ d' e)sti/n ktl. to\ de/ ‘whereas in point of fact’ is very frequent in Plato: see on Apol. 23A. Notice how Socrates reverts to the beginning of the poem: see note on 346Dand Appendix I, p. 214.

29. (dunato
 de\) e)sqlo/n. There is not sufficient ground for rejecting (with most of the editors) e)sqlo/n: its position is a trifle awkward, but not more, since dunato
 de/ is parenthetical, the me/n after gene/sqai being balanced by de/ in e)/mmenai de/. Heindorf reads dunato
 de/, e)sqlo
 d' e)/mmenai with slight MS. authority.

30. pra/cas me
 ga eu)= ktl. ga/r is probably due to Plato, who represents this sentence as adducing a reason for e)/mmenai de\ a)du/naton: see Appendix I, p. 217. pra/cas eu)= is ‘if he has prospered’: the whole sentiment is the converse of a)/ndra d' ou)k e)/sti mh\ ou) kako
 e)/mmenai and is characteristic of the ordinary Greek moral code: cf. Hom. Od. XVIII. 136-7 toi=os ga no/os
e)sti
 e)pixqoni/wn a)nqrw/pwn oi(=on e)p' h)=mar a)/gh|si path a)ndrw=n te qew=n te. The view that affliction involves moral degeneracy appears in the transition of meaning in ponhro/s and moxqhro/s from ‘afflicted’ to ‘depraved’: the common view that ‘prosperity’ brings virtue is involved in the usual equivocation on eu)= pra/ttein ‘fare well’ and ‘do well’; see on Crito, 47E and Euthyphr, 3A. After kako\s d' ei) kakw=s is to be understood e)/pracen.

32. ti/s ou)=n ei)s gra/mmata ktl. In order to read into Simonides the doctrine that virtue is knowledge and vice ignorance, Socrates assigns to pra/cas eu)= in the poem the meaning of acting well, rather than faring well.
36. kako\s de\ kakw=s, sc. pra/cas: a free rendering of kako\s d' ei) kakw=s of the poem, which Kral (following Ast) reads here against the MSS.

40. kakw=s pra/cantes, i.e. ei) kakw=s pra/caimen, as the words of the poem show. Socrates' reasoning is: to become a bad doctor by practising badly, you must first have been a good doctor: for if you cannot become a doctor by practising badly, obviously you cannot become a bad doctor. The argument is as fallacious as it is ingenious: it assumes that kako\s i)atro/s is a twofold notion, and more than i)atro/s, whereas it is a single notion and less. It would be more in conformity with experience to say that the i)diw/ths does become by practising badly a kako\s i)atro/s.

45. au(/th ga\r mo/nh—sterhqh=nai. This sentence (necessary as the converse of the statement in 345Athat good action comes from knowledge) is introduced as an explanation of u(po\ xro/nou ktl., because xro/nos, po/nos, no/sos, etc., produce e)pisth/mhs ste/rhsis.
47. me/llei—gene/sqai. See on 312Cabove.

50. diatelou=nta a)gaqo/n explains a)gaqo/n more precisely: cf. 344Bgeno/menon de\ diame/nein e)n tau/th| th=| e(/cei kai\ ei)=nai a)/ndra a)gaqo/n. diatelei=n without a participle seems not to be elsewhere found in Plato, though it occurs in Thucydides and others.
52. e)pi\ plei=ston: ‘diutissime, ut e)pi\ polu/ saepe significat diu’. kai/ is ‘also’ not ‘and’, and balances ou(\s a)\n oi( qeoi\ filw=sin: oi( qeofilei=s are also a)/ristoi.

div.head: CHAPTER XXXI
div.p: The rest of the poem is now expounded and the theory that no man sins willingly discovered in it.
3. dhloi= (sc. ei)rhme/na) is used as in Soph. Ant. 242 dhloi=s d' w(/s ti shmanw=n kako/n.
5. kenea/n goes proleptically with moi=ran ai)w=nos.
7. pana/mwmon a)/nqrwpon in apposition to to\ mh\ gene/sqai dunato/n. Krosche compares Semonid. Amorg. pa/mpan d' a)/mwmos ou)/tis ou)d' a)kh/rios (Frag. 4).
eu)ruedou=s o(/soi—xqono/s. Hom. Il. VI. 142 brotw=n oi(\ a)rou/rhs karpo\n e)/dousin, Hom. Od. II. 14. 10 ‘quicumque terrae munere vescimur’ (Heindorf).

9. e)pi/ q' u(mi=n eu(rw\n a)pallele/w: after Bergk's emendation for the e)/peiq' u(mi=n of the MSS., which cannot be made to scan: see Appendix I, p. 217. It might be possible (in view especially of fhsi/n in the next line) to regard e)/peita here as no part of the poem, were it not for 346D where it must be part. e)pi/ q' u(mi=n is the most probable of the many emendations proposed and accounts by far the most easily for the reading of the MSS. e)pi/ is to be taken with eu(rw/n, and te is like the quasignomic te in Homer, e.g. Il. I. 218 o(/s ke qeoi=s e)pipei/qhtai, ma/la t' e)/kluon au)tou=. Translate ‘“trust me, I will tell you when I've found your man”, says he’. u(mi=n (a kind of ethic dative) does not belong so much to a)pallele/w as to e)feurw/n. What Simonides himself wrote was no doubt e)pi/ t' u)/mmin (availing himself of the Aeolic form as in the next line); this Plato put in Attic as e)pi/ q' u(mi=n, from which to e)/peiq' u(mi=n the step was easy. Sauppe's e)pi\ dh/ min eu(rw/n and Kroschel's e)pei\ ou)/tin' eu(rw/n are hardly happy.
10. fhsi/n applies only to the last line: the former fhsi\ ga/r covers the first sentence.
12. pa/ntas o(/stis: so below in l. 16 w(/ste tou/tous fa/nai e)painei=n o(\s a)/n and in l. 23 o(\s a)\n—tou/twn: see also note on 319D

14. a)na/gkh| d' ou)de\ qeoi\ma/xontai. Proverbial: cf. Laws, VII. 818B e)/oiken o( to\n qeo\n prw=ton paroimiasa/menos—ei)pei=n w(s ou)de\
qeo\s a)na/gkh| mh/ pote fanh=| maxo/menos. Aars quotes the words of Agamemnon in Il. XIX. 86 e)gw\ d' ou)k ai)/tio/s ei)mi, a)lla\ *zeu\s kai\ *moi=ra kai\ h)erofoi=tis *)erinu/s.

17. o(\s a)
 e(kw
—poih=|: but e(kw
 o(/stis e(/rdh| without a)/n above, as often in poetry: Goodwin, M.T. p. 208, § 540.

19. ou)dei\s tw=n sofw=n—e(ko/nta e)camarta/nein. The doctrine that no one sins willingly—a corollary of the view that vice is only ignorance—is characteristic of the ethical teaching both of Socrates and Plato (compare note on 324Aand on Euthyphr. 2C), but not of all Greek sages, and it is only by the most perverse sophistry that Socrates here reads it into Simonides, ignoring entirely the words a)na/gkh| d' ou)de\ qeoi\ ma/xontai.
23. kai\ dh\ kai/: see on 343Babove.
26. kalo\n ka)gaqo/n: see on Apol. 21D.
27. kai\ e)paine/thn. The words filei=n kai\ e)painei=n which follow in the MSS. were ejected by Heindorf.

28. mhte/ra h)\ pate/ra a)llo/koton. Sauppe remarks that from Homer onwards mh/thr generally comes first in such enumerations—an interesting survival, perhaps, of the greater importance assigned to the mother in primitive Greece. a)llo/koton (‘eccentric’ as in Rep. VI. 487D) from a)/llos (in its sinister sense) and ko/tos (i.q. tro/pos, h)=qos, o)rgh/) according to Phrynichus (quoted by Kroschel).
29. h)\ patri/da: see Crito, 50E-51C.
34. e)/ti ma=llon: not = ma=llon h)\ kat' a)ci/an, but—as is presently explained—because they ‘add voluntary feuds to those which they cannot avoid’.
36. a)nagkai/ais: Heusde's correction for a)na/gkais of MSS.
e)pikru/ptesqai—a)nagka/zesqai. Plato is probably thinking of Socrates after his trial as he depicts him in the Crito. a)nagka/zesqai ‘are constrained’ is of course passive.
39. paramuqei=sqai, like mulcere, as often. Sauppe quotes Hor. Epod. XIII. 18 ‘deformis aegrimoniae dulcibus alloquiis’.

41. h(gh/sato—a)nagkazo/menos: ‘believed—that he had
praised, etc.’ Plato deals a sly thrust at Simonides' notorious avarice, as Pindar (quoted by Sauppe) does in Isthm. 11. 6 a( *moi=sa ga\r ou) filokerdh/s pw to/t' h)=n ou)d' e)rga/tis. The words a)ll' a)nagkazo/menos contain the sting; for the life of the xrhmatisth/s is bi/aios (Ar. Eth. Nic. 1. 3. 1096a. 5).
46. e)/moig' e)carkei= ktl. See Appendix I, pp. 214 ff. for the arrangement of this part of the poem.
48. g' o)nhsi/polin. The MSS. read g' o)nh/sei po/lin, which G. Hermann emended to t' o)nhsi/polin, Bergk to o)nasi/polin.
51. ou) ga/r ei)mi filo/mwmos probably belongs to an earlier part of the poem (before e)/moig' e)carkei=: cf. ou) dia\ tau=ta/ se ye/gw, o(/ti ei)mi\ filo/yogos in line 45): see Appendix I, p. 217.
53. gene/qla is Stephanus' correction for ge/neqla of the MSS., a mistake due to supposing that a)pei/rwn (not from a)/peiros) went with h)liqi/wn: it belongs to gene/qla.
56. pa/nta toi kala/—me/miktai sums up the whole moral teaching of the poem.
60. kai\ ou) zhtw= ktl. Socrates recapitulates part of the poem by way of interpreting the final text: see note on to\ d' e)sti\n gene/sqai ktl. in 344Eabove and Appendix I, p. 214.

62. tou/tou g' e(/neka: ‘si hoc spectetur s. requiratur, to\ pana/mwmon ei)=nai’ (Heindorf): cf. Phaed. 85B a)lla\ tou/tou g' e(/neka le/gein te xrh\ kai\ e)rwta=n o(/ ti a)\n bou/lhsqe. The sense is: if I must wait for perfection before beginning to praise, I shall never praise anyone.
66. w(s pro\s *pittako\n le/gwn: not serious, of course, nor true.

67. dialabei=n: i.e. make a division, ‘pause’, virtually ‘punctuate’. The editors compare the use of diasti/cai in Ar. Rhet. III. 5. 1407b. 14 ta\ ga\r *(hraklei/tou diasti/cai e)/rgon dia\ to\ a)/dhlon ei)=nai pote/rw? pro/skeitai.
68. a)/kwn d' e)/stin ou(/s: see on 344B
70. nu=n de\—sfo/dra ga/r. Cf. Apol. 38B nu=n de\—ou) ga\r e)/stin and note in loc. Here dia\ tau=ta sums up the clause sfo/dra ga\r— le/gein.

div.head: CHAPTER XXXII
div.p: The original question is now resumed, Socrates expressing himself disparagingly on poetical criticism. With some reluctance Protagoras consents to submit himself again to Socrates' interrogatory.

5. e)/sti me/ntoi\ kai\ e)moi\ ktl. Imitated in Hipp. Maior, 286 A, where Hippias says e)/sti ga/r moi peri\ au)tw=n pa/gkalos lo/gos sugkei/menos kai\ a)/llws eu)= diakei/menos kai\ toi=s o)no/masi. Like Socrates in his recent exposition, Hippias looks upon poetical criticism as a legitimate field for the exercise of sophistry and wit.
6. e)pidei/cw: see on e)pideica/menos in 328D
8. w(mologhsa/thn: in 338D where, however, the terms of the agreement are somewhat more stringent.
13. peri\ me\n a)|sma/twn—e)a/swmen. Heindorf quotes Alc. I, 113D e)a/santes ou)=n peri\ au)tw=n skopou=sin o(po/tera sunoi/sei pra/casin.

16. kai\ ga dokei= moi ktl. This passage (from to\ peri\ poih/sews down to ka)
 pa/nu polu
 oi)=non pi/wsin) is quoted by Athenaeus, 111. 51. It is doubtful whether Plato is here animadverting on Xenophon's Symposium, in which (2. 1 and 9. 3 ff) both a flute-girl and a dancing-girl appear: the words toi=s sumposi/ois toi=s tw=n fau/lwn kai\ a)gorai/wn a)nqrw/pwn would contain a very pretty hit at Xenophon, if the evidence for the allusion were more complete. There is a similar passage in the Symposium of Plato (176E) ei)shgou=mai th
 me
 a)/rti ei)selqou=san au)lhtri/da xai/rein e)a=n, au)lou=san e(auth=| h)\ a)
 bou/lhtai tai=s gunaici\ tai=s e)/ndon: this passage Athenaeus (XI. 112) cites in support of his theory of a literary rivalry between Plato and Xenophon.

18. a)gorai/wn: like the Latin circumforanei, ‘a)gorai=os, vel ut critici veteres volunt, a)go/raios, est o( e)n a)gora=| teqramme/nos, s. qui totos dies forum conterit, quem a)gora=s peri/trimma Comicus
appellat, vilis et ex ima plebe homo, Aristoph. Eqq. 181 o(tih\ ponhro\s ka)c a)gora=s ei)= kai\ qrasu/s: 214 ta\ d' a)/lla soi pro/sesti dhmagwgika/, fwnh\ miara/, ge/gonas kakw=s, a)go/raios ei)=’ (Heindorf).

21. timi/as poiou=si ta\s au)lhtri/das: ‘run up the price of flute-players’: to\ ga\r spa/nion—ti/mion (Euthyd. 304B). Heindorf aptly quotes Xen. De Vect. IV. 10 xrusi/on o)/tan polu\ parafanh=| au)to\ me\n a)timo/teron gi/gnetai, to\ de\ a)rgu/rion timiw/teron poiei=.
25. kai\ pepaideume/noi. So Athenaeus (III. 51) and the second hand in T: B and T read pepaideume/noi. Schanz brackets pepaideume/noi, but u(po\ a)paideusi/as in l. 21 is in its favour.
ou)k a)\n i)/dois—yaltri/as. Cf. Theaet. 173D dei=pna kai\ su\n au)lhtri/si kw=moi, ou)de\ o)/nar pra/ttein prosi/statai au)toi=s (i.e. toi=s w(s a)lhqw=s filoso/fois).

30. ka)\n pa/nu polu\n oi)=non pi/wsin: like Socrates in the Symposium: see 220A, 223C. In Laws, I. 637B ff. Plato argues that wine properly used is the means of teaching self-control, since the man who will be sw/frwn when drunk will a fortiori be sw/frwn when sober: cf. ibid. II. 673E ff.

31. e)a
 me
 ktl. me/n suggests that in different society the same would not be the case—an antithesis which is already expressed in 347CD. Cf. Apol. 17B ei) me
 ga tou=to le/gousin, o(mologoi/hn a)
 e)/gwge ou) kata\ tou/tous ei)=nai r(h/twr. For la/bwntai cf. (with Sauppe) Symp. 218A ne/ou yuxh=s mh\ a)fuou=s o(/tan la/bwntai cf. (sc. oi( e)n filosofi/a| lo/goi).

33. ou)/te a)nere/sqai—e)pago/menoi/ te: for the sentiment see on 329Aabove: for ou)/te—te on 309B for au)tou/s after ou(/s on 313A e)pa/gesqai is the regular word for ‘cite’, e.g. Rep. II. 364C ma/rturas poihta\s e)pa/gontai.
36. o(\ a)dunatou=sin: o(/, not in B and T, was restored by Heindorf: it has since been found in a Vienna MS.
38. e)w=sin: the subject is supplied from a)ndrw=n oi(=oi/per h(mw=n oi( polloi/ fasin ei)=nai.

41. kataqeme/nous: for the asyndeton see on 330A Both here and in Tim. 59C katati/qesqai is not used in the sense of laying aside for good, but rather (as generally) putting away to be
resumed again. ‘Putting the poets on their shelves’ would give the effect of the Greek.
45. pare/xein: see on sugkaqei=nai in 336Aabove.
51. kai\ nu=n: as before 336B

54. i(/na tou/tw| me\n tau=ta suneidw=men. Symp. 193E ei) mh\ sunh/|dh *swkra/tei te kai\ *)aga/qwni deinoi=s ou)=si peri\ ta\ e)rwtika/. In su/noida e)mautw=| a)gaqw=| o)/nti sun- goes with e)mautw=|—I am conscious with myself that I am good—by the convenient fiction which separates the observing ego from the observed. Cases where the dative is not a reflexive pronoun are later in development and presuppose only knowledge about, not knowledge along with, the object.
56. w(/s ge/ moi. B has w(/ste moi, T w(s g' e)moi/ (sic). There is no occasion for the emphatic form of the pronoun.
58. tw=n a)/llwn sxedo/n ti. sxedo/n ti need not be accompanied by pa/ntes: compare Phaedo, 59C a)/llos de/ tis parh=n; sxedo/n ti oi)=mai tou/tous paragene/sqai.

59. prou)tra/peto. No other example of the aorist middle of protre/pw is quoted from any Attic author, but e)trapo/mhn is common, e.g. Apol. 21B mo/gis pa/nu e)pi\ zh/thsin au)tou= toiau/thn tina\ e)trapo/mhn.
60. e)ke/leuen: the imperfect of this verb is used in narrative style for the aorist.

div.head: CHAPTER XXXIII
div.p: After a prefatory compliment to Protagoras, Socrates again asks whether the five virtues are only different names for one thing or differ in reality from one another.

4. to\n *(/omhron to/. to/ goes with the whole quotation, to which ti is in predicative apposition (cf. ti/ tou=to le/geis and the like), literally ‘I think that what Homer says, etc., is something’, i.e. ‘I think there is sense in what Homer says’. Schanz brackets to\n *(/omhron, so as to make the articular clause the subject to le/gein as in Ar. Knights, 334, but there is no occasion for the change. The quotation had become almost proverbial (cf. Symp. 174D, Alc. II, 140A) for ‘Two heads are better than one’:
it is from Il. X. 224 ff., where Diomedes says: su/n te du/) e)rxome/nw, kai/ te pro\ o( tou= e)no/hsen, o)/ppws ke/rdos e)/h|: mou=nos d' ei)/ pe/r te noh/sh|, a)lla/ te/ oi( bra/sswn te no/os lepth\ de/ te mh=tis. Leaf (in loc.) explains e)rxome/nw as a pendent accusative and for the order of words in pro\ o( tou= cites Il. V. 219 e)pi\ nw\ tw=|d' a)ndri/.
6. eu)porw/teroi—e)smen, i.e. ou(/tws e)/xontes (viz. su\n du/o e)rxome/nw); it is hardly necessary to read ou(/tws pws or to change pws into ou(/tws as Heindorf suggests.

8. au)ti/ka periiw\n—e)ntu/xh|. The e)pidei/chtai and bebaiw/shtai—deliberative subjunctives—of the MSS. would imply too much eagerness: the change to e)pidei/cetai and bebaiw/setai is adopted by Sauppe and others. This mistake (or the reverse) is tolerably frequent in Plato's MSS., cf. Gorg. 489A (bebaiw/swmai T, bebaiw/somai B), 505E (poih/swmen BT), 510A (a)dikh/swmen BT).
10. e(/neka tou)tou refers to the following clause introduced by h(gou/menos. Heindorf refers to his note on Phaedo, 102D le/gw de\ tou=d' e(/neka, boulo/menos do/cai soi\ o(/pr e)moi/.
17. w(/ste kai\ ktl. The reference is to 316Dff. kai/ does not go with a)/llwn but with the whole sentence (as Sauppe points out).

19. u(pokhruca/menos ‘having had yourself heralded as a sophist’: compare Aeschin. in Ctes. 41 a)/lloi de/ tines u(pokhruca/menoi tou\s au(tw=n oi)ke/tas a)fi/esan a)peleuqe/rous. The force of u(po- is probably the same as in u(pei=pon: see note on 343E Notice the effect of the double seauto/n (both of them after a natural pause): seauto\n u(pokhruca/menos—seauto\n a)pe/fhnas: the -auto/n is brought out so strongly as to suggest that Protagoras is the only true *au)to/s or Master.

22. misqo\n—a)/rnusqai: 328B where however it is not said that Protagoras was the first to take a fee. The Homeric word a)/rnusqai is occasionally used by prose writers in the phrase misqo\n a)/rnusqai: whence misqarnei=n.
25. e)kei=na—ta\ me\n—ta\ de/: see above on 330A
27. h)=n de\—to/de: 329Cff.
39. e(/kasta attracted for e)/kaston: so Rep. VIII. 546C deome/nwn e(no\s e(ka/stwn, i.e. ‘lacking—each of them—one’.
42. ou)de/n soi u(po/logon ti/qemai. u(po/logon ti/qemai like u(po/logon poiou=mai (Lach. 189B) and u(pologi/zomai (Apol. 28B) is ‘to set down against’, ‘per contra’, whence ‘object’ as here.

div.head: CHAPTER XXXIV
div.p: Protagoras gives up what he had contended for before, and contents himself with saying that courage alone is quite different from its sister virtues. Socrates endeavours to identify courage and knowledge in a cumbrous proof, against the validity of which Protagoras rightly protests.
2. mo/ria me/n. The antithesis to me/n was already expressed in e)/fhsqa ou)=n su\ ou)k o)no/mata e)pi\ e(ni\ ei)=nai 349B

4. h( de\ a)ndrei/a ktl. Protagoras therefore yields to Socrates' arguments so far as they have yet gone, and takes his stand on the only virtue the relation of which to the others has not yet been discussed: see on 333Cand D and Introduction, p. xiii.
7. a)kolastota/tous—a)ndreiota/tous de/: like Otho (Tac. Hist. II. 49), apropos of whose death Merivale quotes the lines of Byron, which well illustrate the sentiment of Plato:
And strange to say, the sons of pleasure, They who have revelled beyond measure In beauty, wassail, wine and treasure, Die calm, and calmer oft than he Whose heritage was misery.

8. a)ndreiota/tous de\ diafero/ntws. The extreme difference (cf. pa/nu polu\ diafe/ron in l. 4) between courage and the other virtues is brought out by representing those most lacking in the other virtues as sometimes ‘supremely brave beyond all others’: below in 359Bthe diafero/ntws is omitted as unnecessary in a recapitulation. Sauppe quotes Tim. 23C h( nu=n *)aqhnai/wn ou)=sa po/lis
a)ri/sth pro/s te to\n po/lemon kai\ kata\ pa/nta eu)nomwta/th diafero/ntws: cf. also Gorg. 487B ai)sxunthrote/rw ma=llon tou= de/ontos. Various suggestions have been proposed, but the text is sound.
e)/xe dh/. ‘Hac sistendi formula aut monetur, qui rectam viam ingressus est, ut caveat, ut hic et Gorg. 460A, aut revocatur, qui a recta aberravit, ut Prot. 349Drsquo; (Wohlrab on Theaet. 186B).

9. po/teron tou\s a)ndrei/ous qarrale/ous ktl. Socrates proceeds by reasoning thus: (1) a)ndrei=oi are qarrale/oi; (2) e)pisth/mones are qarrale/oi (349E l. 16 to 350B l. 25); (3) none who are qarrale/oi without e)pisth/mh are a)ndrei=oi (350B ll. 25-30). From this he infers that sofoi/ (i.e. e)pisth/mones) are a)ndrei=oi, i.e. that sofi/a is a)ndrei/a. The reasoning is far from cogent. In the first place, we have to assume (it is nowhere stated) that qarrale/oi contains two classes and no more, viz. qarrale/oi with knowledge and qarrale/oi without knowledge: the assumption would be (to Socrates) a natural one, since (according to the reasoning in ch. XIX ff.) every one who is not e)pisth/mwn is a)nepisth/mwn.
