Now as a)ndrei=oi are qarrale/oi and no a)nepisth/mones (in the class qarrale/oi) are a)ndrei=oi, it follows that a)ndrei=oi are e)pisth/mones, but even then the conclusion of Socrates is not warranted— that e)pisth/mones are a)ndrei=oi, since a)ndrei=oi may be only a part of e)pisth/mones. Socrates —consciously or unconsciously—covers his erroneous reasoning by another fallacy when about to draw his conclusion in 350B, ll. 31 and 34, where see note.

10. kai\ i)/tas g', e)/fh: i.e. they not only have qa/rros (which may be quiescent) but they put it into action. In i)e/nai Protagoras contrives to give the derivation of i)/ths: Sauppe refers to the scholiast on Ar. Clouds, 444 i)/ths. i)tamo/s, a)naidh/s, kai\ di' au)tw=n xwrw=n tw=n pragma/twn. a)ndrei=os is coupled with i)/ths in Symp. 203D and with qrasu/s in Ar. Clouds, loc. cit.

11. fe/re dh/ ktl. This section (from fe/re dh/ to w(s oi(=o/n te
ma/lista in l. 16) is intended to prepare the way for the proof of the third proposition (see on l. 9) in 350B see note on l. 29, and cf. Laches, 192C, where the proof that a)/frwn karte/rhsis is not a)ndrei/a is introduced in much the same way: sxedo\n ga/r ti oi)=da—o(/ti tw=n pa/nu kalw=n pragma/twn h(gei= su\ a)ndrei/an ei)=nai.
14. ei) mh\ mai/nomai/ ge: ‘as I'm a sane man’. This and similar phrases are frequent in Plato, e.g. Euthyd. 283E, Rep. X. 608D (ei) mh\ a)dikw= ge), Gorg. 511B oi)=da—ei) mh\ kwfo/s g' ei)mi.
to\ me/n ti—to\ de/ ti. See on Euthyphr. 12A. Kroschel quotes Phileb. 13C ta\s me\n ei)=nai/ tinas a)gaqa\s h(dona/s, ta\s de/ tinas—kaka/s.

17. aolumbw=sin. This and the next example are given also in Lach. 193 B ff. Sauppe thinks that the object of such diving (an art in which the Greeks were very expert: see Thuc. IV. 26. 8) may have been to clean the wells and the like.
21. ti/nes de\ pe/ltas e)/xontes. See Introduction, p. xxxii.

24. au)toi\ e(autw=n—h)/. The notion ‘than’ is expressed twice: see note on Crito, 44C kai/toi ti/s a)\n ai)sxi/wn ei)/h tau/ths do/ca h)\ dokei=n ktl., and cf. below, 350Eand (with Sauppe) Hdt. VIII. 86 e)ge/nonto—makrw=| a)mei/nones au)toi\ e(wutw=n h)\ pro\s *eu)boi/h|.

29. ai)sxro
 menta)/n—a)ndrei/a: and if ai)sxro/n, not a)reth/ (which it is), since all a)reth/ is kalo/n (349E. Cf. Lach. 182C h( de/ ge a)ndrei/a w(mologei=to kalo
 ei)=nai and with the general sentiment Meno, 88B oi)=on a)ndrei/a, ei) mh\ e)/sti fro/nhsis h( a)ndrei/a a)ll' oi)=on qa/ppos ti: ou)x o(/tan me
 a)/neu nou= qapph=| a)/nqpwros, bla/rtetai, o(/tan de\ su
 nw=|, w)felei=tai;

30. le/geis: the present is idiomatically used in referring to an earlier part of a discussion not yet ended: see on o(/per le/gw in Apol. 21A. With le/geis followed by an accusative in this sense compare Symp. 199E peirw= dh\ kai\ to\n *)/erwta ei)pei=n: o( *)/erws e)/rws e)sti\n ou)deno\s h)\ tino/s;

31. ou)xi\tou\s qarrale/ous ei)=nai. This Protagoras did not say, but only that oi( a)ndrei=oi are qarrale/oi: see 349E For this reason Sauppe and others reject tou/s before qarrale/ous, and in favour of this urge the reply of Protagoras (kai\ nu=n ge): but inasmuch as (1) ou)kou=n ou(=toi—maino/menoi fai/nontai seems to be intended to be incompatible with tou\s a)ndrei/ous ou)xi\—ei(=nai, (2) qarralew/tatoi
de\ o)/ntes a)ndreio/tatoi in l. 35 clearly implies that qarrale/oi are conceived of as a)ndrei=oi (no less than a)ndrei=oi as qarrale/oi), we must, if we regard the argument as a whole, retain the MSS. reading. Protagoras' kai\ nu=n ge is an unwary admission: he does not at first catch the difference between oi( a)ndrei=oi/ ei)sin oi( qarrale/oi and oi( a)ndrei=oi/ ei)si qarrale/oi, and Socrates avails himself of his opponent's slip to hasten to his conclusion—which but for this misrepresentation could only be expressed as a)ndrei=oi are sofoi/ ( = e)pisth/mones), not sofoi/ are a)ndrei=oi: see on 349Eand 350D

34. e)kei=, i.e. in the case of qa/rros based on sofi/a, illustrated in 350A Sauppe (after Schöne) reads oi(\ sofw/tatoi, ou(=toi ktl.: but oi( sofw/tatoi need not go closely with ou(=toi (which is resumptive) any more than oi( ou(/tw qarrale/oi o)/ntes with the preceding ou(=toi. There is a kind of chiasmus in the order ou(=toi— oi(—qarrale/oi) (oi( sofw/tatoi ou(=toi.

36. ou) kalw=s—mnhmoneu/eis ktl. Protagoras sees now that ‘All brave are bold’ is not equivalent to ‘All bold are brave’, and rectifies his kai\ nu=n ge by pointing out that he originally said only ‘All brave are bold’ but he confines his attention to this point, without touching on the fundamental flaws in Socrates' argument from 349Eto 350B
39. w(molo/ghsa: in 349E

40. to/te h)/rou. So B and T. In to/te there is perhaps a latent contrast to kai\ nu=n ge of l. 31. Protagoras is correcting his recent slip—had you asked me then (viz. at 349E, I should have answered rightly. tou=to has inferior MSS. authority.

41. tou\s de\ a)ndrei/ous w(s ou) qarrale/oi ei)si/n. The ou) after w(s is due to a confusion between (1) tou\s de\ a)ndrei/ous w(s ou) qarrale/oi ei)si/n, ou)damou= e)pe/deicas and (2) oi( de\ a)ndrei=oi w(s qarrale/oi ei)si/n, to\ e)mo\n o(molo/ghma, ou)damou= ktl. The insertion of ou) is the more natural because after verbs of refuting and the like the object clause gives what is maintained and not what is refuted, whence e)le/gxein w(s ou), a)ntile/gein w(s ou) etc.
45. kai\ e)n tou/tw| oi)/ei ktl. Protagoras ignores Socrates' third proposition in 350B(25-30), where it is shown that qa/rros without e)pisth/mh is not a)ndrei/a; see next note.

48. prw=ton me\n ga\r ktl., i.e. you might as well argue
(1) oi( i)sxuroi/ are dunatoi/, (2) oi( e)pisth/mones are dunatoi/, therefore oi( e)pisth/mones are i)sxuroi/. This would only be correct if for (1) we substituted oi( dunatoi/ are i)sxuroi/. To make Protagoras' picture of Socrates' argument complete, we should have to add (3) none who are dunatoi/ without e)pisth/mh are i)sxuroi/—but this is not true, whereas Socrates' third proposition is. The completed picture therefore fails to represent correctly Socrates' reasoning in each of its steps, but none the less are Protagoras' objections strictly relevant, and indeed fatal to Socrates' conclusion as expressed in 350C(33-6), and that is why Socrates makes no reply.

58. a)po\ e)pisth/mhs—th
 du/namin ktl. Protagoras says in effect: du/namis and i)sxu/s are of the body, qa/rsos and a)ndrei/a of the soul. du/namis may come from knowledge (as when one has learnt how to wrestle: above 350E, or from madness or rage (as in the feats of madmen, or men inspired with the thirst for vengeance; such men have no real physical strength or i)sxu/s as it is presently defined, but excel themselves by virtue of du/namis). i)sxu/s comes from natural constitution (fu/sis) and proper nurture of the body (by gymnastics in the widest sense). Similarly qa/rsos may result from art (te/xnh is substituted for e)pisth/mh in view of the illustrations in 350A, from rage or madness (as when Empedocles leapt into Etna); a)ndrei/a comes from the native character and proper nurture of the soul (cf. Rep. III. 410D to\ qumoeide\s—th=s fu/sews—o)rqw=s me
 trafe
 a)ndpei=on a)
 ei)/h, ma=llon d' e)pitaqe
 tou= de/ontos sklhpo/n te kai\ xalero
 gi/gnoit' a)/n, w(s to\ ei)ko/s).

div.head: CHAPTER XXXV
div.p: Here Socrates, taking a fresh start, endeavours to make Protagoras assent to the doctrine that pleasure is good. Protagoras desires to have the question examined. He allows that wherever knowledge is present, it must rule, but this is inconsistent with the view that one can know the better and do the worse. It is agreed to examine this popular view, in case the inquiry should throw light on the relation between courage and the rest of virtue. On the ethical doctrine of this and the following chapters see Introduction, p. xxvi.
3. eu)= zh=n ei) a)niw/menos—zw/|h. There is the usual ambiguity in eu)= zh=n: see on 344Eabove.

5. ou)k eu)= a)/n soi dokei=. The MSS. have dokoi=, which all the editors (except Heindorf) retain. The meaning required is: ‘would he not, think you, have lived well?’ (to which Protagoras replies e)/moige sc. dokei=), not ‘would you not think he has lived well?’ and dokei= is as necessary here as in a)=r' ou)=n dokei= soi a)/nqrwpos a)
 eu)= zh=n ei)—zw/|h above. The idiom is attested by abundant examples, e.g. Ar. Plut. 380 kai\ mh
 fi/lws g' a)/n moi dokei=s, nh\ tou\s qeou/s, trei=s mna=s a)nalw/sas logi/sasqai dw/deka, Wasps, 1404-5 ei) nh\ *di/' a)nti\ th=s kakh=s glw/tths poqe
 purou\s pri/aio swfronei=n a)/n moi dokei=s: in Plato it is extremely frequent, e.g. Rep. 1. 335Bpa/nu me
 ou)=n ou(/tws a)/n moi dokei= kalw=s le/gesqai, Alc. I, 105C ei) au)= soi ei)/poi—ou)k a)
 au)= moi dokei=s e)qe/lein, Gorg. 514E, cf. Euthyd. 294B, 306B Gorg. 522A, and below 357A The corruption is natural: it occurs also in the MSS. of Ar. Wasps, loc. cit.

10. e)gw\ ga\r le/gw: i.e. ‘I mean’ not ‘I say’: cf. below, l. 23 in E. Socrates puts his question in a different form inviting an affirmative answer. After the h(de/a following Heindorf would insert ta\ h(de/a, but the subject is easily supplied.

11. mh\ ei)/ ti—a)/llo. So B and the first hand in T. The clause ei)/ ti—a)/llo defines negatively the meaning of kata\ tou=to, as kaq' o(\ h(de/a e)sti/n defined it positively. mh/ deprecates or forbids the possible misunderstanding: its use in the idiomatic mh\ o(/ti is the same in kind: see above on 319D To read ei) mh/ ti (with the second hand in T) would be to beg the whole question—that step is not reached till 353D
18. e)/sti me\n a(\ ktl. See on a)nqrw/pois me\n—w)fe/lima in 334A

26. e)a\n me\n pro\s lo/gon ktl. pro\s lo/gon does not (except per accidens) mean ‘relevant’ but is equivalent to eu)/logon: compare the phrases meta\ lo/gou, kata\ lo/gon; and, for the use of pro/s, pro\s o)rgh/n, pro\s bi/an and the like. So in 343D 344A Here
the meaning is further explained by the clause kai\ to\ au)to\— a)gaqo/n. to\ ske/mma is quite different from ske/yis: it is not the inquiry itself, but the proposition to be inquired into, viz. that Pleasure is good: if this proposition is reasonable, says Protagoras, we shall accept it, if not, we shall dispute it. The sentiment does not deserve the scorn which Heindorf pours upon it, if only we catch the force of pro\s lo/gon, ske/mma and a)mfisbhth/somen.

31. di/kaios—su/. Plato very frequently omits the copula e)sti/n; ei)= and e)sme/n more rarely, ei)=nai often, h)=n rarely, parts of the conjunctive and optative very rarely. Schanz, Novae Commentationes Platonicae, 31-5.

kata/rxeis: a lofty word (here used with a touch of irony) with religious associations: the middle is used of beginning a sacrifice. Cf. Symp. 177E a)lla\ tu/xh| a)gaqh=? katarxe/tw *fai=dros kai\ e)gkwmiaze/tw to\n *)/erwta and ibid. 176A.

34. h)\ pro\s a)/llo ti. It is not of course implied that u(gi/eia is an e)/rgon sw/matos, i.e. something o(\ sw=ma e)rga/zetai. Examples of sw/matos e)/rga would be different kinds of bodily labour. h)\ pro\s u(gi/eian ktl. is equivalent to pw=s e)/xei h)\ pro\s u(gi/eian ktl.: cf. below 352Bpw=s e)/xeis pro\s e)pisth/mhn;

35. to\ pro/swpon kai\ ta\s xei=ras a)/kras: the rest being covered by clothes. xei/r is not hand here (otherwise xei=ras a)/kras would be the tips of the fingers), but the arm, as in Homer's fi/las peri\ xei=re balo/nte (Od. XI. 211).

37. e)piske/ywmai. The word is apt here, as it is often used of a medical inspection: cf. Phaedo, 117E e)pesko/pei tou\s po/das kai\ ta\ ske/lh. With the whole passage cf. Theaet. 162A a)=ra ka)
 ei)s *lakedai/mona e)lqw
—pro\s ta\s palai/stras a)cioi=s a)
 a)/llous qew/menos gumnou/s, e)ni/ous fau/lous, au)to\s mh\ a)ntepideiknu/nai to\ ei)=dos parapoduo/menos;
39. qeasa/menos: with the usual asyndeton; see on 330A
42. kai\ tou=to: kai/ refers to 351CD.
45. h(gemoniko/n: this word was afterwards selected by the Stoics to denote to\ kuriw/taton th=s yuxh=s, e)n w(=| ai( fantasi/ai kai\ ai( o(rmai\ gi/nontai (Diog. Laert. VII. 159).
46. w(s peri\ toiou/tou au)tou= o)/ntos: see on 337E

51. peri\ th=s e)pisth/mhs w(/sper peri/: see the reference in the last note. Aristotle alludes to this passage in Eth. Nic. VII. 2. 1145b. 23 deino\n ga\r e)pisth/mhs e)nou/shs, w(s w)/|eto *swkra/ths, a)/llo ti kratei=n kai\ perie/lkein au)th\n w(/sper a)ndra/podon.

54. e)a/nper gignw/skh|—mh\ a)\n krathqh=nai: a frequent theme in Plato, e.g. Meno, 77B ff., Gorg. 466D ff., two passages which contain much in common with the discussion in this and the next chapter.
56. h)\ a(\ a)\n h(: the reading of Stephanus; B has h)\ a(\ h(, T h)\ a)\n h(.
59. ai)sxro\n—mh\ ou)xi/. Goodwin, M.T. p. 327, § 817. As a sofisth/s himself Protagoras must exalt sofi/a.
62. kalw=s ge su\ le/gwn: sc. fh\|s tou=to, to be supplied from fa/nai.
64. gignw/skontas ta\ be/ltista ou)k e)qe/lein pra/ttein: ‘video meliora proboque: deteriora sequor.’
73. u(po\ tw=n h(donw=n h(tta=sqai is virtually within inverted commas. With kai\ ou) the sentence which started as a relative clause becomes independent: see note on 313A

div.head: CHAPTER XXXVI
div.p: Although pleasures are sometimes called evil and pains good, it is in such cases their consequences which are intended to be so called: at the time itself all pain is evil, and all pleasure good.

The argument proceeds by these stages: First, the meaning of h(/ttw ei)=nai tw=n h(donw=n is explained (353C: next, it is shown that pleasures are called evil when they bring pain in their train or loss of pleasure, not because they are pleasant themselves (353C354A, and that pains are called good because they bring pleasure in their train or escape from pain, not because they are painful themselves (354A354C; therefore pleasure in
itself is good, and pain evil (354CE). The rest of the chapter forms an introduction to the chapter which follows.
3. e)le/gomen is more humble than le/gomen—the idea is ‘used to call’ till you said it was wrong.
4. a)kou/ete dh/: Socrates bespeaks ‘Attention!’ like a herald. a)kou/ete lew/| (e.g. Ar. Peace, 551) was the usual way of beginning a proclamation at Athens. Cf. Apol. 20D, 32A, Theaet. 201D.

5. a)/llo ti. This, the shorter form of this particle of interrogation, is probably not a deliberate abbreviation for a)/llo ti h)/. Thus a)/llo ti tou=to a)lhqe/s e)stin = ‘this is true—anything else?’ i.e. isn't it?, the words being thrown in parenthetically like nicht wahr and n'est ce pas.

6. e)n toi=sde—oi/=on: toi=sde would lead us to expect an enumeration of the cases: as it is, only examples are given. The effect of the Greek may be brought out by ‘in the following cases—that often for example, etc.’ With this punctuation it is needless to write (as Kroschel does) toioi=sde for toi=sde.
8. gignw/skontes o(/ti ponhra/ e)stin: cf. Meno, 77C h)= ga\r dokei= soi, w)= *me/nwn, gignw/skwn ta\ kaka\ o(/ti kaka/ e)stin o(/mws e)riqumei=n au)tw=n; ma/lista.
14. ka)\n ei)/: see note on 328Aabove.

16. o(/mws d' a)\n kaka\ h)=n. So the MSS.: most recent editors (except Kral) read ei)/h. The imperfect is used because the answer ‘No’ is expected and desired: would they be evil just because they give us pleasure? Certainly not. See Goodwin, M.T. p. 190, § 503. Schleiermacher wrongly rejected de/ after o(/mws: the ‘apodotic de/’ is frequent after o(/mws, w(sau/tws, ou(/tw and the like.

16. o(/ ti maqo/nta poiei= ktl. So the MSS. A variety of emendations have been proposed for maqo/nta, such as a(marto/nta (Schleiermacher, followed by Heindorf), a)maqai/nonta (Orelli), paro/nta (Hermann), paqo/nta (Sauppe and others), while Kroschel doubts the entire passage h)=n—o(ph|ou=n, saying ‘Totus autem locus ita comparatus est ut de eius emendatione desperandum esse videatur’. It would be natural to regard this particular passage as corrupt if this were an isolated example of the idiom in question; but—not to mention other authors—it occurs also in the following passages of Plato: Apol. 36B ti/
a)/cio/s ei)mi paqei=n h)\ a)poti=sai, o(/ ti maqw
 e)n tw=| bi/w| ou)x h(suxi/an h)=gon; Euthyd. 283E ei) mh\ a)groiko/teron—h)=n ei)pei=n, ei)=pon a)/n, soi\ ei)s kefalh/n, o(/ ti maqw
 e)mou=—katayeu/dei ktl.; ibid. 299A polu\ me/ntoi—dikaio/tepon a)
 to
 u(me/tepon rate/pa tu/rtoimi, o(/ ti maqw
 sofou\s ui(ei=s ou(/tws e)/fusen. In each of these cases the MSS. reading maqw/n (not paqw/n) should be retained. In the direct speech ti/ maqw/n is used in an impatient question: ti/ maqw
 tou=to e)poi/hsas is ‘what ever made you think of doing this?’ (e.g. Ar. Clouds, 1506, Wasps, 251, Ach. 826): cf. the idiom ti/ lhrei=s e)/xwn; in which ti/ depends on e)/xwn (see Kühner, Gr. Gr. II, 624). ti/ maqw/n becomes in the indirect o(/ ti maqw/n, but in every case in which this phrase occurs in Plato o(/ ti maqw/n means not ‘why’ but ‘because’. The transition in meaning is sometimes explained as parallel to the use of oi)=os, o(/sos, w(s etc. for o(/ti toiou=tos, o(/ti tosou=tos, o(/ti ou(/tws, so that o(/ ti maqw/n = o(/ti tou=to maqw/n; but a simpler explanation is perhaps possible (see my edition of the Apol. Appendix II, p. 123). o(/ ti maqw/n is an impatient o(/ ti just as ti/ maqw/n is an impatient ti/; but as o(/ti and o(/ ti are in reality the same word (see on 333B, and o(/ti means ‘because’, o(/ ti maqw/n comes also to mean ‘because’ (impatiently), the original interrogative force being lost. Similarly, in sentences like lhrei=s e)/xwn, the interrogation is dropped, and the participle alone survives, conveying the same sense of blame or impatience as in ti/ lhrei=s e)/xwn; which is probably the form of sentence in which this idiom originated. Here maqo/nta is of course the nom. plur.; if (as we suppose) the original force of the participle is no longer felt in this idiom, there is nothing harsh in finding it in agreement with a neuter subject.

29. ou)kou=n pa/lin a)\n—e)roi/meqa. There is no sufficient reason for changing a)/n to au)= or for omitting a)/n: a)/n points forward to the apodosis in l. 35 fai=en a)/n and is just as idiomatic as a)/n in w(/sper a)\n ei), e.g. in 311Babove.

31. oi/=on ta/ te gumna/sia ktl. Rep. II. 357C tri/ton de\ o(ra=|s ti—ei)=dos a)gaqou=, e)n w(=| to\ gumna/zesqai kai\ to\ ka/mnonta i)atpeu/esqai kai\ i)a/tpeusi/s te kai\ o( a)/llos xphmatismo/s; tau=ta ga\p e)ri/rona fai=men a)/n, w)felei=n de\ h(ma=s, kai\ au)ta\ me\n e(autw=n e(/neka ou)k a)\n decai/meqa e)/xein, tw=n de\ misqw=n te xa/rin kai\ tw=n a)/llwn o(/sa gi/gnetai a)p' au)tw=n.

32. ta\s stratei/as. Ar. Eth. Nic. X. 7. 1177b. 9 ou)dei\s ga\r ai(rei=tai to\ polemei=n tou= polemei=n e(/neka, ou)de\ paraskeua/zei po/lemon:
do/cai ga\r a)\n pantelw=s miaifo/nos tis ei)=nai, ei) tou\s fi/lous polemi/ous poioi=to, i(/na ma/xai kai\ fo/noi gignointo.

33. kau/sew/n te—limoktoniw=n. Gorg. 521E polla\ u(ma=s kai\ kaka\ o(/de ei)/rgastai a(nh/r (sc. o( i)atro/s)—te/mnwn te kai\ ka/wn, kai\ i)sxnai/nwn kai\ rni/gwn—rikpo/tata rw/mata didou\s kai\ reinh=n kai\ diyh=n a)nagka/zwn. limoktoni/a (‘Hungerkur’, says Stallbaum) is part of the mikra\ di/aita of Rep. III. 406D.

40. a)/llwn a)rxai/: ‘dominions over others’—not a)/llwn po/lewn: cf. Gorg. 452D ai)/tion a(/ma me\n e)leuqeri/as au)toi=s toi=s a)nqrw/pois, a)/ma de\ tou= a)/llwn a)/rxein e)n th=| au(tou= po/lei e(ka/stw|. Heindorf's conjecture a)/llai (i.e. ‘besides’) is not necessary, in view of Gorg. 514A (quoted by Sauppe) h)\ xrh/mata polla\ lamba/nein h)\ a)rxh/n tinwn h)\ a)/llhn du/namin h(ntinou=n.
44. a)ll' h)\ h(dona/s is Stephanus' emendation for a)ll' h(dona/s.
47. w(s a)gaqo\n o)/n: the copula is attracted to the predicate, as regularly: cf. below, 359Dto\ h(/ttw ei)=vai e(autou= hu(re/qh a)maqi/a ou)=sa.

64. ei)/ me a)ne/roisqe: without the fai/hn a)/n which we should expect. Socrates apostrophises the a)/nqrwpoi as if they stood before him; the fai/hn a)\n e)/gwge of l. 66 is part of what Socrates says to the a)/nqrwpoi.
68. e)n tou/tw|: see on 310Dabove. pa=sai ai( a)podei/ceis means all the proofs that pleasure is good and pain evil.
69. a)naqe/sqai suggests (as often) draughts-playing: a comparison which is worked up into a simile by Plato in Rep. VI. 487B-C.
71. h)\ to\ kako\n a)/llo ti. B and T have h)/ before a)/llo ti by a natural mistake: it is corrected in T by a later hand.
77. a)/nqrwpos: so the MSS., but o( a)/nqrwpos in line 80. Kroschel refers to the variation in 321Da)/nqrwpon—tw=| a)nqrw/pw| —a)nqrw/pw?—a)/nqrwpos. Cf. below 355E
79. kai\ au)=qis au)= le/gete. We should of course expect le/ghte, but the second part of a logically subordinate clause in Greek tends to become an independent clause: see on 313A

div.head: CHAPTER XXXVII
div.p: The meaning of the phrase ‘to be overcome by pleasure’ is now explained in conformity with the results of the last chapter.

If we substitute ‘good’ for ‘pleasure’ the common saying that we do evil, knowing it to be evil, because overcome by ‘pleasure’, becomes ‘we do evil knowing it to be evil, because overcome by good’ (355BC). ‘To be overcome by good’ is shown to be the choosing of greater evil in place of lesser good (D-E). Similarly, substituting pleasure for good, and pain for evil, we have the sentiment ‘we do the painful, knowing it to be painful, because overcome by pleasure’, and here also ‘to be overcome by pleasure’ is to choose in place of lesser pleasures greater pains (355E356A. No doubt in this case the pleasures are present and the pains remote, but we make allowance for this in our process of weighing pleasures and pains against themselves and one another (356AC). ‘Near’ and ‘Far’ have the same bewildering effect on the eyes when we look at size and number; but there the arts of measurement and of arithmetic resolve our perplexity (356C357A. In like manner there must be some art or knowledge whose function it is to settle the value of ‘more’ and ‘less’, ‘near’ and ‘far’, etc., in their application to pleasure and pain. In other words to\ h(donh=s h(tta=sqai is due to ignorance (357A357E.

2. xrw/meqa a(/ma. a(/ma is due to a correction in one inferior MS., approved by Cobet and Kroschel; BT have xrw/meqa a)/ra. If we read xrw/meqa a)/ra, there are difficulties serious enough to suggest an error in the reading: (1) the position of a)/ra is to say the least most unusual: no example is quoted of a)/ra coming at the end of a conditional clause in this way; (2) is a)/ra to be taken with e)a/n in the usual sense (si forte) or as inferential? The inferential meaning strikes us as somewhat far-fetched, and the other is both inappropriate here and impossible from the position of the particle. On the other hand a(/ma is almost necessary to the sense; without a(/ma, the words e)a\n mh\—xrw/meqa
would not correctly describe Socrates' procedure in the following discussion, in which he does use all four names. But as he does not use them together, his procedure is accurately described by the addition of a(/ma to xrw/meqa.

6. qe/menoi—ou(/tw: ou(/tw is explained by o(/ti gignw/skwn— au)ta\ poiei=: ‘let us lay it down and say, etc.’ The thesis of the many is stated in order to be demolished. With the style of reasoning which follows cf. Gorg. 499A-B, where (as a reduction ad absurdum of the view that pleasure is good and pain evil) it is argued that in that case the bad man would be just as bad and just as good as the good man since he feels just as much pain and pleasure as the other: see also Alc. I, 116 A a)=r' ou)=n kai\ h(=| a)gaqo
 kalo/n, h(=| de\ kako
 ai)sxpo/n; vai/. th
 a)/pa e)n tw=| role/mw| toi=s fi/lois boh/qeian le/gwn kalh
 me
 ei)=nai, kakh
 de/, ou)de
 diafepo/ntws le/geis h)\ ei) prosei=pes au)th
 a)gaqh
 me/n, kakh
 de/.
10. u(po\ me\n h(donh=s. The antithesis is not expressed by a de/ clause but in e)kei/nw| dh\—tou= a)gaqou= below.
11. metei/lhfen: the subject is h(donh/ and to\ a)gaqo/n is in apposition to a)/llo o)/noma. a)nti\ th=s h(donh=s means ‘in place of pleasure’, i.e. the name pleasure.

18. e)n u(mi=n: not ‘before your tribunal’, but ‘in you’, i.e. inside you, in your souls. The idea is of a conflict between the good and evil in the soul before you do the evil. e)n u(mi=n might have been e)n au)tw=?, but the u(bristh/s now selects his interlocutors as his examples. The subtle reasoning which follows may be put thus: We do evil, knowing it to be evil, because we are overcome by good. But—since that which we do is evil—the good which overcomes is less worthy than the evil in us which it overcomes. ‘Less worthy’ (to overcome) means that ‘there is less of it’: to be overcome by good is therefore to choose less good than evil. The argument is extraordinarily ingenious but hardly sound— the flaw lies in substituting ‘the evil in us’ for ‘us’; it was not ‘the evil in us’, but ‘we’ who were overcome by good. See also Introduction, p. xxvi. The usual way of taking e)n u(mi=n as ‘before your tribunal’ or the like (cf. Gorg. 464D) makes the false step much more serious—since it substitutes not ‘the evil in us’ but simply ‘the evil’ for ‘us’.

21. a)na/cia/ e)stin ta)gaqa\ tw=n kakw=n should be translated literally—‘the good is unworthy of the bad’. The expression— in Greek as in English—is somewhat strained in order to correspond to ou)k a)ci/wn above (l. 17); but after all ‘I am unworthy of you’ is much the same as ‘I am less worthy than you’. The Greeks can even use a)na/cios in the sense of ‘more worthy than’, ‘too good for’: e.g. Soph. Philoct. 1009.

22. ta\ me\n mei/zw—h)=|: i.e. when ta\ kaka/ are mei/zw and ta\ a)gaqa\ smikro/tera, then ta)gaqa/ are a)na/cia tw=n kakw=n: ta\ kaka/ are a)na/cia tw=n a)gaqw=n, when ta\ a)gaqa/ are mei/zw, and ta\ kaka\ smikro/tera. Similarly with plei/w and e)la/ttw. It must be borne in mind that a)/cios does not here denote moral, but rather physical strength or value: good is a)na/cion kakou=, because it is smaller or less numerous.
23. plei/w, ta\ de\ e)la/ttw h)=|. See on 330A
26. metala/bwmen, i.e. ‘let us change and take the names pleasant and painful and apply them to, etc.’ Cf. below 356D e)pi/ follows o)no/mata as in ti/qesqai o)/noma e)pi/ tini and the like.

31. kai\ ti/s a)/llh a)naci/a. This—the MSS. reading—is undoubtedly right. Plato coins the word a)naci/a for ‘unworthiness’ to complete the parallel with D above: cf. ll. 17-21 ou)k a)ci/wn o)/ntwn nika=n—kata\ ti/ de\—a)na/cia/ e)stin ta)gaqa\ tw=n kakw=n ktl. Similarly in Phaedo, 105E, Plato coins a)na/rtios, in 106A a)/qermos (rightly accepted, in spite of MS. authority, by editors) and a)/yuktos (see MSS., but Wyttenbach's a)/yuxros is—we think rightly—accepted by some editors) as pointed and convenient negatives to a)/rtios, qermo/s, yuxro/s. Cicero's translation ‘quae igitur potest esse indignitas voluptatis ad molestiam, nisi in magnitudine aut in longitudine alterius utrius posita?’ (Nobbe's Cicero, p. 1313) shows that a)naci/a was read in his time: so in Ficinus' ‘quae vero alia inest ad dolorem indignitas voluptati quam excessus inter se atque defectus?’ The word a)naci/a hardly took root in Greek, though occasionally found in the writings of the Stoics, whose regular word for this notion is a)paci/a. h(donh=| (now found to be the reading of some MSS.) for h(donh/ is due to Heindorf.

33. tau=ta d' e)sti/: as Sauppe remarks, we should expect
tau=ta d' e)sti\ to\ mei/zw—gi/gnesqai, but the words are said as if for kai\ ti/s a)/llh a)naci/a ktl. had been written kai\ pw=s a)/llws a)na/cia ta\ h(de/a rpo\s ta\ lurhpa/, a)ll' h)\ u(repba/llonta a)llh/lwn kai\ e)llei/ponta;

35. ma=llon kai\ h(=tton: this case is not given above (D-E) because the notion of intensity is more applicable to pleasure (and pain) than to good (and evil): cf. Phileb. 24A ff. with 27E h(donh\ kai\ lu/ph pe/ras e)/xeton, h)\ tw=n to\ ma=llo/n te kai\ h(=tton dexome/nwn e)oto/n; nai/, tw=n to\ ma=llon, w)= *sw/krates.

ei) ga/r tis le/goi. So far we have reached this point. To be overcome by pleasure is to choose in place of lesser pleasures greater pains and the like. But here the element of time comes in: a man might fairly say—yes, but the pleasures are now, the pains remote. Socrates tries to show that this makes no real difference.

36. to\ paraxrh=ma h(du/. When we are overcome by pleasure, we do the pleasant, not the painful: therefore the contrast is between the present pleasure and the remote consequences, whether pleasure or pain. For this reason it would be wrong to supply kai\ luphro/n after h(du/.

39. a)ll' w(/sper a)gaqo\s i(sta/nai ktl. Cf. Rep. X. 602D a)=r' ou)=n ou) to\ metrei=n kai\ a)riqmei=n kai\ i(sta/nai boh/qeiai xarie/statai rpo\s au)ta\ e)fa/nhsan, w(/ste mh\ a)/pxein e)n h(mi=n to\ faino/menon mei=zon h)\ e)/latton h)\ ple/on h)\ baru/teron ktl.;
40. kai\ to\ e)llu\s ktl.: in order that a near pleasure might count for more than a remote.

42. e)a
 me
 ga h(de/a ktl. Cf. Laws, v. 733B h(donh
 boulo/meqa h(mi=n ei)=nai, lu/rhn de\ ou)/q' ai(pou/meqa ou)/te boulo/meqa, to\ de\ mhde/tepon a)nti\ me
 h(donh=s ou) boulo/meqa, lu/rhs de\ a)lla/ttesqai boulo/meqa: lu/rhn de\ e)la/ttw meta\ mei/zonos h(donh=s boulo/meqa, h(donh
 de\ e)la/ttw meta\ mei/zonos lu/phs ou) boulo/meqa ktl.

45. e)a/n te ta\ e)ggu\s ktl. When once you have equated ‘near’ and ‘far’ (see above), then (but not till then) your final choice is not affected by the question of proximity in time. Theoretically, no doubt, this is right; but no man is so a)gaqo\s i(sta/nai as to weigh e)ggu/s and po/rrw correctly; whence the saying ‘Let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we die’. ‘Near’ and ‘far’ can only be weighed aright on the supposition that man is immortal and will live hereafter under the same
moral laws as rule us here: but of immortality there is no hint in this dialogue.
47. tau=ta: i.e. ta\ h(de/a.
51. o(/te: the notion of time readily passes into that of cause, as in quoniam and cum.

52. fai/netai u(mi=n ktl. Two examples are given: (1) size— of which paxe/a and fwnai\ mega/lai (according to the Greek and Roman way of viewing sound) are special varieties, (2) number, i.e. ta\ polla/. The specific varieties paxe/a and fwnai\ mega/lai are not dealt with in the sequel. With what follows compare (besides Rep. X. 602D cited above) Euthyphr. 7B ff. and Alc. I, 126C ff., and with the present passage Phileb. 42A and Rep. VII. 523C524C. The resolution by the intellect of such contradictory sense-perceptions is made the basis of Plato's scheme of higher education in the Republic.
55. ai( i)/sai is Heindorf's correction for i)/sai.
57. mh/kh—pra/ttein: as we h(de/a pra/ttomen. pra/ttein (with mh/kh) is explained by lamba/nein: see above on 314A
59. h( metrhtikh\ te/xnh. See Introduction, p. xxix.
60. h)\ h( tou= fainome/nou du/namis. h)/ is omitted in B and T. ‘The power of that which appears’ is its power to affect us.

61. e)pla/na kai\ e)poi/ei ktl. a)/n is not to be supplied. Plato is reverting to the illustration in C. The imperfect is idiomatic for ‘causes us, as we saw, to wander’, etc. (viz. because ta\ au)ta\ mege/qh seem to us both mei/zw and e)la/ttw): it is what Goodwin calls the ‘philosophic imperfect’: cf. Crito, 47D diafqerou=men e)kei=no kai\ lwbhso/meqa, o(\ tw=| me
 dikai/w| be/ltion e)gi/gneto (becomes as we saw), tw=? de\ a)di/kw? a)pw/lluto. By adding kai\ e)n tai=s pra/cesin —smikrw=n Plato treats his hypothesis that eu)= pra/ttein is to select mega/la mh/kh as a fact; he does so also in a)
 e)poi/hse ktl. i.e. ‘would have made’, viz. if we had made use of it, but we did not. If the hypothesis were still treated as a hypothesis, we should have had a)
 e)poi/ei (and not a)
 e)poi/hse) to correspond to what would then have been a)
 (expressed or understood) e)pla/na kai\ e)poi/ei.
a)/nw te kai\ ka/tw. a)/nw ka/tw (Theaet. 195C) and a)/nw kai\ ka/tw (Gorg. 495A) are other forms of this proverbial phrase.

77. a)riqmhtikh/. In Gorg. 451B ff. a)riqmhtikh/ is said to be a science concerned with to\ a)/rtio/n te kai\ peritto/n, o(/sa e(ka/tera tugxa/nei o)/nta, whereas the function which is here assigned to a)riqmhtikh/ is there given to logistikh/: ta\ me\n a)/lla kaqa/per h( a)piqmhtikh\ h( logistikh\ e)/xei: repi\ to\ au)to\ ga/p e)stin to/ te a)/ption kai\ to\ repitto/n: diafe/pei de\ tosou=ton, o(/ti kai\ rpo\s au(ta\ kai\ rpo\s a)/llhla pw=s e)/xei plh/qons (cf. ll. 71 ff. to\ ple/on—to\ e)/latton h)\ au)to\ pro\s e(auto\ h)\ to\ e(/teron pro\s to\ e(/teron) e)piskopei= to\ peritto\n kai\ to\ a)/rtion h( logistikh/.

79. ei)=en—e)pei\ de\ dh/. The MSS. read e)peidh\ de/, but after ei)=en Plato regularly uses de\ dh/ in coming to the application of a train of reasoning or illustrations: cf. 312Eei)=en: o( de\ dh\ sofisth\s peri\ ti/nos deino\n poiei= le/gein; and 311Cei)=en—para\ de\ dh\ *prwtago/ran ktl.

87. ei)sau=qis skeyo/meqa. Siebeck, who asserts (Zur Chronologie der Platonischen Dialogen, pp. 121 ff.) that this and similar formulas were intended by Plato to be a distinct promise of future dialogues (if not a reference to a later part of the same dialogue), finds here a reference to Politicus, 283D ff., where the ‘measuring art’ is discussed and described as the basilikh\ te/xnh.
90. h(ni/ka h(mei=s—w(mologou=men: 352Bff.
93. e)/fate: in 352D The original h)/resqe has to be repeated in consequence of the introduction of this independent clause.
95. h)/resqe: in 353A

98. ei)/pate: but ei)/paton in 353A otherwise there is no change in the quotation. B and T have ei)/pete, but Stobaeus (who cites from tosou=ton in 357Bto megi/sth 357Ein his Florilegium) reads ei)/pate. According to Rutherford (New Phrynichus, p. 219) ei)/pete is not Attic, but this is doubtful, if any faith can be placed in MS. authority.

104. h(=s to\ pro/sqen. This—the reading of the best MSS.— has been unjustly rejected in favour of ei)s to\ pro/sqen; but ei)s to\
pro/sqen can hardly be justified here. Sauppe refers to 339Do)li/gon de\ tou= poih/matos ei)s to\ pro/sqen proelqw/n, where, however, ei)s to\ pro/sqen goes with proelqw/n, and in all the cases which he quotes there is a verb containing the idea of progress to go with the phrase, and so in Ar. Knights. 751 a)ll' e)s to\ pro/sqe xrh\ parei=n' e)s th
 pu/kna (where probably we should read parie/n' for parei=n' as in Ach. 43 pa/rit' e)s to\ pro/sqen). Where there is no such verb (which is very rarely the case), the phrase means ‘with a view to what lies in front’, e.g. Alcib. I, 132B ou)kou=n tosou=ton me
 h(mi=n ei)s to\ pro/sqen pepe/rantai. It need hardly be said that the phrase cannot mean simply e)/mprosqen. On the other hand h(=s seems to be just what is needed: the construction in full would be kai\ ou) mo/non e)pisth/mhs (e)ndei/a|), a)lla\ kai\ (tau/ths th=s e)pisth/mhs e)ndei/a|) h(
 to\ pro/sqen e)/ti w(mologh/kate o(/ti metrhtikh/ (sc. e)sti: for the omission of e)sti/ after o(/ti cf. below 359Da)pedei/xqh a)/rti o(/ti a)du/naton): ‘and from lack, not merely of knowledge, but of the knowledge which you have further admitted above to be measuring knowledge’. The attraction of the relative extends to metrhtikh/ also in spite of o(/ti: cf. Apol. 37B w(=n eu)= oi)=d' o(/ti kakw=n o)/ntwn for tou/twn a(\ eu)= oi)=d' o(/ti kaka\ o)/nta (o(/ti being used with the participle as in Gorg. 481E: see note on Apol. loc. cit.).

108. a)maqi/a h( megi/sth: cf. Laws, III. 689A ti/s ou)=n h( megi/sth dikai/ws a)
 le/goito a)maqi/a;—tau/thn th
 diafwni/an lu/rhs te kai\ h(donh=s rpo\s th
 kata\ lo/gon do/can a)maqi/an fhmi\ ei)=nai th
 e)sxa/thn, megi/sthn de/, o(/ti tou= plh/qous e)sti\ th=s yuxh=s.

110. ou)/te au)toi/: the verb hangs fire: we should expect Plato to continue ou)/te oi( u(me/teroi pai=des e)/rxontai ktl. Stephanus thought prose/rxesqe had fallen out after au)toi/, Madvig i)/te, while Kroschel suggests ou)/t' e)foita=te au)toi/. It seems probable that the text is corrupt; at all events no parallel has yet been adduced. The two cases quoted by Sauppe (Dem. pro\s *)/afobon, § 54, and pseudo-Dem. pro\s *timo/qeon, § 52) are more than doubtful in respect of their text, which (as Sauppe quotes it) is not according to the MSS. Madvig's i)/te is simplest, but the future seems out of place: perhaps h)=|te should be read.
112. w(s ou) didaktou= o)/ntos: i.e. tou= mh\ h(donh=s h(tta=sqai.

div.head: CHAPTER XXXVIII
div.p: Socrates begins to apply the results of the previous discussion to the subject of his dispute with Protagoras.
Pleasure is good and pain evil, and no one willingly encounters what he believes to be evil. But fear is the expectation of evil: therefore no one will willingly encounter what he fears.
3. w)= *(ippi/a te kai\ *pro/dike. Here and in 358Eand 359Aw)= has dropped out in the MSS. after preceding -w. The effect of its omission would be to render the address unduly abrupt.

3. u(mi=n. So the MSS. Sauppe's h(mi=n is not necessary. u(mi=n means all three sophists: and o( lo/gos is not the discussion as a whole, but the speaking, viz. in answer (cf. dou=nai kai\ de/casqai lo/gon). Throughout this chapter all the sophists reply: in the next Socrates makes use of their united admissions to destroy Protagoras alone.
7. diai)resin tw=n o)noma/twn: see note on 314C

9. ei)/te o(po/qen kai\ o(/pws—o)noma/zwn. This mode of address insinuates that Prodicus was a qei=os a)nh/r, since a god was addressed in a similar way. See Crat. 400E w(/sper e)n tai=s eu)xai=s no/mos e)sti\n h(mi=n eu)/xesqai, oi(/tine/s te kai\ o(ro/qen xai/pousin o)nomazo/menoi and cf. Euthyd. 288A qauma/sia/ ge le/get', w)= a)/ndres *qou/rioi, ei)/te *xi=oi ei)/q' o(po/qen kai\ o(/ph| xai/reton o)nomazo/menoi and Symp. 212C o(/ ti kai\ o(/ph| xai/reis o)noma/zwn, tou=to o)no/maze. A similar effect is produced in Symp. 176C by the words *swkra/th d' e)cairw= lo/gou, since there was a proverb to\ qei=on e)cairw= lo/gou: cf. Rep. VI. 492E qei=on me/ntoi kata\ th\n paroimi/an e)cairw=men lo/gou. The multitude of epithets given to gods is best illustrated by such a hymn as the Homeric Hymn to Ares, ll. 1 ff. *)=ares u(repmene/ta, bpisa/pmate, xpuseorh/lhc, o)bpimo/qume, fe/pasri. polisso/e, xalkokorusta\ ktl. In the multitude of names the suppliant hopes to include the acceptable one.
11. pro\s o(\ bou/lomai: emphatic, ‘with a view to my meaning’ )( pro\s o(\ o)noma/zw.

13. e)pi\ tou/tou. This usage can only be on the analogy of h( e)pi\ *sa/rdewn o(do/s and the like: actions are looked on as ways leading to a goal or destination or te/los: cf. above 354Cand D.
To take the words (with Sauppe) as ‘in the case of this’, ‘in this domain’, would give a wrong meaning; the moral character of an act being determined by its end, it is kalo/n only if its end is kalo/n. The expression is however very curious, and perhaps unique. I once thought that a(/pasai might conceal some present participle such as a)/gousai—agreeing with pra/ceis: but the occurrence of a(pa/sas below in 359Eshows a(/pasai to be probably genuine here. The reasoning is this. Pleasure, the end, is good, pain evil; consequently all actions aiming at the end are kalai/, and therefore good (as usual w)fe/limos is but a synonym for ‘good’); therefore— as no one willingly selects evil rather than good—no one willingly does the worse (i.e. selects evil actions) when he might act better. As it is with pra/ceis that bravery and cowardice are concerned, it is necessary for Plato to establish that ‘no one willingly seeks the worse’ is true of individual acts as well as of ultimate ends.
14. a)=r' ou) kalai/. The words kai\ w)fe/limoi which follow ou) kalai/ in the MSS. are rightly rejected because they anticipate the identification in the next line.
17. h)\ a(\ poiei=, kai\ dunata/ is Heindorf's emendation of the corrupt h)\ a(\ e)poi/ei kai\ du/natai of the MSS.

18. h(/ttw ei)=nai au(tou= ktl. The phrases h(/ttwn au(tou= and krei/ttwn e(autou= are here substituted for h(/ttwn th=s h(donh=s and krei/ttwn th=s h(donh=s. Cf. the discussions in Rep. IV. 430E ff. and Laws, I. 626E ff., where krei/ttw and h(/ttw ei)=nai e(autou= are interpreted as the victory of the better part in us over the worse and conversely. As the worse part is the part which seeks h(donh/, i.e. to\ e)piqumhtiko/n, the identification is just.
30. kalei=te/ ti de/os. Heindorf's emendation for kalei=te de/os of the MSS. See note on 330Cabove.

31. prosdoki/antina\—kakou=: a common definition; cf. Lach. 198B de/os ga\r ei)=nai prosdoki/an me/llontos kakou=. fo/bos in Laws, 1. 644C is defined as ‘expectation before pain’ (pro\ lu/phs e)lpi/s).

46. de/os, fo/bos d' ou)/. Prodicus' distinction is just, though
often dropped in practice: in fo/bos ‘the physical agitation due to present danger (h( parauti/ka pto/hsis, says Ammonius) is the leading idea’, in de/os the apprehension of evil to come (kakou= u(po/noia). See note on Euthyphr. 12B, where Plato implicitly recognises the difference.
35. a)lla\ to/de: sc. diafe/rei. ou)de\n diafe/rei does not of course mean ‘there is no difference’, but ‘it doesn't matter’.

div.head: CHAPTER XXXIX
div.p: It is here proved that courage is wisdom.

Socrates first reverts to the point at which the discussion on h(donh=s h(tta=sqai began (359AC): next, Protagoras asserts that a)ndrei=oi and deiloi/ are willing to encounter opposite things, but Socrates shows that both encounter what they take to be qarrale/a, i.e., so far, the same things (359CE). Protagoras thereupon objects that a)ndrei=oi will encounter e.g. war, while deiloi/ will not. Socrates replies by showing that if cowards do not willingly enter upon war, the reason is their ignorance (359E60A). In general, while brave men fear and feel courage honourably, i.e. well, the reverse is true of cowards, owing to their ignorance (360A360B. And since it is through deili/a that men are deiloi/, and we have shown that men are deiloi/ through a)maqi/a tw=n deinw=n kai\ mh\ deinw=n, cowardice is ignorance, and consequently bravery is wisdom, viz. deinw=n te kai\ mh\ deinw=n (360C360E.
4. to/te: 330Aff.
7. to\ u(/steron: 349Dff.
17. h)ro/mhn: 349E
18. kai\ i)/tas g', e)/fh. The recapitulation stops here. e)/fhn e)gw/ two lines below is the usual ‘said I’ of narrated dialogue.

20. e)pi\ ti/: so MSS.: the second hand in B reads e)pi\ ti/na, but cf. below, l. 26, where the question is repeated with e)pi\ ti/. For the common passage from singular to plural the editors compare Phaedo, 58C ti/ h)=n ta\ lexqe/nta kai\ praxqe/nta;
24. deina/: the MSS. read deila/ by mistake, and so in 360Cbelow deilw=n three times for deinw=n.
28. e)n oi(=s su\ e)/leges toi=s lo/gois: see on 342B

31. e)peidh\ to\ h(/ttw—a)maqi/a ou)=sa. The only proof given that we ‘encounter evils believing them to be evils’ was the phrase h)/ttw ei)=nai h(donh=s (for which h(/ttw ei)=nai e(autou= is here substituted: see on 358C. We have demolished this proof by showing that the phrase means a)maqi/a, and we therefore infer that e)pi\ a(\ deina\ h(gei=tai ei)=nai ou)dei\s e)/rxetai (deina/ being a subdivision of kaka/).
32. hu(re/qh. The MSS. have eu(re/qh: but see on 315B
37. au)ti/ka: ‘veluti, ne longe hinc abeam’ (Kroschel) and so ‘for example’: a very frequent use in Plato.
38. po/teron—kalo\n o)\n ktl. Cf. 349E
41. e)/mprosqen: 358B
51. ka/llio/n te. The MSS. read kalo/n te. Stephanus made the necessary change.

56. kai\ oi( deiloi\ kai\ oi( qrasei=s kai\ oi( maino/menoi. In 350Bff. those who are qarrale/oi without e)pisth/mh are called maino/menoi by an expressive metaphor. Here the maino/menoi— which is suggested, but no more—by the maino/menoi in 350Bmdash; are treated as a distinct class: the word is to be understood of literal madmen like Ajax in the play of Sophocles. The word qrasei=s has an evil connotation as in Laws, I. 630B qrasei=s kai\ a)/dikoi kai\ u(bristai\ kai\ a)frone/statoi sxedo\n a(pa/ntwn: Plato could not have said qarrale/oi here since qarrale/oi throughout the dialogue is applied also to a)ndrei=oi. It would be better to reject (with Kral) both kai\ oi( qrasei=s and kai\ oi( maino/menoi than only kai\ oi( qrasei=s with Sauppe and Schanz; we should then—as throughout this chapter—have only one negative to a)ndrei=oi, viz. deiloi/, but we may allow some latitude of expression to Socrates, and kai/ after ou)kou=n is slightly in favour of supposing that other classes follow oi( deiloi/, though it may go with the whole sentence.
67. e)pe/neusen: Protagoras dies hard: see on Euthyphr. 8A.
73. ou)/te—te: see on 309B
75. au)to/s—pe/ranon. Gorg. 506C le/ge, w)gaqe/, au)to\s kai\ pe/ranon.

78. filonikei=n—to\ e)me\ ei)=nai. For the orthography of filonikei=n see note on 336Eabove. Apparently filonikei=n is not elsewhere used in Plato with the accusative, but the construction is a natural one and occurs in Thucydides: in Rep. I. 338A we have prosepoiei=to de\ filonikei=n pro\s to\ e)me\ ei)=nai to\n a)pokrino/menon.

div.head: CHAPTER XL
div.p: Socrates points out that while Protagoras' theory would point to the conclusion that virtue is not teachable, he himself in trying to prove that virtue is knowledge goes near to maintaining that it is. Thus the interlocutors have as it were changed places. The dialogue ends with mutual compliments.

3. au)to\ h( a)reth/: ‘virtue itself’, literally ‘virtue, the thing itself’. Cf. Crat. 411D ei) de\ bou/lei, au)to\ h( no/hsis tou= ne/ou e)sti\n e(/sis, Theaet. 146E gnw=nai e)pisth/mhn au)to\ o(/ ti/ pot' e)sti/n: ‘au)to/ (per se) substantivis et adiectivis adiunctum rei alicuius naturam acvim per se et universe spectatam significat’, says Ast. This use of au)to/s furnished Plato (as in au)toa/nqrwpos and the like) with a convenient way of denoting his Ideas, but here of course au)to/ does not denote the Idea but is ipsum as opposed to ta\ peri\ th=s a)reth=s.
13. pa/nta xrh/mata: exaggeration—as if Socrates held e)pisth/mh to be the a)rxh/ of the universe and said e)pisth/mh pa/nta as Heraclitus might say pu=r pa/nta.
18. o(/lon: i.e. h( a)reth/—the gender is like au)to/ in line 3. Sauppe cites Meno, 79B e)mou= dehqe/ntos o(/lon ei)pei=n th\n a)reth/n.
21. e)/oiken speu/donti: a frequent usage in Plato; see on Apol. 27A e)/oiken ga\r—diapeirwme/nw|.
23. a)/nw ka/tw: see on 356Dabove.

26. e)celqei=n—e)pi\. There is a slight hint of military metaphor: ‘fare forth against virtue also to see what she is’, ‘also attack the question what is virtue’: cf. Rep. II. 374A o(\ (strato/pedon) e)celqo
—diamaxei=tai toi=s e)piou=sin: cf. the similar use of i)e/nai e)pi/ in Rep. v. 473C e)p' au)to\ dh/, h(=n d' e)gw/, ei)=mi o(\ tw=| megi/stw| proseika/zomen ku/mati. Here e)c- is appropriate, because the first campaign is as it were ended (tau=ta diecelqo/ntas): it is moreover natural to retain it, on account of the tendency noted on 311A A later hand in T has e)lqei=n, but the MSS. reading is unobjectionable, nor is there any need to read dielqei=n or diecelqei=n th
 a)reth/n as Kroschel suggests. For the sentiment cf. Meno, 100B to\ de\ safe\s peri\ au)tou= ei)so/meqa to/te, o(/tan pri
 w(/|tini tro/pw| toi=s a)nqpw/rois rapagi/gnetai a)peth/, rpo/tepon e)rixeiph/swmen au)to\ kaq' au(to\ zhtei=n ti/ pot' e(/stin a)reth/.
27. e)piske/yasqai peri\ au)tou=: Siebeck (in the treatise cited on p. 203) here and in 361Eei)sau=qis—die/cimen finds a promise of the Meno and the Gorgias.
28. mh( polla/kis: ne forte, as often in Plato. What often happens may happen in a future case: so Lucretius uses ‘saepe’ for ‘ut saepe fit’.
31. *promhqeu\s—promhqou/menos. Puns on proper names are frequent in Plato: see Riddell's Digest of Idioms, § 323.
34. kat' a)rxa/s, viz. 348Cff., 320B
37. ou)/te—te: see on 309B

40. w/=n e)ntugxa/nw: a somewhat rare attraction, since in the unattracted form the relative would be in the dative and not in the accusative case: cf. Theaet. 144A w(=n dh\ pw/pote e)ne/tuxon— kai\ pa/nu polloi=s peplhsi/aka—ou)de/na pw h)?sqo/mhn ktl., where Wohlrab cites also Gorg. 509A.
41. thlikou/twn: Socrates was about 36 at the date of action of the Protagoras.

*kalli/a| tw=| kalw=|: see on 336Babove. For kalw=| cf. Symp. 174A tau=ta dh\ e)kallwpisa/mhn i(/na kalo\s para\ kalo\n (viz. Agathon) i)/w. Sauppe reminds us of the use of kalo/s on vases, and also cites Ar. Ach. 143 e)n toi=si toi/xois e)/graf' *)aqhnai=oi kaloi/ (of Sitalces) and the famous *kriti/a| tou=t' e)/stw tw=| kalw=| of the dying Theramenes (Xen. Hell. II. 3. 56).

div.head: APPENDIX I - THE POEM OF SIMONIDES
div.p: The difficulties of this poem are well known, and have called forth many pages of comment.On p. 20 of his fourth edition of the Protagoras, Sauppe enumerates the discussions on the subject down to 1884. The most important contribution since that year is Das Gedicht des Simonides in Platons Protagoras, von J. Aars (Christiania, 1888). Aars's restoration has received the approval of Peppmüller (in the Berliner Philologische Wochenschrift for 1899, pp. 174 ff.) and others; and there now seems to be some prospect of finality in the criticism of the poem. In his programme (Das Simonideische Gedicht in Platons Protagoras und die Versuche dasselbe zu reconstruiren, Graz, 1889) Schwenk follows Aars in every essential point. The restoration proposed by Schneidewin has met with most favour, and is printed in most texts of the Protagoras, not because it is thought to be certain, but as the nearest approach to certainty of which the case admits. It may be at once allowed that no restoration can claim to represent with certainty just what Simonides wrote in the order in which it was written. Plato is seldom careful to make his quotations accurate, and the perverse exposition of the meaning of this particular poem is hardly calculated to increase our confidence in his verbal accuracy here. Nevertheless, Plato is our sole authority for the poem in question, and consequently that restoration will be the most probable which, while it satisfies every metrical requirement, involves the fewest changes in the text and sequence of the poem as it stands in Plato.
The words apparently quoted from the poem, as they occur in the Bodleian manuscript, are according to Schanz as follows (we note obvious corrections at the foot of the page).

p.foreign:
a)gaqo
 me
 a)laqe/ws gene/sqai xalepo
 xersi/
te kai\ posi\ kai\ no/w| tetra/gwnon a)/neu yo/gou tetugme/non

note.p: 4 *pitta/keion I (i.e. Vind. suppl. Phil. gr. 7) rightly.

p.foreign: ve/metai kai/toi sofou= para\ fwto\s ei)rhme/non xalepo\n fa/to

mh\ ou) kako
 e)/mmenai o(
 a)

div.p: 346C e)/moige e)carkei= o(\s a)\n mh\ kako\s h)=| mhd' a)/gan a)pa/lamnos ei)dw/s ge o)nh/sei po/ling' o)nhsi/polin after Bergk; Hermann o)nhsi/polin. di/kan u(gih\s a)nh/r ou) mh\n e)gw\ mwmh/somai ou) ga/r ei)mi filo/mwmos tw=n ga\o h)liqi/wn a)pei/rwn ge/neqlagene/qla. pa/nta toi kala\ toi=si/ t' ai)sxra\ mh\ me/miktai.

In 346DE part of the poem is paraphrased and repeated in the words ou) zhtw= pana/mwmon a)/nqrwpon eu)ruedou=s o(/soi karpo
 ai)nu/meqa xqono/s, e)/reiq' u(mi=n eu(pw
 a)raggele/w: w(/ste tou/tou g' e(/neka ou)de/na e)raine/somai, a)lla/ moi e)capkei= a)
 h)=| me/sos kai\ mhde
 kako
 roih=|, w(s e)gw\ pa/ntas file/w kai\ e)pai/nhmi e(kw
 o(/stis e(/rdh| mhde
 ai)sxro/n.

The only words whose place in the poem is somewhat doubtful are e)/moig' e)carkei= and ou) ga/r ei)mi filo/mwmos. They are excluded both by Bergk and Blass, but it is not likely that they come from Plato, since moi e)carkei= occurs also in the final recapitulation, and ou) dia\ tau=ta/ se ye/gw, o(/ti ei)mi\ filo/yogos is said (346C as well as ou) ga/r ei)mi filo/mwmos. Bonghi (quoted by Aars)p. 8, note 1. assigns the words oi)=o/n te me/ntoi e)pi/ ge xro/non tina/ in 344Bto a place in the poem after a)/neu yo/gou tetugme/non; it is however tolerably clear that they come from Socrates, who is merely developing the latent antithesis in xalepo/n.
Schneidewin'sIn his Delectus poesis Graecorum, p. 379. restoration is as follows:
xersi/n te kai\ posi\ kai\ no/w| tetra/gwnon a)/neu yo/gou tetugme/non,
(Desunt quinque versus.)
ou)de/ moi e)mmele/ws to\ *pitta/keion ne/metai,
kai/toi sofou= para\ fwto\s ei)rhme/non: xalepo\n fa/t' e)slo\n e)/mmenai.
qeo\s a)\n mo/nos tou=t' e)/xoi ge/ras: a)/ndra d' ou)k e)/sti mh\ ou) kako\n e)/mmenai,
o(\n a)\n a)ma/xanos sumfora\ kaqe/lh|.
pra/cais ga\r eu)= pa=s a)nh\r a)gaqo/s,
tou)pi/pleiston a)/ristoi, tou/s ke qeoi\ filw=sin.
mhd' a)/gan a)pa/lamnos ei)dw/s t' o)nhsi/polin di/kan, u(gih\s a)nh/r.
ou) ga\r e)gw\ filo/mwmos.
tw=n ga\r a)liqi/wn a)pei/rwn gene/qla.
pa/nta toi kala/, toi=si/ t' ai)sxra\ mh\ me/miktai.

p.foreign: tou)/neken ou)/pot' e)gw\ to\ mh\ gene/sqai dunato\n

div.p: dizh/menos, kenea\n e)s a)/prakton e)lpi/da moi=ran ai)w=nos bale/w,
pana/mwmon a)/nqrwpon, eu)ruedou=s o(/soi karpo\n ai)nu/meqa xqono/s.
e)/peit' u)/mmin eu)rw\n a)paggele/w.
pa/ntas d' e)pai/nhmi kai\ file/w,
mhde\n ai)sxro/n, a)na/gka| d' ou)de\ qeoi\ ma/xontai.

There is little probability in this arrangement. Schneidewin altogether neglects the evident metrical resemblance between the words from e)/moig' e)carkei= to toi=si/ t' ai)sxra\ mh\ me/miktaiSee the restoration below on p. 216. and the other sections of the poem. But the obvious and indeed fatal objection to Schneidewin's restoration is that he makes a wide departure from the order of the words as they come in Plato, placing the e)/moig' e)carkei= ktl. of 346Cbefore the tou)/neken ou)/pot' e)gw/ of 345C That Socrates reverts in 346Dto tou)/neken ou)/pot' e)gw\ ktl. is no reason for placing these words in the last part of the poem, any more than we should place the words *)/andr' a)gaqo\n me\n a)laqe/ws ktl. after a)/ndra d' ou)k e)/sti ktl. because Socrates reverts to them in 344E A man who professes to be
giving a continuous exposition of a poem may revert to the middle of it when he has come to the end, in order to illustrate the sentiment with which the poem concludes, but it would be the superfluity of naughtiness to put the end of the poem into the middle, which is what Schneidewin makes Socrates do. If ou) zhtw= ktl. in 346Dwere in reality the conclusion of the poem, we ought to frame our *strofh\ b' out of these very words, and not from tou)/neken ou(/pot' e)gw\ ktl. We should then have to omit the words a)na/gka| d' ou)de\ qeoi\ ma/xontai, because they are not found in 346DE, but it is beyond question that these words are part of Simonides' poem. It is tolerably certain that in 346Dwe have but a recapitulation of part of the argument, presented as a commentary on the concluding text pa/nta toi kala\ ktl., which sums up the whole ethical teaching of the poem. This is practically admitted by Schneidewin himself when he writes his final strophe not as it appears in 346D but as it stands in 345CD.

BergkPoetae Lyr. Graeci4, III, 384 ff. arranges the poem in three complete strophes. His restoration has the merit of recognising the similarity in rhythm between Schneidewin's epode and the other parts of the poem; several of his emendations are also in all probability right.See the footnotes on p. 213. It may, however, be doubted whether he does well in altogether excluding from the poem the words e)/moig' e)carkei= and ou) ga/r ei)mi filo/mwmos, and he deserts the Platonic order even more ruthlessly than Schneidewin when he places o(\s a)\n h)=|Bergk's emendation for mh/. kako\s—mh\ me/miktai directly after a)/neu yo/gou tetugme/non, besides that Plato clearly indicates by the words proio/ntos tou= a)/|smatos (339C, o)li/gon—ei)s to\ pro/sqen proelqw/n (339D, and o)li/ga dielqw/n (344B, that there is a lacuna after tetugme/non.

BlassIn the Rheinisches Museum for 1872, pp. 326 ff. agrees with Bergk in regarding the poem as a sequence of strophes, but discovers four of these in place of three. In the first strophe Blass's arrangement agrees with that of Schneidewin; in the second, he supposes the first two verses to be lost, and the rest to contain o(\s a)\n h)=| kako\s ktl. down to toi=si/ t' ai)sxra\ mh\ me/miktai; the third consists of ou)de/ moi e)mmele/ws—tou/s ke qeoi\ filw=sin; the fourth and last extends from tou)/neken ou)/ pot' e)gw/ to a)na/gkh? d' ou)de\ qeoi\ ma/xontai. This arrangement (which further agrees with that of Bergk in rejecting e)/moig' e)carkei= and ou) ga/r ei)mi filo/mwmos) upsets even more completely
than either of the others the sequence of the poem as it is given by Plato, and for that reason is most unlikely to be right.
The only arrangement which faithfully adheres to the Platonic order of citation is that of Aars, in the treatise referred to already.P. 212, n. 1.
div.head: STROPHE 1
div.p: 1. *)/andr' a)gaqo\n me\n a)laqe/ws gene/sqai xalepo/n,
2. xersi/n te kai\ posi\ kai\ no/w| tetra/gwnon, a)/neu yo/gou tetugme/non.
Verses 3-7 are wanting.
div.head: STROPHE 2
div.p: 1. ou)de/ moi e)mmele/ws to\ *pitta/keion ne/metai,
2. kai/toi sofou= para\ fwto\s ei)rhme/non: xalepo\n fa/t' e)sqlo\n e)/mmenai.
3. qeo\s a)\n mo/nos tou=t' e)/xoi ge/ras: a)/ndra d' ou)k e)/sti mh\ ou) kako\n e)/mmenai,
4. o(\n a)mh/xanos sumfora\ kaqe/lh|.
5. pra/cas me\n eu)= pa=s a)nh\r a)gaqo/s,
6. kako\s d' ei) kakw=s <tis>,
7. kai\ to\ plei=ston a)/ristoi, tou/s ke qeoi\ filw=sin.
div.head: STROPHE 3
div.p: 1. tou)/neken ou)/ pot' e)gw\ to\ mh\ gene/sqai dunato\n
2. dizh/menos kenea\n e)s a)/prakton e)lpi/da moi=ran ai)w=nos bale/w,
3. pana/mwmon a)/nqrwpon, eu)ruedou=s o(/soi karpo\n ai)nu/meqa xqono/s:
4. e)pi\ d' u)/mmin eu(rw\n a)paggele/w.
5. pa/ntas d' e)pai/nhmi kai\ file/w,
6. e(kw\n o)/stis e(/rdh?
7. mhde\n ai)sxro/n: a)na/gkh| d' ou)de\ qeoi\ ma/xontai.
div.head: STROPHE 4
div.p: 1. Wanting.
2. ¯ ¯ ˘ ¯ ˘ ˘ ¯ ˘ [ou)/k ei)m' e)gw\ filo/mwmos:] e)carkei= g' e)moi/,
3. o(\s a)\n h)=| kako\s mhd' a)/gan a)pa/lamnos, ei)dw/s g' o)nhsi/polin di/kan,
4. u(gih\s a)nh/r, ou)de\ mh/ min e)gw\
5. mwmh/somai: tw=n ga\r h)liqi/wn
6. a)pei/rwn gene/qla:
7. pa/nta toi kala/, toi=si/ t' ai)sxra\ mh\ me/miktai.

This restoration seems to us on the whole the most probable. In l. 4 of strophe 2 Plato no doubt wrote o(
 a)/n (the MSS. reading) for o(/n, using the more common construction in defiance of metre, just as in l. 5 ga/r after me/n is due to the desire to show the sequence of thought. In ll. 6 and 7 of the same strophe Plato omits some monosyllable after kakw=s, perhaps tis or ti or au)=: Hermann's view that kai/ of the next line should be written in l. 6, and l. 7 be made into tou)pi/pleiston a)/ristoi ktl., is perhaps less probable. For l. 7 we should prefer as nearer to the words of Plato ka)pi\ plei=ston a)/ristoi ktl. In the third strophe we prefer e)pi/ t' u)/mmin for the reasons given in the note upon the passage on p. 180. In the last strophe o(\s a)
 h)=| kako/s is Bergk's emendation for o\s a)
 mh\ kako\s h)=|: here again Plato substitutes the commoner idiom for the rarer and more poetic, with which we may compare Aristophanes, Birds, 694 gh= d' ou)d' a)h ou)d' ou)rano\s h)=n. It is, however, more likely that Simonides wrote o(\s a)
 h)=| kako\s mh/t' a)/gan a)pa/lamnos, i.e. mh/te kako\s mh/te ktl., for this idiom is seldom found with mhde/ or ou)de/: see Jebb on Sophocles, Philoctetes, 771. To take mhde/ for a)lla\ mh/ would give a wrong meaning, as can be seen from the paraphrase in 346Da)lla/ moi e)carkei= a)
 h)=| me/sos kai\ mhde
 kako
 poih=|. It seems better too, in this line, to take ei)dw/s g' o)nhsi/polin di/kan u(gih\s a)nh/r (sc. e)stin) together, and print colons before ei)dw/s and after a)nh/r. In l. 4 ou)de\ mh/ min is Bergk's restoration for mh/n of the MSS. The position assigned by Aars to ou)/k ei)m' e)gw\ filo/mwmos (in l. 2) is only tentative, but it is slightly supported by ou) dia\ tau=ta/ se ye/gw o(/ti ei)mi\ filo/yogos coming before e)/moig' e)carkei= in 346C There is nothing in Plato to indicate that the first line (with part of the second) is wanting in strophe 4, but neither is there anything to prove the reverse, and (since the poem is not in any case preserved entire, five verses being omitted in the first strophe) it is much more reasonable to assume an omission here than violently to distort the sequence of the poem as quoted by Plato.

Whether the poem is to be ranked as an w)|dh\ e)pi/nikos, an e)gkw/mion, or a sko/lion is a question which should not be raised until the poem has first been restored from the quotations in the Protagoras. If the restoration given above is even approximately correct, the poem cannot be classed as an epinikion; an encomium it is not likely to be, since no one is praised. There is no reason whatever for identifying it with the famous encomium
referred to by Quintilian (XI. 2. 11). Blass holds that the poem was a scolion, and this is by far the most probable view, but no certainty is attainable on the point. With the exception of the lacunae which we have noted, the poem is most probably complete, for Socrates is trying to prove that Simonides attacks Pittacus throughout the whole poem: see 345Dou(/tw sfo/dra kai\ di' o(/lou tou= a)/|smatos e)pece/rxetai tw=| tou= *pittakou= r(h/mati and 343C 344B
We add a translation of the poem, incorporating the few changes which we have made in Aars's restoration.
div.head: STROPHE 1
div.p: It is hard to quit you like a truly good man, in hands and feet and mind foursquare, fashioned without blame.
(The five lost vv, may have further elaborated the meaning of ‘truly good’.)
div.head: STROPHE 2
div.p: Nor do I deem the word of Pittacus well said, wise though he was that spake it: ‘it is hard’ he said ‘to be noble.’ To a god alone belongs that meed; a man cannot but prove evil, if hopeless calamity overthrow him. Every man if he has fared well is good, evil, if ill; and for the most part best are they whom the gods love.
div.head: STROPHE 3
div.p: Therefore never will I cast away my portion of life vainly upon a bootless hope, seeking what cannot come to be, an all-blameless man, of us who take the fruit of the broad earth; when I find him, look you, you shall hear. I praise and love all them that willingly do nothing base; against necessity even gods do not contend.
div.head: STROPHE 4
div.p: ¯ ¯ ¯ [I love not fault-finding]; enough for me if one be not evi nor exceeding violent: yea sound is the man who knoweth justice, benefactress of cities; nor will I find fault with him; for the tribe of fools is infinite. Surely all is fair wherein is no alloy of foul.

The easy-going morality of the poem is in harmony with what we know both of the life and poetry of Simonides: he was ever ‘a genial and courtly man’, anxious to make the most of life, ‘dwelling with flowers like the bee, seeking yellow honey’ (Sim. Frag. 47).

div.head: APPENDIX II - PROTAGORAS' LIFE AND WORKS
div.p: We give the life of Protagoras as recorded by Diogenes Laertius (IX. 50-6) and add the fragments of his works, according (in the main) to Frei's arrangement.Quaestiones Protagoreae, pp. 176 ff., where the references are fully given.

div.head: FRAGMENTS
div.p: A. Physical
1. pa/ntwn xrhma/twn me/tron a)/nqrwpos: tw=n me\n o)/ntwn w(s e)/sti, tw=n de\ ou)k o)/ntwn w(s ou)k e)/sti (from *)alh/qeia h)\ peri\ tou= o)/ntos s. *kataba/llontes: see Pl. Theaet. 152A).

2. peri\ me
 qew=n ou)k e)/xw ei)de/nai ou)/q' w(s ei)si
 ou)/q' w(s ou)k ei)si/n: rolla\ ga\p ta\ kwlu/onta ei)de/nai: h(/ te a)dhlo/ths kai\ bpaxu\s w)
 o( bi/os tou= a)nqrw/pou (from peri\ qew=n ap. Diog. Laert. IX. 51).
From Protagoras' peri\ tw=n e)n *ai(/dou no fragments seem to survive.
B. Ethical
Of the peri\ a)retw=n there seem to be no fragments.

3. tw=n ga ui(e/wn nehniw=n o)/ntwn kai\ kalw=n, e)n o)ktw\ de\ tai=s ra/sh|si h(me/ph|si a)roqano/ntwn nhrenqe/ws a)ne/tlh. eu)di/hs ga\p ei)/xeto, e)c h(=s rollo
 w)/nhto kata\ ra=san h(me/phn ei)s eu)rotmi/hn kai\ a)nwduni/hn kai\ th
 e)n toi=si rolloi=si do/can. ra=s ga/p ti/s min o(pw=n ta\ e(wutou= re/nqea e)ppwme/nws fe/ponta megalo/fpona/ te kai\ a)ndpei=on e)do/kei ei)=nai kai\ e(wutou= krei/ssw, ka/rta ei)dw\s th
 e(wutou= e)n toioi=sde pra/gmasi a)mhxani/hnThe Ionic is as it appears in Plutarch. Following the example of Frei, we have not written the other fragments in Ionic. (from (?) peri\ tw=n ou)k o)rqw=s toi=s a)nqrw/pois prassome/nwn ap. Plut. Consol. ad Apoll. 33. 118E-F. The subject is the fortitude of Pericles on hearing of the death of his two sons, Paralus and Xanthippus).
The peri\ filotimi/as is known only from Diogenes' catalogue (IX. 55).
C. Political
Of the peri\ politei/as nothing (so far as is known) survives.
4. h)=n ga/r pote xro/nos—ktei/nein w(s vo/son po/lews (from (?) peri\ th=s e)n a)rxh=? katasta/sews ap. Pl. Prot. 320C322D.
D. Grammatical
Of the peri\ o)rqoepei/as (mentioned in Pl. Phaedr. 267C) nothing remains.
E. Rhetorical
5. (?) du/o lo/goi ei)si\ peri\ panto\s pra/gmatos a)ntikei/menoi a)llh/lois (from the a)ntilogiw=n du/o ap. Diog. Laert. IX. 51).
6. to\n h(/ttw lo/gon krei/ttw poiei=n (from the te/xnh e)ristikw=n ap. Ar. Rhet. 11. 24, p. 1402a. 23).
The di/kh u(pe\r misqou= (Diog. Laert. IX. 55) and the ‘rerum illustrium disputationes, quae nunc communes appellantur loci’ (Cic. Brut. 46) have apparently left no trace.
F. Various

7. fu/sews kai\ a)skh/sews didaskali/a dei=tai, kai\ a)po\ veo/thtos de\ a)rcame/nous dei= manqa/nein (from the me/gas lo/gos—probably identical with the *prostaktiko/s: see Cramer, Anecdot. Paris, 1, 171).
8. [*prwtago/ras e)/lege] mhde\n ei)=nai mh/te te/xnhn a)/neu mele/ths mh/te mele/thn a)/neu te/xnhsCf. Gomperz (cited in the next note), p. 11. (perhaps from the same, ap. Stob. Flor. 29. 80).

Another fragment, probably from the same work, is quoted by J. Gildermeister and F. Bücheler from a Syriac translation of Plutarch's peri\ a)skh/sews (Rhein. Mus. XXVII, 1872, 526). The original perhaps ran:
9. ou) blasta/nei paidei/a e)n th=? yuxh=?, e)a\n mh/ tis ei)s buqo\n e)/lqh?.

Of the peri\ maqhma/twn, and the peri\ texnw=n (of which perhaps the peri\ pa/lhs was a part) nothing (so far as is certainly known) survives. Gomperz's ingenious and learned attemptReprinted from the Sitzungsberichte der Kais. Akademie der Wissenschaft in Wien: Philosophisch-Historische Classe, Band CXX. to prove that the ‘Defence of Medicine’ which under the title of peri\ te/xnhs appears in the collection of Hippocratean worksLittré, VI, 1-27. was written by Protagoras and belongs to the treatise peri\ texnw=n has not, as yet, commended itself to critics.See Wellmann in the Archiv für Geschichte der Philosophie, V, 97 ff.
